                                                  FOREWORD

It gives me great pleasure to write a foreword to the Textbook of Preclinical Conservative
Dentistry. Preclinical Conservative Dentistry has assumed a lot of significance with relevance
to the rapid progress made in dental materials and instruments. Preclinical Conservative
Dentistry has been introduced as a separate examination subject bearing in mind the importance
it demands. This textbook forms the basis and backbone for a dental student for his future
clinical training. It assumes greater importance in view of the fact that these fundamentals
are to be properly imparted to the dental student.
    This book on Preclinical Conservative Dentistry explicitly deals with these fundamentals
in different Chapters dealing widely in introduction, description of teeth, instruments,
nomenclature, tooth preparation, filling materials including endodontics. The significance of
this book is that these fundamentals are explained in a simple understandable manner which will make the student grasp
the same without any strain or confusion. I am sure, this will also be useful as a handbook or reference book to all the
dentists as well.
    I have no hesitation in recommending this book to all dental students as well as dental surgeons and I heartily
congratulate Dr Nisha Garg on her excellent effort in bringing out this book in a presentable way.




                                                                                               S Ramachandran MDS
                                                                   Principal, Ragas Dental College & Hospital, Chennai
                                                                     Professor, Conservative Dentistry & Endodontics
                                                                                      Member, Dental Council of India
                                                       PREFACE

Operative dentistry is one of the oldest branches of dental sciences forming the central part of dentistry as practiced in
primary care. It occupies the use of majority of dentist’s working life and is a key component of restorative dentistry. The
subject and clinical practice of conservative dentistry continues to evolve rapidly as a result of improved understanding of
etiology, prevention and management of common dental diseases. The advances and developments within the last two
decades have drastically changed the scope of this subject. But before taking professional training, gathering basic
knowledge along with operating skill is mandatory.
    The main objective of this book is to provide students with the knowledge required while they are developing necessary
clinical skills and attitude in their undergraduate training in conservative dentistry and endodontics. We have tried to cover
wide topics like morphology of teeth, cariology, different techniques, instruments and materials available for restorations
of teeth along with the basics of endodontics.
    So we can say that after going through this book, the student should be able to:
• Sit properly while operating and be able to organize their operating environment efficiently.
• Understand the morphology of teeth and differentiate one tooth from another.
• Chart teeth.
• Understand basics of cariology, its prevention and conservative management.
• Tell indications and contraindications of different dental materials.
• Apply modern pulp protective regimens.
• Select suitable restorative materials for restoration of teeth.
• Understand the basics of endodontic treatment like what are the indications of endodontic treatment, basic instruments,
    access preparation, biomechanical preparation and obturation of root canal system.


                                                                                                                 Nisha Garg
                                                                                                                 Amit Garg

First and foremost, we bow in gratitude to Almighty God for endowing us strength, courage and confidence in accomplishing
this venture to best of our abilities. Without his blessings, we could not have completed this project.

persons who helped us.

(Vice-Chairman) MRDC, Faridabad for providing healthy and encouraging environment for our work.

occupation and inspired us to learn more and more.
    We would like to express our thanks to staff of Department of Operative Dentistry, MRDC, Faridabad, Dr Arundeep
Singh, Dr Manish Gupta and Dr Sarika for their “ready to help” attitude, constant guidance and positive criticism which
helped in improvement of this book.

support and constant encouragement.

staff of Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers, New Delhi, for all encouragement as well as for bringing out this book in an
excellent form.
    Last but not least, we are thankful to students of this country, who appreciated our previous books “Textbook of
Endodontics”, “Review of Endodontics and Operative Dentistry” and “Textbook of Operative Dentistry” and encouraged
us to venture out this project.

                                                                                                                surfaces of maxillary molars. It is usually formed by the
                                                 As we know there are 32 teeth in permanent dentition and
                                                                                                                union of triangular ridge of distobuccal cusp and distal cusp
                                                 20 teeth in deciduous dentition. A tooth has crown and a
                                                                                                                ridge of the mesiolingual cusp.
                                                 root portion. Crown part of the tooth is covered with enamel
                                                 and root portion of tooth is covered by cementum. The          Fossa: It is an irregular depression or concavity.
                                                 crown and root join at cementoenamel junction (CEJ).
                                                    Before discussing the individual tooth, one should be       Lingual fossae: Occur on lingual surface of incisors.
                                                 familiar with few terms. These are:                            Central fossae: Occur on occlusal surface of molars.
                                                 Cervical line: Each tooth has a crown and root portion.
                                                 The crown is covered with enamel and the root portion is       Sulcus: It is a long depression on the surface of tooth ridges
                                                 covered with cementum. The crown and root join at the          and cusps.
                                                 cementoenamel junction (CEJ). This junction is also called     Developmental groove: It is shallow groove between the
                                                 the cervical line.                                             primary parts of the crown or root.
                                                 Cingulum: It is lingual lobe of an anterior tooth and makes
                                                 up the bulk of the cervical third of the lingual surface.      Pits: These are small pinpoint depressions located at the
                                                                                                                junction of developmental grooves or at ending of those
                                                 Ridge: It is linear elevation on the surface of a tooth.       grooves.
                                                 Marginal ridges: These are rounded borders of enamel
                                                 that form the mesial and distal margins of occlusal surfaces   Lobe: It is one of the primary sections of formation in the
                                                 of posterior teeth (premolars and molars) and mesial and       development of the crown.
                                                 distal margins of the lingual surfaces of anterior teeth       Mamelons: These are three rounded protuberances found
                                                 (incisors and canines).                                        on the incisal edges of newly erupted incisor teeth.
                                                 Triangular ridges: These descend from the tips of the
                                                                                                                Cusp: It is elevation on the crown portion of a tooth making
                                                 cusps of molars and premolars toward the central part of
                                                                                                                up a divisional part of the occlusal surface.
                                                 occlusal surfaces.

                                                 ridges join, they combine to form a transverse ridge.          produced by an extra formation of enamel.

Lingual Aspect (Fig. 1.2)
1. Mesial and distal outlines converge palatally.
2. Below cervical line, a smooth convexity is present called
   cingulum.
3. Below cingulum there is a shallow concavity which is
   bordered by mesial and distal marginal ridge, incisal ridge
   and cingulum.

Mesial Aspect (Fig. 1.3)
1. Wedge triangular shaped crown with base towards cervix
   and apex towards incisal ridge.
2. Incisal edge of crown is in line with center of the root.
3. Labial outline is convex from cervix till incisal edge.                           Fig. 1.2: Lingual aspect

Buccal Aspect (Fig. 1.16)                                         developmental depressions of roots.
1. Crown is roughly trapezoidal with convex buccal surface     4. Developmental groove is found in enamel of mesial
   and buccal ridge.                                              marginal ridge. This groove is usually continuous with
2. Mesial outline is slightly concave from cervical line to       central groove of occlusal surface of crown.
   the mesial contact area.                                    5. Two roots; one buccal and one palatal are clearly visible
3. Distal outline is straighter than mesial outline.              from mesial aspect.
4. Buccal cusp is long and sharp, and thus resembles canine.
5. Mesial cusp slope is longer than distal cusp slope. This
   difference places buccal cusp tip distal to long axis of
   the tooth.

Palatal Aspect (Fig. 1.17)
1. Due to palatal convergence, crown is narrower on palatal
   side than on buccal side.
2. Palatal cusp is smooth, short and blunt as compared to
   buccal cusp.
3. Mesial and distal slopes of palatal cusp make rounded
   angle at cusp tip.
4. Since palatal cusp is shorter than buccal cusp, the tips
   of both cusps with their mesial and distal slopes can be
   seen from palatal aspect.

Mesial Aspect (Fig. 1.18)
1. Roughly trapezoidal in shape with longest side towards
                                                                                   Fig. 1.17: Palatal aspect
   cervical portion, and shortest towards occlusal portion.




                   Fig. 1.16: Buccal aspect                                        Fig. 1.18: Mesial aspect

                                                 4. Central developmental groove divides the occlusal
                                                    surface buccolingually. This groove extends from distal               Buccal Aspect (Fig. 1.21)
                                                                                                                          1. Crown is shorter (approximately 1 mm) than first
                                                                                                                             premolar.
                                                                                                                          2. It is less pointed and more oblong in shape when
                                                                                                                             compared to first premolar.
                                                                                                                          3. Mesial slope of buccal cusp is shorter than distal slope
                                                                                                                             (reverse is true for first premolar).

                                                                                                                          Palatal Aspect (Fig. 1.22)
                                                                                                                          1. Both palatal and buccal cusps are of same dimensions.
                                                                                                                          2. Palatal surface is narrower than buccal surface.

                                                                                                                          Mesial Aspect (Fig. 1.23)
                                                                                                                          1. Buccal and palatal cusps are of almost same height.
                                                                                                                          2. No developmental groove or depression is found on
                                                                                                                             mesial surface.
                                                                        Fig. 1.19: Distal aspect
                                                                                                                          3. Greater distance between cusp tips increases the
                                                                                                                             dimensions of occlusal surface buccolingually.

                                                 pit; MTF: Mesial triangular fossa; MMDG: Mesial marginal development

                            Distal Aspect (Fig. 1.24)




                                                                                                         Morphology of Teeth
                            It is almost similar to mesial aspect except that distal root
                            depression is present, which is deeper than mesial depression.

                            Occlusal Aspect (Fig. 1.25)
                            1. Outline is rounded or oval.
                            2. Central developmental groove is shorter and more
                               irregular.
                            3. Multiple supplementary grooves radiate from central
                               groove. These groves end in shallow depressions in the
                               enamel of occlusal surface giving it a wrinkled
                               appearance.


Fig. 1.22: Palatal aspect




                            Fig. 1.25: Occlusal aspect: DBCR: Distobuccal cusp ridge; MBCR:
                            Mesiobuccal cusp ridge; DBTG: Distobuccal triangular groove; DMR:
                            Distal marginal ridge; DTF: Distal triangular fossa; DP: Distal pit; DPTG:
                            Distopalatal triangular groove; MBTG: Mesiobuccal triangular groove;
                            MMR: Mesial marginal ridge; MTF: Mesial triangular fossa; MP: Mesial
                            pit; MPTG: Mesiopalatal triangular groove; MPCR: Mesiopalatal cusp
                            ridge


                            FIRST MOLAR
Fig. 1.23: Mesial aspect

                                                     Important features
                             1. First permanent tooth to erupt.
                             2. Most caries prone.
                             3. Location is at center of fully developed jaw antero-
                                posteriorly, so also considered as “corner stones” of
                                dental arches.

                            Buccal Aspect (Fig. 1.26)
                            1. Crown is trapezoidal in shape, the cervical line
                               representing the shorter of uneven sides.
                            2. Two cusps; mesiobuccal and distobuccal are seen.
                            3. Mesiobuccal cusp is broader and its mesial and distal
                               slopes meet at an obtuse angle.
                            4. Distobuccal cusp is less broad and its mesial and distal
                               slopes meet at a right angle.
                            5. Buccal developmental groove divides two buccal cusps.
Fig. 1.24: Distal aspect       It extends occlusoapically and terminates approximately
     10
                                                                                                                           Cusp ridge of this cusp is 2 mm cervical to the
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                      cusp tip of mesiopalatal cusp. Cusp of Carabelli is found
                                                                                                                      in 60 percent of cases.
                                                                                                                   5. Mesiopalatal cusp is the longest cusp whereas
                                                                                                                      distopalatal cusp is round and spheroidal in shape.
                                                                                                                   6. All three roots are visible from this aspect.

                                                                                                                   Mesial Aspect (Fig. 1.28)
                                                                                                                   1. Crown appears as shorter and broader buccolingually.
                                                                                                                   2. Mesiobuccal, mesiopalatal and fifth cup, “the cusp of
                                                                                                                      Carabelli” are seen from this aspect.
                                                                                                                   3. Mesial marginal ridge is confluent with mesiobuccal and
                                                                                                                      mesiopalatal cusp ridges. It is irregular and curves
                                                                                                                      cervically.
                                                                     Fig. 1.26: Buccal aspect
                                                                                                                   Distal Aspect (Fig. 1.29)
                                                                                                                   1. It is almost similar to that of mesial aspect.

                                                                                                                   1. Almost rhomboidal or parallelogram in outline with four

                                                 Mesial Aspect (Fig. 1.33)
                                                 Crown length is less when compared to first molar. Mesial
                                                 marginal ridge is located more occlusally than distal marginal
                                                 ridge.

                                                 Distal Aspect (Fig. 1.34)
                                                 1. Since distobuccal cusp is smaller, mesiobuccal cusp can
                                                    be seen from this aspect.
                                                 2. Distal marginal ridge is placed more cervically than
                                                    mesial marginal ridge.
                                                                                                                                     Fig. 1.35: Occlusal aspect
                                                 Occlusal Aspect (Fig. 1.35)
                                                 It is almost similar to maxillary first molar except that:
                                                 1. Mesiodistal dimensions are smaller than first molar.
                                                                                                                  Labial Aspect (Fig. 1.36)
                                                 2. Mesiobuccal and mesiopalatal cusps are same as that of
                                                      first molar, but distobuccal and distopalatal cusps are     1. Crown is smooth, tapered from incisal ridge to cervical
                                                      smaller and less well developed.                               portion.
                                                 3. Fifth cusp is missing.                                        2. Sharp mesial and distal incisal angles with straight incisal
                                                 4. More of supplementary grooves and pits are present               edge perpendicular to long axis of the tooth.
                                                      than first molar.
                                                                                                                  Lingual Aspect (Fig. 1.37)
                                                               MANDIBULAR TEETH                                   1. Smooth surface with slight concavity.
                                                                                                                  2. Due to lingual convergence, crown is narrower on lingual
                                                 CENTRAL INCISOR                                                     side.
                                                                                                                  3. Small and convex cingulum.
                                                                       Important points                           Mesial Aspect (Fig. 1.38)
                                                  •   Smallest tooth in arch
                                                  •   Bilaterally symmetrical
                                                                                                                  1. Wedge shaped with incisal edge being lingual to long
                                                                                                                     axis of the root.
                                                                                                 13
                            2. Mesial surface is straight above the cervical line till incisal




                                                                                                 Morphology of Teeth
                               ridge.
                            3. Cervical line is deeply curved.

                            Distal Aspect (Fig. 1.39)

                            It is almost similar to mesial aspect, except that cervical
                            line curves 1 mm less than on mesial surface.

                            Incisal Aspect (Fig. 1.40)

                            1. Bilateral symmetrical.
                            2. Incisal edge is perpendicular to the line bisecting
                               labiolingually.
                            3. Labial surface of crown is wider mesiodistally than
                               lingual surface.

                                                 MANDIBULAR LATERAL INCISOR
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry



                                                 Labial Aspect (Fig. 1.41)

                                                 1. Crown is tilted distally on the root.
                                                 2. Mesioincisal angle is sharp, whereas distoincisal angle
                                                    is slightly rounded.

                                                 Lingual Aspect (Fig. 1.42)

                                                 1. Distal marginal ridge is shorter than mesial marginal
                                                    ridge.
                                                 2. Cingulum lies slight distal to the long axis of the tooth.

                                                 Mesial Aspect (Fig. 1.43)
                                                                                                                     Fig. 1.42: Lingual aspect
                                                 1. Slightly longer than distal aspect.
                                                 2. Incisal edge slopes downwards in the distal direction
                                                    due to longer mesial side.
                                                 3. Curvature of cervical line is deep.

                                                 Distal Aspect (Fig. 1.44)
                                                 1. Incisal edge is twisted distolingually, i.e. distal portion is
                                                    placed more lingually than mesial portion.
                                                 2. Curvature of cervical line is less deep than on mesial
                                                    surface.

                                                 Incisal Aspect (Fig. 1.45)
                                                 Incisal edge is twisted distolingually. This twist corresponds
                                                 to the curvature of mandibular arch.

MANDIBULAR CANINE

Labial Aspect (Fig. 1.46)
                                                               Mesial Aspect (Fig. 1.48)
1. Crown is narrower than maxillary canine.
2. Crown appears longer because of its narrowness than         1. Wedge shaped with cusp tip almost centered over the
   maxillary crown.                                               root.
3. Mesial outline is almost straight.                          2. Curvature of cervical line is more than on maxillary
4. Mesial slope of cusp is shorter than distal slope.             canine.
5. Crown appears to be tilted distally because there is more   3. Due to less prominence of cingulum and less labiolingual
   of crown distal to long axis of root than mesial to it.        thickness of crown, cusp appears more pointed with
                                                                  slender cusp ridge.
Lingual Aspect (Fig. 1.47)
                                                               Distal Aspect (Fig. 1.49)
1. Lingual surface is flatter in comparison to maxillary
   canine.                                                     It is almost similar to mesial aspect except that:
2. Cingulum is not very much prominent.                        1. Crown is twisted distolingually, so distolingual angle is

   ridge.                                                      2. Curvature of cervical line is less than on mesial side.

                                                 Incisal Aspect (Fig. 1.50)
                                                 1. Mesiodistal dimensions are lesser than labiolingual
                                                    dimensions.
                                                 2. Cusp tip and mesial cusp ridge are lingually placed.
                                                 3. Tooth appears to have distolingual twist.

                                                 FIRST PREMOLAR

                                                 Buccal Aspect (Fig. 1.51)
                                                 1. Appears bilateral symmetrical.
                                                 2. Buccal cusp tip is located near the long axis of tooth.
                                                 3. Crown appears trapezoidal in shape with cervical margin
                                                    being the shortest of uneven sides.
                                                 4. Buccal cusp tip is pointed and the cusp slopes meet at     Fig. 1.51: Buccal aspect
                                                    an obtuse angle.
                                                 5. Mesial cusp slope is slightly shorter than distal cusp
                                                    slope.
                                                 6. Buccal ridge is present from cervical margin to cusp
                                                    tip.

                                                 Lingual Aspect (Fig. 1.52)
                                                 1. Because of lingual convergence, crown of first premolar
                                                    tapers toward the lingual side.
                                                 2. Lingual cusp is small, with pointed tip.
                                                 3. Middle buccal lobe is well developed making its major
                                                    portion. Due to this feature, it resembles canine.
                                                 4. Mesiolingual developmental groove is present which
                                                    demarcates mesiobuccal and lingual lobe. It extends into
                                                    the mesial fossa of occlusal surface.
                                                 5. A characteristic feature of this tooth is that mesial
                                                    marginal ridge is located more cervically than distal
                                                    marginal ridge.                                            Fig. 1.52: Lingual aspect

Occlusal Aspect (Fig. 1.55)
1. Roughly diamond shaped.
2. Tip of buccal cusp is slightly buccal to center of root.
3. Mesiobuccal and distobuccal line angles are prominent.
4. Buccal ridge appears prominent.
5. Distal marginal ridge is at right angle to the buccal surface
   whereas mesial marginal ridge is at an acute angle to
   buccal surface.
6. Mesial fossa contains mesial developmental groove
   which extends buccolingually.

One Buccal Cusp and Two Lingual Cusps
                                                                                   Fig. 1.61: Buccal aspect
1. Square shape with buccal cusp being largest in size,
   followed by mesiolingual and distolingual cusps.
2. Each cusp has well developed triangular ridges, separated
   by grooves.
3. Grooves join to form a central pit and Y shape
   appearance.
4. Lingual development groove extends between two lingual
   cusps and ends on lingual surface of crown just below
   convergence of lingual cusp ridges.

Operative dentistry plays an important role in enhancing          DEFINITION OF OPERATIVE DENTISTRY
dental health and now branched into dental specialties. Today
operative dentistry continues to be the most active               According to Mosby’s dental dictionary. “Operative dentistry
component of most dental practice. Epidemiologically,             deals with the functional and esthetic restoration of the hard
demand for operative dentistry will not decrease in the future.   tissues of individual teeth.”
26
         According to Sturdvent, “Operative dentistry is defined
     as science and art of dentistry which deals with diagnosis,
     treatment and prognosis of defects of the teeth which do
     not require full coverage restorations for correction.”
         Such corrections and restorations result in the restoration
     of proper tooth form, function and esthetics while
     maintaining the physiological integrity of the teeth in
     harmonious relationship with the adjacent hard and soft
     tissues. Such restorations enhance the dental and general
     health of the patient.
         According to Gilmore, “Operative dentistry is a subject                            Fig. 2.2: Maxillary central and lateral incisors
     which includes diagnosis, prevention and treatment of
     problems and conditions of natural teeth vital or nonvital so
     as to preserve natural dentition and restore it to the best                 Incisors
     state of health, function and esthetics.”                                   The square-shaped teeth located in front of the mouth, with
                                                                                 four on the upper and four on the lower are called incisors.
     Definition of dental anatomy or anatomy of teeth is the                     Incisors are important teeth for phonetics and esthetics.
     branch of anatomy which deals with the study of human                       They help in cutting the food (Fig. 2.2).
     teeth structures. It includes development, appearance and
     classification of teeth. Dental anatomy is also a taxonomical               Canines
     science; it is concerned with the naming of teeth and the
     structures of which they are made.                                          The sharp teeth located near the corner of the mouth.
         For convenience human dentition is divided into four                    Because of their anatomy and long root, they are strong
     quadrants viz; upper (maxillary) right, upper (maxillary) left,             teeth. They help in tearing and cutting of food (Fig. 2.3).
     lower (mandibular) right and lower (mandibular) left (Fig.
                                                                                 Premolars
     2.1). Right and left here relate to patient’s right and left
     side.                                                                       There are a total of eight premolars inside the mouth present
         It is important to understand anatomy of teeth because                  after the canines. Four premolars are present in upper and
     of following reasons:                                                       lower arch, two on each side of the canine. Facially they
     • For maintenance of supporting tissues in the healthy                      resemble canines and lingually as molars (Fig. 2.4). They
         state.                                                                  help in tearing and grinding of the food.
     • For restoration of damaged tooth to its original form.
     • For optimal functions of teeth.

     CLASSES OF HUMAN TEETH
     Depending upon their form and function human teeth can
     be divided into following classes:

     quadrants, i.e. upper right, upper left, lower right and lower left. Here
     right and left relate to patient’s right and left                               Fig. 2.3: Maxillary canine showing sharp tip and long root

Molars (Fig. 2.5)
                                                                     The second set of teeth, i.e. the permanent teeth erupt
Distal to premolars are the molars. There are six molars on
                                                                 at the age of six. There are a total of 32 permanent teeth in
each arch (three on each side), therefore a total of 12 inside
                                                                 an adult mouth. Total number of teeth are divided into two
the mouth. They have multiple cusps which help in crushing
                                                                 arches, i.e. an upper and a lower arch each found on the
and grinding the food. These teeth also help in maintenance
                                                                 upper and lower jaws respectively. Normally, a total of 16
of vertical height of the face.
                                                                 teeth may be found on each complete arch.
SETS OF TEETH
                                                                 TOOTH NUMBERING SYSTEMS
There are two sets of teeth that develop in a person’s mouth
                                                                 There are different tooth numbering systems for naming a
(Fig. 2.6). The first set of teeth is called as “milk or baby”
                                                                 specific tooth. The three most commons systems are the
or “primary teeth”. The total number of teeth in this set are
                                                                 FDI World Dental Federation notation, Universal numbering
twenty. Primary teeth erupt at the age between 6 months
                                                                 system and Zsigmondy-Palmer notation method. The FDI
and 2 years. Most children develop all their primary teeth at
                                                                 system is used worldwide and the universal is used widely
the age of three.
                                                                 in the USA.

                                                                       Most commonly used tooth numbering systems
                                                                  1. Zsigmondy-Palmer system
                                                                  2. Universal system (ADA system)
                                                                  3. FDI system (Fédération Dentaire Internationale)

                                                                 Zsigmondy-Palmer System (Fig. 2.7)
                                                                 It was originally termed as “Zsigmondy system” after the
                                                                 Austrian dentist Adolf Zsigmondy who developed the idea
                                                                 in 1861, using a Zsigmondy cross to record quadrants of
                                                                 tooth positions.
                                                                     Adult teeth were numbered 1 to 8 and the primary
                                                                 dentition as Roman numerals I, II, III, IV, V from the midline.
                                                                 Palmer changed this to A, B, C, D, E. This makes it less
              Fig. 2.5: Photograph showing molars                confusing and less prone to errors in interpretation.
28




             Fig. 2.7: Diagram showing presentation of Zsigmondy-Palmer     Fig. 2.8: Diagram showing presentation of universal system of
                  notation of both deciduous and permanent dentitions        tooth nomenclature for both deciduous and permanent teeth


         The Zsigmondy-Palmer notation consists of a symbol               The universal numbering system uses a unique letter or
     () designating in which quadrant the tooth is found and a            number for each tooth.
     number indicating the position from the midline. Permanent               The universal/national system is represented as
     teeth are numbered 1 to 8 and primary teeth are indicated            follows.
     by a letter A to E.
                                                                          Permanent Teeth
     Advantages
                                                                          For permanent teeth, 1 is the patient’s upper right third
     •       Simple and easy to use.
                                                                          molar and follows around the upper arch to the upper left
     •       Less chances of confusion between primary and
                                                                          third molar 16, descending to the lower left third molar 17
             permanent tooth as there is different notation, e.g.
                                                                          and follows around the lower arch to the lower right third
             permanent teeth are described by numbers while primary
             teeth by alphabets.                                          molar (32) (Fig. 2.8).
                                                                              In this system, the teeth that should be there are
     Disadvantages                                                        numbered. If wisdom tooth is missing the first number will
                                                                          be 2 instead of 1, acknowledging the missing tooth. If teeth
     •       Difficulty in communication.
                                                                          have been extracted or teeth are missing, the missing teeth
     •       Confusion between upper and lower quadrants, while
                                                                          will be numbered as well.
             communication and transferring a data.
                                                                              In the original system, children’s 20 primary teeth were
                                     Features
                                                                          numbered in the same order, except that a small letter “d”
                                                                          follows each number to indicate deciduous teeth. So, a
         •     Introduced by “Zsigmondy” in 1861                          child’s first tooth on the upper right would be 1d and the
         •     Each quadrant is designated by symbol
                                                                          last tooth on the lower right would be 20d.
         •     Permanent teeth are numbered 1-8
         •     Primary teeth are indicated by A-E
                                                                          Modified Version of Universal System
     Universal System                                                     Order for the Primary Dentition
     This system was given by American Dental Association in              It is denoted by English upper case letters A through T
     1968. This system is most popular in the United States.              instead of number 1 to 20, with A being the patient’s upper
                                                                                                                                  29
right second primary molar and T being the lower right
second primary molar, e.g.
B is maxillary right deciduous first molar
P is mandibular right deciduous central incisor
5 is maxillary right permanent first premolar

Advantage
Unique letter or number for each tooth avoiding confusions.

Disadvantage
Difficult to remember each letter or number of tooth.

                          Features
 •   Given by American Dental Association in 1968
 •   Use a unique number/letter for each tooth
 •   Permanent teeth are numbered 1-32 starting from
     upper       right molar
 •   Deciduous teeth are designated as A-T, in this A is upper
     right second molar.

FDI—Fédération Dentaire Internationale
(Two-digit Notation)
This two-digit system was first introduced in 1971 which
later on, was adopted by ADA (1996). This system is
commonly practiced in European countries and Canada.                   Fig. 2.9: Diagram showing presentation of FDI system of
Now it is gaining popularity in India also.                              tooth nomenclature for permanent and primary teeth
    This system is known as two digit system because it
uses a two-digit numbering system in which the first number       8. Teeth are numbered from number 1 to 5, 1 being central
represents a tooth’s quadrant and the second number               incisor and 5 is second molar.
represents the number of the tooth from the midline of the
                                                                  Advantages
face. Both digits should be pronounced separately while
communication. For example, the lower left permanent              •   Simple to understand
second molar is 37; however, it is not said thirty-seven, but     •   Simple to teach
rather three seven.

Permanent Teeth (Fig. 2.9)
In the FDI (Fédération Dentaire Internationale) notation 1s
are central incisors, 2s are laterals, 3s are canines, 4s are
1st premolars, 5s are 2nd premolars, 6s are the 1st molar,
etc. up through 8s which are 3rd molars. The permanent
teeth quadrants are designated 1 to 4 such that 1 is upper
right, 2 is upper left, 3 is lower left and 4 is lower right,
with the resulting tooth identification a two-digit combination
of the quadrant and tooth (e.g. the upper right canine is 13
and the left is 23) (Figs 2.10 and 2.11).

Deciduous Teeth
In the deciduous dentition the numbering is correspondingly             Fig. 2.10: Diagrammatic presentation of FDI notation of
similar except that the quadrants are designated 5, 6, 7 and                  maxillary right canine and left second molar
30
                                                                                                         Features
                                                                            •   Introduced in 1971
                                                                            •   Also known as two-digit notation
                                                                            •   In two-digit system, first number represents tooth’s
                                                                                quadrant while second number—number of tooth from
                                                                                midline
                                                                            •   Permanent right central incisor is designated as 11
                                                                            •   Deciduous right central incisor is designated as 51.


                                                                           Comparison of Tooth Numbering Systems
                                                                           As a result, any given tooth has three different ways to
                                                                           identify it, depending on which notation system is used (Fig.
                                                                           2.12). The permanent left maxillary central incisor is
                   Fig. 2.11: FDI system of permanent teeth
                                                                           identified by the number “9” in the universal system. In the
                                                                           FDI system, the same tooth is identified by the number
     •     Simple to pronounce                                             “21”. The Palmer system uses the number and symbol, L1,
     •     No confusion                                                    to identify the tooth. Further confusion may result if a
     •     Each tooth has specific number                                  number is given on a tooth without assuming a common
     •     Easy to record on computers                                     notation method. Since, the number, “21”, may signify the
     •     Easy for charting.                                              permanent left mandibular first premolar in the universal
                                                                           system                                                       or
     Disadvantage                                                          the permanent left maxillary central incisor in the FDI system,
     May be confused with universal tooth numbering system.                the notation being used must be clear to prevent confusion.

     NOMENCLATURE OF TOOTH SURFACES
                                                                     Gingival
     Coronal portion of each tooth is divided into surfaces that
     are designated according to their related anatomic structures   Tooth surface near to gingiva.
     and landmarks (Fig. 2.13).                                      Cervical
     Buccal                                                          Tooth surface near the cervix or neck of tooth.
     Tooth surface facing the check.                                 Anatomic Crown

     Labial                                                          It is part of tooth that is covered with enamel (Fig. 2.14).

     Tooth surface facing the lip.                                   Clinical Crown
                                                                     It is part of tooth that is visible in oral cavity (Fig. 2.14). In
     Facial
                                                                     case of gingival recession, clinical crown is longer than
     Labial and buccal surface collectively form facial surface.     anatomical crown (Fig. 2.15).

     Mesial
     Tooth surface toward the anterior midline.

     Distal
     Tooth surface away from the anterior midline.

     Lingual
     Tooth surface towards the tongue.

     Occlusal
     Masticating surface of posterior teeth (in molar or
     premolar).

     Incisal
     Functioning/cutting edge of anterior tooth (in incisors and
                                                                                 Fig. 2.15: When there is gingival recession,
     cuspids).                                                                  clinical crown is more than anatomical crown
                                                                                                                                      33
                                                                   Residual Caries
                                                                   It is demineralized tissue left in place before a restoration is
                                                                   placed. It can occur by clinician’s neglect or intentionally.

                                                                   Active Carious Lesion
                                                                   A progressive lesion is described as an active carious
                                                                   lesion.

                                                                   Inactive/Arrested Carious Lesion
                                                                   A lesion that may have formed earlier and then stopped is
                                                                   referred to as an arrested or inactive carious lesion. Arrested
                                                                   carious lesion is characterized by a large open preparation
                                                                   which no longer retains food and becomes self-cleansing.

           Fig. 2.16: Photograph showing dental caries             Pits and Fissure Caries
                                                                   Pit and fissure caries are the caries which occur on occlusal
                                                                   surface of posterior teeth and buccal and lingual surfaces
NOMENCLATURE RELATED                                               of molars and on lingual surface of maxillary incisors
TO DENTAL CARIES                                                   (Fig. 2.18).

                                                                   Smooth Surface Caries
Dental Caries
                                                                   Smooth surface caries occurs on gingival third of buccal
It is defined as a microbiological disease of the hard structure   and lingual surfaces and on proximal surfaces (Fig. 2.19).
of teeth, which results in localized demineralization of the
inorganic portion and destruction of the organic substances        Root Caries
of the tooth (Fig. 2.16).
                                                                   Root caries occur on exposed root cementum and dentin
                                                                   usually following gingival recession.
Primary Caries
It denotes lesions on unrestored surfaces.                         Acute Dental Caries
                                                                   Acute caries travels towards the pulp at a very fast speed.
Recurrent Caries
Lesions developing adjacent or beneath the restorations            Rampant Caries
are referred to as either recurrent or secondary caries            It is the name given to multiple active carious lesions
(Fig. 2.17).                                                       occurring in the same patient, frequently involving surfaces

                     Fig. 2.19: Smooth surface caries                          Fig. 2.20: Photograph showing abrasion cavities

     of teeth that are usually caries-free. Rampant caries is of       Abfraction
     following three types:
     • Early childhood caries is a term used to describe dental        Abfractions are the microfractures which appear in the
         caries presenting in the primary dentition of young           enamel as cervical area of tooth flexes under heavy loads.
         children.                                                     Abfraction lesion appears as a wedge shaped defect with
     • Bottle caries or nursing caries are seen in the primary         sharp line angles.
         dentition of infants and young children. The clinical
         pattern is characteristic, with the four maxillary            Resorption
         deciduous incisors most severely affected.
                                                                       Resorption is defined as “a condition associated with either
     • Xerostomia induced rampant caries are commonly seen
         after radiotherapy of malignant areas because of reduced      a physiologic or a pathologic process resulting in the loss
         salivary flow.                                                of dentin, cementum or bone.”
                                                                           If resorption occurs, it is because of some pathologic
     Chronic Dental Caries                                             reasons but deciduous teeth show physiologic resorption
                                                                       before they are shed off.
     Chronic caries progresses very slowly towards the pulp.
     They appear dark in color and hard in consistency.
                                                                       Localized Non-hereditary Enamel Hypoplasia
     NOMENCLATURE RELATED TO                                           It refers to the localized defects in the crown portion of
     NONCARIOUS DEFECTS OF TEETH                                       tooth caused due to injury to ameloblasts during the enamel
                                                                       matrix formative stage. These lesions may appear as isolated
     Attrition
                                                                       pits or widespread linear defects, depressions or loss of a
     It is defined as a physiological, continuous, process resulting   part of enamel. Injury to ameloblasts may be caused by the
     in loss of tooth structure from direct frictional forces          following:
     between contacting teeth. It occurs both on occlusal and          • Traumatic intrusion of deciduous teeth.
     proximal surfaces. Attrition is accelerated by parafunctional
                                                                       • Fluorosis.
     mandibular movements, especially bruxism.
                                                                       • Exanthematous diseases.
     Abrasion                                                          • Deficiency of vitamins A, C and D.
                                                                       • Hypocalcemia.
     It refers to the loss of tooth substance induced by
     mechanical wear other than that of mastication. Abrasion
                                                                       Localized Non-hereditary
     results in saucer-shaped or wedge-shaped indentations with
     a smooth, shiny surface (Fig. 2.20).                              Enamel Hypocalcification
                                                                       It refers to the localized defects in crown portion of tooth
     Erosion                                                           due to injury caused to the ameloblasts during mineralization
     It can be defined as a loss of tooth substance by a chemical      stage. In these, the enamel is normal in structure but its
     process that does not involve known bacterial action. The         mineralization is defective. The color of lesion changes fast
     eroded area appears smooth, hard and polished.                    from chalky to yellow, brown, dark brown or grayish.

Good knowledge of dental anatomy, histology, physiology
and occlusion is the foundation stone of operative dentistry.
In other words, thorough knowledge of morphology, dental
anatomy, histology, is essential to get optimal results of
operative dentistry. Though the dental tissues are passive,
the occurrence of caries can only be understood when the
structure of the teeth is understood.
    The teeth consist of enamel, dentin, pulp and cementum
(Fig. 3.1).

ENAMEL
Tooth enamel is the hardest and most highly mineralized
substance of the body which covers the crown of the tooth.
It is the normally visible dental tissue of a tooth which
is mainly responsible for color, esthetics, texture and
translucency of the tooth. One of the main goal in operative           Fig. 3.1: Diagrammatic representation of enamel,
dentistry is preservation of enamel. So today’s dentistry                    dentin, pulp and supporting structures
                                                                                                                                      37
mainly revolves around simulating natural enamel in its color,




                                                                                                                                      Structure of Teeth
esthetics, contours and translucency by replacing with
synthetic restorative materials.
    Although enamel can serve lifelong, but it is more
susceptible to caries, attrition (physical forces) and fracture
due to its structural make up, i.e. mineralized crystalline
structure and rigidity. One of the interesting features of
enamel is that it cannot repair itself. So, loss in enamel surface
can be compensated only by restorative treatment.

Composition
It is highly mineralized structure which mainly contains
inorganic contents in the form of crystalline structure. Main
inorganic content in the enamel is hydroxyapatite. In addition                 Fig. 3.2: Diagram showing direction of enamel
to inorganic content, it also contains a small portion of                         rods in deciduous and permanent teeth
organic matrix along with small amount of water which is
present in intercrystalline spaces.
                                                                     vertical at the cusp tips. In the cervical region, there is
                         Composition                                 difference in the direction of the enamel rods of deciduous
                                                                     and permanent teeth (Fig. 3.2). The cervical enamel rods

    b. Other minerals and trace elements—3-5%                        in permanent teeth they are inclined apically. This change in
                                                                     direction of enamel rods should be kept in mind during tooth

 1. Proteins and lipids—1-2%

                                                 Color
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 The color of enamel is usually gray and translucent in nature.
                                                 Color of tooth mainly depends upon three factors: (a) color
                                                 of underlying dentin, (b) thickness of enamel, (c) amount
                                                 of stains in enamel. The translucency of enamel is directly
                                                 related to degree of mineralization and homogenicity.
                                                 Anomalies occurring during developmental and minerali-
                                                 zation stage, antibiotic usage and excess fluoride intake affect
                                                 the color of tooth.

                                                                 Color of enamel is affected by
                                                  •    Color of underlying dentin
                                                  •    Thickness of enamel
                                                  •    Amount of stains in enamel
                                                  •    Anomalies occurring during developmental and mine-            Fig. 3.3: Diagram showing different structures present in enamel
                                                       ralization stage like antibiotic usage and excess fluoride
                                                       intake affects the color.
                                                                                                                    other group of rods, finally taking a twisted and irregular
                                                 Strength                                                           path towards the tooth surface.

                                                 of enamel is 2.8. Hardness of enamel is different in different
                                                 areas of the external surface of a tooth. The hardness also        Bands of Hunter-Schreger

                                                 surface. Also the density of enamel increases from dentino-
                                                                                                                    of light reflection (optical phenomenon) due to changes in
                                                 enamel junction to the outer surface. When compared, dentin

Enamel Spindles
                                                                     cusps of teeth of opposite arch occlude during masti-
Odontoblastic processes sometimes crosses DEJ and their              cation.
end is thickened. Spindles serve as pain receptors, that is
why, when we cut in the enamel patient complains of pain.

Striae of Retzius
They appear as brownish bands in the ground sections and
illustrate the incremental pattern of enamel. These represent
the rest periods of ameloblast during enamel formation,
therefore also called as growth circles. When these circles
are incomplete at the enamel surface, it results in alternating
grooves called imbrications lines of pickerills, the elevations
in between called perikymata. Perikymata are shallow
furrows where the striae of Retzius end. These are conti-            Fig. 3.4: Showing pits and fissures of premolars and molars
nuous around the tooth and parallel the CEJ.
    Striae of Retzius are stripes that appear on enamel when
viewed microscopically in cross-section. Formed from
changes in diameter of “Tomes” processes, these stripes
demonstrate the growth of enamel, similar to the annual
rings on a tree.

Prismless Layer
There is structureless layer of enamel near the cervical line
and to a lesser extent on the cusp tip which is more minera-
lized.

Dentinoenamel Junction
Dentinoenamel junction is pitted/scalloped in which crests                 Fig. 3.5: Deep pits and fissures making areas
are toward enamel and shallow depressions are in dentin.                            favorable for food impaction

                                                                                                                       Composition
                                                                                                                       Dentin contains 70% inorganic hydroxyapatite crystals and
                                                                                                                       the rest is organic substance and water making it more
                                                                                                                       resilient than enamel.
                                                                                                                           The organic components consist primarily of collagen
                                                                                                                       type 1.

                                                                     Dentinal Tubules (Table 3.1)
                                                                     The dentinal tubules follow a gentle “S”-shaped curve in
Color                                                                the tooth crown and are straighter in the incisal edges, cusps
The color of dentin is slightly darker than enamel and is            and root areas. The ends of the tubules are perpendicular to
generally light yellowish in young individuals while it              dentinoenamel and dentinocemental junctions (Fig. 3.8). The
becomes darker with age. On constant exposure to oral                dentinal tubules have lateral branches throughout the dentin,
fluids and other irritants, the color becomes light brown or         which are termed as canaliculi or microtubules. Each dentinal
black (Fig. 3.7).                                                    tubule is lined with a layer of peritubular dentin, which is
                                                                     much more mineralized than the surrounding intertubular
Thickness                                                            dentin. Number of dentinal tubules increase from 15,000-
Dentin thickness is usually more on the cuspal heights and
incisal edges and less in the cervical areas of tooth. It is
around 3-3.5 mm on the coronal surface. With advancing
age and various irritants, the thickness of secondary and
tertiary dentin increases.

Hardness
The hardness of dentin is one-fifth that of enamel. Hardness
is not the same in all its thickness. Its hardness at the DEJ
is 3 times more than that near the pulp so it is important to
keep the depth of preparation near the DEJ. Hardness of
dentin also increases with advancing age due to minerali-
zation. Compressive hardness is about 266 MPa. The
modulus of elasticity is about 1.67 × 106 Psi. As the modulus
of elasticity of dentin is low, so it indicates dentin is flexible
in nature. The flexibility of dentin provides support or
cushion to the brittle enamel. The tensile strength of dentin              Fig. 3.8: Diagram showing course of dentinal tubules
is 40-60 MPa. It is approximately one-half of that of enamel.

 •   Hardness increases with age.                                    Numbers         45,000-65,000/mm2 15,000-20,000/mm2

Difference between Enamel and Dentin




                                                                                                                                   Structure of Teeth
                   Enamel                                                       Dentin
Color              Whitish blue or white gray                                   Yellowish white or slightly darker than enamel
Sound              Sharp, high pitched sound on moving fine explorer tip        Dull or low pitched sound on moving fine
                                                                                explorer tip
Hardness           Hardest structure of the tooth                               Softer than enamel
Reflectance        More shiny surface and reflective to light than dentin       Dull and reflects less light than enamel


Difference between Primary, Secondary and Reparative/Tertiary Dentin

                            Primary                       Secondary                                Tertiary
1. Definition               Dentin formed before root     Formed after root completion       Formed as a response to any
                            completion                                                       external stimuli such as dental
                                                                                             caries, attrition and trauma
2. Type of cells            Usually formed by primary Formed by primary odontoblasts         Secondary odontoblasts or
                            odontoblasts                                                     undifferentiated mesenchymal
                                                                                             cells of pulps
3. Location                 Found in all areas of dentin It is not uniform, mainly present   Localized to only area of
                                                         over roof and floor of pulp chamber external stimulus
4. Orientation of tubules   Regular                      Irregular                           Atubular
5. Rate of formation        Rapid                        Slow                                Rapid between 1.5 µm to
                                                                                             3.5 µm/day depending on the
                                                                                             stimuli
6. Permeability             More                         Less                                Least


                      Functions of dentin
 1.   Provide strength to the tooth
 2.   Offers protection of pulp
 3.   Provides flexibility to the tooth
 4.   Affects the color of enamel
 5.   Defensive in action (initiating pulpal defence mecha-
      nism).

Clinical Considerations of Dentin
1. As dentin is known to provide strength and rigidity to
   the tooth, care should be taken during tooth preparation.
2. Tooth preparations should be done under constant air
   water spray to avoid build up of heat formation which,
   in further, damages dental pulp.
3. Dentinal tubules are composed of odontoblastic
                                                                            Fig. 3.9: Diagram showing fluid movement in dentinal
   processes and dentinal fluid. The dehydration of dentin                        tubules resulting in dentin hypersensitivity
   by air blasts causes outward fluid movement and
   stimulates the mechanoreceptor of the odontoblast,
   resulting in dentinal sensitivity (Fig. 3.9).                      removed or modified. This can be done by etching or
4. Dentin should always be protected by liners, bases or              conditioning.
   dentin bonding agents.                                          6. Etching of dentin causes removal of smear layer and
5. When tooth is cut, considerable quantities of cutting              etching of intertubular and peritubular dentin for
   debris made up of small particles of mineralized collagen          micromechanical bonding.
   matrix are formed. This forms a layer on enamel of              7. Restoration should be well adapted to the preparation
   dentin called smear layer for bonding of restorative               walls so as to prevent microleakage and thus damage to
   materials to tooth structure, this smear layer has to be           underlying dentin/pulp.

                                                 DENTAL PULP                                                         Odontoblastic Layer
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 The dental pulp is soft tissue of mesenchymal origin located        Odontoblasts consist of cell bodies and their cytoplasmic
                                                 in the center of the tooth. It consists of specialized cells,       processes. The odontoblastic cell bodies form the odonto-
                                                 odontoblasts arranged peripherally in direct contact with           blastic zone whereas the odontoblastic processes are located
                                                 dentin matrix. This close relationship between odontoblasts         within predentin matrix. Capillaries, nerve fibers and dendritic
                                                 and dentin is known as “Pulp – dentin complex”. The pulp            cells may be found around the odontoblasts in this zone.
                                                 is connective tissue system composed of cells, ground
                                                 substances, fibers, interstitial fluid, odontoblasts, fibroblasts   Cell Free Zone of Weil
                                                 and other cellular components. Pulp is actually a                   Central to odontoblasts is subodontoblastic layer, termed as
                                                 microcirculatory system consists of arterioles and venules          cell free zone of Weil. It contains plexuses of capillaries and
                                                 as the largest vascular component. Due to lack of true              fibers ramification of small nerve.
                                                 collateral circulation, pulp is dependent upon few arterioles
                                                 entering through the foramen. Due to presence of the                Cell Rich Zone
                                                 specialized cells, i.e. odontoblasts as well as other cells which
                                                 can differentiate into hard tissue secreting cells. The pulp        This zone lies next to subodontoblastic layer. It contains
                                                 retains its ability to form dentin throughout the life. This        fibroblasts, undifferentiated cells which maintain number
                                                 enables the vital pulp to partially compensate for loss of          of odontoblasts by proliferation and differentiation.
                                                 enamel or dentin occurring with age.                                                       Contents of pulp

                                                                                                                     1. Odontoblasts: They are first type of cells encountered
                                                                                                                        as pulp is approached from dentin. The number of
                                                                                                                        odontoblasts has been found in the range of 59,000 to
                                                                                                                        76,000 per square millimeter in coronal dentin with a
                                                                                                                        lesser number in root dentin. In the crown of the fully
                                                                                                                        developed tooth, the cell bodies of odontoblasts are

                                                       which are involved in the elimination of dead cells,
                                                       debris, bacteria and foreign bodies, etc.
                                                    b. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes: Most common form
                                                       of leukocyte is neutrophil, though it is not present in
                                                       healthy pulp. They are major cell type in micro-
                                                       abscesses formation and are effective at destroying
                                                       and phagocytizing bacteria and dead cells.
                                                    c. Lymphocytes: In normal pulps, mainly T-lympho-
                                                       cytes are found. They are associated with injury and
                                                       resultant immune response.

                                                       cells release histamine which causes vasodilatation,
                                                       increased vessel permeability and thus allowing fluids              Fig. 3.14: Diagrammatic representation of pulp cavity

                                                 Extracellular Components                                           It is that portion of pulp preparation which extends from
