                                                 substance of pulp:                                                 varies with size, shape, number of the roots in different
                                                                                                                    teeth.
                                                 Fibers                                                                  The apical foramen is an aperture at or near the apex of
                                                                                                                    a root through which nerves and blood vessels of the pulp
                                                 The fibers are principally type I and type III collagen.
                                                                                                                    enter or leave the pulp cavity.
                                                 Collagen is synthesized and secreted by odontoblasts and
                                                 fibroblasts.
                                                                                                                    Functions of Pulp
                                                 Ground Substance                                                   The pulp lives for dentin and the dentin lives by the grace of
                                                                                                                    the pulp.
                                                 It is a structureless mass with gel like consistency forming
                                                 bulk of pulp.                                                      Pulp performs four basic functions, i.e.:
                                                 Components of ground substance are:                                1. Formation of dentin
                                                 1. Glycosaminoglycans                                              2. Nutrition of dentin
                                                 2. Glycoproteins                                                   3. Innervation of tooth
                                                 3. Water.                                                          4. Defense of tooth.
                                                 Functions of ground substance:

                                                 1. Forms the bulk of the pulp.

                                                    to the vasculature.                                             later deposits dentin. Pulp primarily helps in:

                                                 form of tooth. This space is called pulp cavity which is           • Creates an environment favorable for matrix minera-

                                                                                                                                      47
Innervation of Tooth




                                                                                                                                      Structure of Teeth
Through the nervous system, pulp transmits sensations
mediated through enamel or dentin to the higher nerve
centers. Pulp transmits pain, also senses temperature and
touch.

Defense of Tooth
Odontoblasts form dentin in response to injury particularly
when original dentin thickness has been compromised as in
caries, attrition, trauma or restorative procedure.

Age Changes in Pulp
Pulp like other connective tissues, undergoes changes with
time. Pulp can show changes in appearance (morphogenic)
                                                                         Fig. 3.16: Diagrammatic representation of pulp stones
and in function (physiologic).

Morphologic Changes                                                PERIRADICULAR TISSUE
•   Continued deposition of intratubular dentin- reduction         Periradicular tissue consists of cementum, periodontal
    in tubule diameter.                                            ligament and alveolar bone (Fig. 3.17).
•   Reduction in pulp volume due to increase in secondary
    dentin deposition (Fig. 3.15).                                 Cementum
•   Presence of dystrophic calcification and pulp stones
                                                                   Cementum can be defined as hard, avascular connective
    (Fig. 3.16).
                                                                   tissue that covers the roots of the teeth. It is light yellow in
•   Decrease in sensitivity.
                                                                   color and can be differentiated from enamel by its lack of
•   Reduction in number of blood vessels.
                                                                   luster and darker hue. It is very permeable to dyes and
Physiologic Changes                                                chemical agents, from the pulp canal and the external root
                                                                   surface.
•   Decrease in dentin permeability provides protected
    environment for pulp-reduced effect of irritants.
•   Possibility of reduced ability of pulp to react to irritants
    and repair itself.

     48
                                                     Cementum consists of approximately 45 to 50%
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 inorganic matter and 50 to 55% organic matter and water
                                                 by weight. It is softer than dentin. Sharpey’s fibers, which
                                                 are embedded in cementum and bone, are the principal
                                                 collagenous fibers of periodontal ligament.

                                                                        Composition
                                                  •   Inorganic content—45-50% (by wt.)
                                                  •   Organic matter—50-55% (by wt.)
                                                  •   Water

                                                                 THEORIES OF DENTAL CARIES




                                                                                                                                 Dental Caries
                                                                 As we know, dental caries is a multifactorial disease of
                                                                 tooth which has been explained by many theories. Though
                                                                 there is no universally accepted theory of the etiology of
                                                                 dental caries, but following three theories are considered in
                                                                 etiology of dental caries:
                                                                 1. Acidogenic theory
                                                                 2. Proteolytic theory
                                                                 3. Proteolysis-chelation theory.

                                                                 Acidogenic Theory
                                                                 •   WD Miller was the first known investigator of dental
                                                                     caries. He published his results in 1882.
                                                                 •   This theory is most accepted.
                                                                 •   Miller said “Dental decay is a chemico-parasitic process
             Fig. 4.2: Pathogenesis of dental caries                 consisting of two stages, the decalcification of enamel,
                                                                     which results in its total destruction, as a preliminary
•   Acidogenic nature: This means bacterias should be able           stage; followed by dissolution of the softened residue
    to transport sugars and convert them to acid.                    of the enamel and dentin.
•   Aciduric nature: Bacterias should be able to thrive at       •   In the first stage there is destruction which is done by
    low pH.                                                          the acid attack where as the dissolution of the residue
    – Bacterias should be able to produce extracellular and          (2nd stage) is carried out by the proteolytic action of
                                                                     the bacterias.
        intracellular polysaccharides which contribute to the
                                                                 •   This whole process is supported by the presence of
        plaque matrix. These intracellular polysaccharides
                                                                     carbohydrates, microorganisms and dental plaque.
        can be used for energy production and converted to
                                                                 •   All the preventive steps have been based on this theory.
        acid when sugars are not available (Fig. 4.2).

    flora are actively involved in the disease. Preventive
    measures against these bacteria can control occurrence       Proteolytic Theory
    of the disease.

•   The non-specific plaque hypothesis believes that the

    total plaque microflora. Accordingly all plaque should

                                                 “Caries Balance Concept”                                             The difference in occurrence of dental caries in different
                                                 (Proposed by Featherstone) (Fig. 4.3)                            individuals of same age, sex, race and geographic area, diet,
                                                                                                                  and similar living conditions is because of various factors
                                                 According to the caries balance theory, caries does not result   that manipulate the etiology of caries.

•   Lack of enamel maturation or the presence of develop-
    mental defects in enamel may result in increase the caries    Diet (Fig. 4.5)
    risk. These defects increase plaque retention, increase
    bacterial colonization, and in some cases, the loss of        •     Physical nature of diet: In the earlier times, the primitive
    enamel make it more susceptible to tooth demineraliza-              man used to eat rough and raw unrefined foods which
    tion.                                                               had self-cleansing capacity. But in present times, soft
•   The physical characteristics of teeth like deep and
    narrow occlusal fissures, deep buccal or lingual pits
    and enamel hypoplasia, etc. affect the initiation of dental
    caries.
•   Fluoride content is lesser in carious enamel and dentin
    as compared to a sound tooth. In carious enamel and
    dentin it is 139 ppm and 223 ppm, whereas in sound
    enamel and dentin it is 410 ppm and 873 ppm,
    respectively.
•   If a tooth is out of position, rotated or in any abnormal
    position, it becomes difficult to clean, and hence retains
    more food and debris.

•   Saliva contains salivary proteins which get deposited
    onto the tooth surface which help the enamel against
    acid dissolution. This protective layer is referred to as                  Fig. 4.5: Physical nature of diet affects the
    the pellicle.                                                                       incidence of dental caries

                                                     teeth and are not removed easily due to lack of roughage.          It can be prevented by restricting the intake of dietary

                                                     nowadays than the past.                                            Tooth remineralization can take place if the pH of the

                                                 •   It is seen that acids produced by fermentable carbo-            • Presence of inorganic ions in saliva
                                                     hydrates cause a rapid drop in plaque pH to a level which       • Quick washing of retained food.
                                                     results in demineralization of the tooth structure. But         •   Frequency of carbohydrate intake: In a person with
                                                     since acids produced in plaque diffuse out of the plaque            normal salivary function, after intake of fermentable

                                                     bacteria. The gradual return of the pH occurs because                          vitamin D deficiency. It can result in early
                                                     of buffers present in plaque and saliva. This drop in pH                       attack of caries. It has been seen that
                                                     can demineralize tooth structure depending on the                              supplement of vitamin D in children helps in
                                                     absolute pH decrease, as well as the length of time that                       the formation of healthy teeth and thus helps
                                                     the pH is below the “critical pH” level. The critical pH                       in reduction in the dental caries.
                                                     value for demineralization usually ranges between 5.2           Vitamin K: Deficiency does not affect the dental caries
                                                     to 5.5. Caries occurs when the process of reminerali-                          incidence.
                                                     zation is slower than the process of demineralization           Vitamin B Its deficiency may exert a caries protective
                                                                                                                     complex:       influence on the tooth. Several types of
                                                                                                                                    vitamin B are important growth factors for
                                                                                                                                    the oral acidogenic flora which serve as
                                                                                                                                    component of the co-enzymes involved in
                                                                                                                                    glycolysis. Vitamin B6 acts as an anticaries
                                                                                                                                    agent because it promotes the growth of non-
                                                                                                                                    cariogenic organisms.
                                                                                                                     Vitamin C: Directly vitamin C does not help in protection
                                                                                                                                    of tooth against dental caries, but it is required
                                                                                                                                    for the normal health of the gingiva.

                                                                                                                     The Bacteria
                                                                                                                     •   Dental caries do not occur if the oral cavity is free of
                                                                                                                         bacteria.
                                                                                                                     •   Most commonly seen bacterias associated with caries
                                                 Fig. 4.6: Stephan curve graph showing plaque pH before and after
                                                 glucose rinse. (a) pH decreases because of acids produced by            are Streptococcus mutans, Lactobacillus spp., Veillonella
                                                 bacteria, (b) pH increases, due to buffering of plaque and saliva       spp. and Actinomyces spp.
                                                                                                                                   57
•   Streptococci mutans are considered main causative




                                                                                                                                   Dental Caries
    factors for caries because of their ability to adhere to
    tooth surfaces, produce abundant amounts of acid, and
    survive and continue metabolism at low pH conditions.
    Colonization with Streptococcus mutans at an early age
    is an important factor for early caries initiation.

Time Period
The time period during which all above three direct factors,
i.e. tooth, microorganisms and substrate are acting jointly
should be adequate to produce acidic pH which is critical
for dissolution of enamel to produce a carious lesion. Time
required for acid production from the fermentation of the
carbohydrates by bacteria and for demineralization of tooth,                    Fig. 4.8: Smooth surface caries
is allowed by poor oral hygiene and not cleaning teeth
immediately after eating.

CLASSIFICATION OF DENTAL CARIES
Carious lesions can be classified in different ways.

According to their Anatomical Site
•   Pit and fissure caries (Fig. 4.7): Pit and fissure caries
    occur on occlusal surface of posterior teeth and buccal
    and lingual surfaces of molars and on lingual surface of
    maxillary incisors.
•   Smooth surface caries (Fig. 4.8): Smooth surface caries
    occurs on gingival third of buccal and lingual surfaces
    and on proximal surfaces.                                                         Fig. 4.9: Root caries
•   Root caries (Fig. 4.9): When the lesion starts at the
    exposed root cementum and dentin, it is termed as root      According to Whether it is a New
    caries.                                                     Lesion or Recurrent Carious Lesion
                                                                •   Primary caries denotes lesions on unrestored surfaces
                                                                    (Fig. 4.10).
                                                                •   Recurrent caries (Fig. 4.11): Lesions developing adjacent
                                                                    to fillings are referred to as either recurrent or secondary
                                                                    caries.




                 Fig. 4.7: Pit and fissure caries                                   Fig. 4.10: Primary caries
     58
                                                                                                                        It occurs usually due to poor oral hygiene and taking
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                        frequent cariogenic snacks and sweet drinks between
                                                                                                                        meals. It is also seen in mouths where there is hypo-
                                                                                                                        salivation.
                                                                                                                        Rampant caries is of following three types:
                                                                                                                        – Early childhood caries is a term used to describe
                                                                                                                            dental caries present in the primary dentition of young
                                                                                                                            children.
                                                                                                                        – Bottle caries or nursing caries are names used to
                                                                                                                            describe a particular form of rampant caries in the
                                                                                                                            primary dentition of infants and young children. The
                                                                                                                            clinical pattern is characteristic, with the four
                                                                                                                            maxillary deciduous incisors most severely affected.
                                                          Fig. 4.11: Radiograph showing recurrent caries
                                                                  adjacent to proximal restoration
                                                                                                                        – Xerostomia induced rampant caries (radiation
                                                                                                                            rampant caries) are commonly observed that after
                                                                                                                            radiotherapy of malignant areas of or near the
                                                 •   Residual caries is demineralized tissue left in place before
                                                                                                                            salivary glands. Because of radiotherapy salivary flow
                                                     a filling is placed (Fig. 4.12).
                                                                                                                            is very much reduced. This results in rampant caries
                                                 According to the Activity of Carious Lesion                                even in those teeth which were free from caries
                                                                                                                            before radiotherapy.
                                                 •   Active carious lesion: A progressive lesion is described       •   Chronic dental caries: Chronic caries travel very slowly
                                                     as an active carious lesion.                                       towards the pulp. They appear dark in color and hard in
                                                 •   Inactive/arrested carious lesion: A lesion that may have           consistency.
                                                     formed earlier and then stopped is referred to as an
                                                     arrested or inactive carious lesion. Arrested carious lesion   Based on Treatment and Restoration Design
                                                     is characterized by a large open cavity which no longer
                                                     retains food and becomes self-cleansing.                       •   Class I: Pit and fissure caries occur in the occlusal
                                                                                                                        surfaces of premolars and molars, the occlusal two-
                                                 According to Speed of Caries Progression                               third of buccal and lingual surface of molars, lingual
                                                                                                                        surface of incisors.
                                                 •   Acute dental caries: Acute caries travels towards the
                                                                                                                    •   Class II: Caries in the proximal surface of premolars
                                                     pulp at a very fast speed.
                                                                                                                        and molars.
                                                 •   Rampant caries: It is the name given to multiple active
                                                                                                                    •   Class III: Caries in the proximal surface of anterior
                                                     carious lesions occurring in the same patient, frequently
                                                                                                                        (incisors and canine) teeth and not involving the incisal
                                                     involving surfaces of teeth that are usually caries free.
                                                                                                                        angles.
                                                                                                                    •   Class IV: Caries in the proximal surface of anterior teeth
                                                                                                                        also involving the incisal angle.
                                                                                                                    •   Class V: Caries on gingival third of facial and lingual or
                                                                                                                        palatal surfaces of all teeth.
                                                                                                                    •   Class VI: Caries on incisal edges of anterior and cusp
                                                                                                                        tips of posterior teeth without involving any other
                                                                                                                        surface.

                                                                                                                    Based on Pathway of Caries Spread
                                                                                                                    (Figs 4.13A and B)
                                                                                                                    Forward Caries
                                                                                                                    When the caries cone in enamel is larger or of same size as
                                                                    Fig. 4.12: Residual caries                      present in dentin, it is called as forward caries.
                                                                                                                            59




                                                                                                                            Dental Caries
                                    Figs 4.13A and B: A. Forward caries, B. Backward caries



Backward Caries
When spread of caries along dentinoenamel junction exceeds
the adjacent caries in enamel, it is called backward caries
(here caries extend from DEJ to enamel).

Based on Number of Tooth Surfaces Involved
Simple caries: Caries involving only one tooth surface is
termed as simple caries (Fig. 4.14).
Compound caries (Fig. 4.15): If two surfaces are involved
it is termed as compound caries.
Complex caries (Fig. 4.16): If more than two surfaces are                          Fig. 4.15: Compound caries
involved it is called as complex caries.
                                                                 Moderate caries (Fig. 4.18): Involves more than half the
Classification According to the Severity                         thickness of enamel, but does not involve dentinoenamel
                                                                 junction.
Incipient caries (Fig. 4.17): Involves less than half the
thickness of enamel.                                             Advanced caries (Fig. 4.19): Involves the dentinoenamel
                                                                 junction and less than half distance to pulp cavity.




                   Fig. 4.14: Simple caries                                         Fig. 4.16: Complex caries
     60
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                  Fig. 4.17: Incipient caries                      Fig. 4.20: Severe caries


                                                                                Severe caries (Fig. 4.20): Involves more than half distance
                                                                                to pulp cavity.

                                                                                Graham Mount’s Classification
                                                                                This classification system is based on two simple parameters:
                                                                                a. Location of carious lesion
                                                                                b. Size of carious lesion
                                                                                    Here, the system is designed to recognize carious lesions
                                                                                beginning at the earliest stage, in which remineralization is
                                                                                the indicated.

                                                                                Cavity site      Size 1    Size 2     Size 3      Size 4
                                                                                               (Minimal) (Moderate) (Enlarged) (Extensive)

                                                                                Site 3            3.1         3.2         3.3         3.4

                                                                                HISTOPATHOLOGY OF DENTAL CARIES

                                                                                Caries of Enamel (Fig. 4.21)
                                                                                Caries of enamel initiates by deposition of dental plaque on
                                                                                tooth surface. We will discus the carious process of the
                                                                                enamel according to its location on tooth surface, i.e. smooth
                                                                                surface caries, and pit and fissure caries.

                                                                                Smooth Surface Caries
                                                                                •   Smooth surface caries occurs on gingival third of buccal
                                                                                    and lingual surfaces and on proximal surfaces below
                                                 Fig. 4.19: Advanced caries         the contact point (Fig. 4.22).

                                                                         black in color and with a fine explorer, a “catch” is felt.
                                                                         Enamel at the margins of these the pits and fissures
                                                                         appears opaque bluish-white.
                                                                     •   Caries begin beneath plaque resulting in decalcification
                                                                         of enamel.
                                                                     •   Enamel in the bottom of pit or fissure is very thin, so
                                                                         early dentin involvement frequently occurs.
                                                                     •   Here the caries follows the direction of the enamel rods.

                                                                                                                 Early Dentinal Changes
                                                                                                                 •   Initial penetration of the dentin by caries causes an
                                                                                                                     alteration in dentin, known as dentinal sclerosis.
                                                                                                                 •   In this reaction there occurs the calcification of dentinal
                                                                                                                     tubules which seals off from further penetration by
                                                                                                                     microorganisms.
                                                                                                                 •   More prominent in slow chronic caries.
                                                                                                                 •   When dentinal tubules are completely occluded by the
                                                                                                                     mineral precipitate, section of the tooth gives a transpa-
                                                               Fig. 4.23: Zones in caries of enamel                  rent appearance in transmitted light, this dentin is termed

                                                                  valuable because an increased prevalence of difficult to

caries. These zones begin from the pulpal side (Fig. 4.24).

   as it does in a healthy area, generating a shadow




                                                                                                                                 Dental Caries
   corresponding to decay.
   Advantages:
   • Noninvasive method
   • Useful in patients with posterior crowding
   • No radiation hazards
   • Comfortable to patients
   Disadvantages:
   • Not possible in all anatomic locations
   • Considerable intra- and inter-observer variation
4. Digital imaging fiberoptic transillumination (DIFOTI):                   Fig. 4.26: Normal radiographic landmarks

   The light from the DIFOTI probe is positioned on the
   tooth to be assessed, then the tooth is illuminated and

   algorithms. The illumination and imaging conditions are      Caries of Various Surfaces

   • Noninvasive                                                advanced in the dentin and where it has created a greater

   • Not able to measure the depth of the carious lesions       may not be evident radiographically until approximately 30-
   • Cannot differentiate dental caries and stained deep        40% demineralization has occurred (Fig. 4.28).
       fissures.                                                    The shape of early radiolucent lesion in the enamel is a
                                                                triangle with its broad base at the tooth surface. Once the
Radiographic Method of Diagnosis                                lesion crosses the DEJ and invades into the dentin, it appears
                                                                as another triangle with base at DEJ and apex towards the
Radiographs play an important role in diagnosis of the dental
                                                                pulp chamber. Collectively, these may appear as two triangles
diseases.
                                                                with their bases facing towards the external surface.
    The interpretation of radiographs should be done in a
systematic manner. The clinician should be familiar with
normal radiographic landmarks.

        Normal radiographic landmarks (Fig. 4.26)
 •   Enamel: It is the most radiopaque structure.
 •   Dentin: Slightly darker than enamel.
 •   Cementum: Similar to dentin in appearance.
 •   Periodontal ligament: Appears as a narrow radiolucent
     line around the root surface.
 •   Lamina dura: It is a radiopaque line representing the
     tooth socket.
 •   Pulp cavity: Pulp chamber and canals are seen as
     radiolucent lines within the tooth.

   It is important to understand the radiographic
appearance of carious lesions at various areas of the tooth              Fig. 4.27: Radiograph showing occlusal caries
     66
                                                                                                                CARIES RISK ASSESSMENT
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                The main objective of caries risk assessment in dentistry is
                                                                                                                to deliver preventive and restorative care specific to an
                                                                                                                individual patient. Various caries risk indicators are
                                                                                                                sociodemographic factors, such as education and income
                                                                                                                of parents, systemic and topical fluoride exposure,
                                                                                                                toothbrushing behavior, bottle use and dietary habits (Fig.
                                                                                                                4.30).
                                                                                                                    In 1960s, Keyes has showed that there are three
                                                                                                                prerequisite factors for the development of dental caries,
                                                                                                                known as Keyes’s triad (Fig. 4.30). These factors are
                                                                                                                plaque, tooth and the diet. Later on many studies were
                                                                                                                conducted which extended Keyes model with many other
                                                      Fig. 4.28: Radiograph showing proximal caries of molar
                                                                                                                factors affecting the interplay between these primary
                                                                                                                factors.
                                                      Bitewing radiographs are preferably utilized to detect
                                                 interproximal caries. Recurrent caries at cervical margins          A patient is said to be at high caries risk if there is:
                                                 is best observed in bitewing films, since the central ray is    •    One new lesion on smooth surface during past one
                                                 directed along the plane of the cervical areas.                      year
                                                                                                                 •    New carious lesion on root surface
                                                 Caries of buccal and lingual surfaces: More than one            •    Patient on medication which causes hyposalivation
                                                 radiographs are needed to diagnose because the buccal or        •    Systemic disorder
                                                 lingual lesion may be superim-posed on the DEJ and suggest      •    Past dental history with multiple restorations
                                                 occlusal caries.                                                •    Exposure to sugary snacks for more than three times
                                                                                                                      a day
                                                 Root surface caries: Should be detected clinically as
                                                                                                                 •    Senility.
                                                 radiographs are not needed for diagnosis.

                                                 Methods to Improve Oral Hygiene (Fig. 4.32)                      •   Other mechanical devices.
                                                 Measures for preventing dental caries include the following:
                                                 • Dental prophylaxis
                                                 • Toothbrushing
                                                 • Interdental cleaning.
                                                 Dental prophylaxis: In dental prophylaxis, polishing of
                                                 roughened tooth surfaces and replacement of faulty
                                                 restorations is done so as to decrease the formation of dental
                                                 plaque, therefore, resulting in less incidence of caries.
                                                 Toothbrushing: Toothbrushing is considered to be the most
                                                 reliable means of controlling plaque and provide clean tooth
                                                 surface.
                                                     Many toothbrushing techniques have been described and
                                                 being promoted as being effective. Bass technique is most
                                                 recommended as it emphasizes sulcular placement of bristles
                                                 while in periodontal cases, sulcular technique with vibratory
                                                 motion is preferred (Figs 4.33A to C).
                                                 Interdental cleaning aids (Fig. 4.34): Interdental cleaning
                                                 devices can be (Figs 4.35A to C):
                                                 • Dental floss and tape: Used in persons with normal
                                                    proximal contact between their teeth.                                         Fig. 4.34: Interdental cleaning aids

                                                                                                                       of fluoride to decrease the possibility of dental fluorosis

Rationale of Caries Vaccine
                                                                  Ans. – Deep pits and fissures
1. Rationale for caries vaccine is that immunization with              – Gingival recession cases
   S. mutans should induce an immune response so as to                 – Below contact area.
   prevent organisms from colonizing the tooth surface

   and thus prevent carious decay.
2. General public should be well exposed to vaccine.              Q.   What are pit and fissure caries?

   teeth so as to achieve maximum benefits.                       Q.   What are acute and chronic caries?

                                                                balancing, (B) Working end is away from long axis of handle, this is
                                                                not balanced
Shank
Shank connects the handle to the blade. It tapers from the
handle down to the blade and is normally smooth, round or
tapered. The shank may be straight or angled.                   Blade or Nib
    Based on number of shank angles (Figs 5.3A to D),           The blade is the last section. It is the working part of the
instruments can be classified as:                               instrument. It is connected to the handle by the shank. For
1. Straight: Shank having no angle.                             non-cutting instruments, the working part is termed the nib
2. Monoangle: Shank having one angle.                           and is used to place, adapt and condense the materials in
3. Biangle: Shank having two angles.                            the prepared tooth. Depending on the materials being used,
4. Triple angle: Shank having three angles.                     the surface of the nib may be plain or serrated. To cleave
    The angulation of instrument is provided for access and     and smoothen the enamel and dentin, the working point of
stability. Closer the working point to the long axis of the     the instrument is beveled to create the cutting edge. If
handle, better will be the control on it. For better control,   instrument has blade on both the ends of the handle, it is
the working point should be preferably within 3 mm of the       known as “double-ended” instrument. In such cases, one
center of the long axis of the handle (Figs 5.4A and B).        end is for the left side and other for the right.
      76
                                                     In some instruments, there are three bevels. Two are on
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 the side and one is at the end. The edge on the end is called
                                                 the primary cutting edge and the edges on the sides are
                                                 called the secondary cutting edges.

                                                 Instrument Formula

                                                 GV Black established an instrument formula for describing
                                                 dimensions of blade, nib or head of instrument and angles
                                                 present in shank of the instrument (Fig. 5.5). The formula
                                                 is usually printed on the handle consisting of a code of
                                                 three or four numbers separated by spaces.
                                                     The first number of the formula indicates width of the
                                                 blade or primary cutting edge in tenths of a millimeter
                                                 (Fig. 5.6).
                                                     The second number represents the angle formed by the
                                                 primary cutting edge and long axis of the instrument handle
                                                 in clockwise centigrade. The instrument is positioned in
                                                 such a way that the number always exceeds 50 and is
                                                 measured in clockwise centigrades. If the cutting edge is at
                                                 right angle to the length of the blade, then this number is
                                                                                                                                   Fig. 5.5: Instrument formula
                                                 omitted.
                                                     The third number (second number in three number code)
                                                 represents the length of the blade in millimeters, that is,
                                                 from the shank to the cutting edge (Fig. 5.7).
                                                     The fourth number (third number in three number code)
                                                 represents the angle which the blade forms with the long
                                                 axis of the handle or the plane of the instrument in clockwise
                                                 centigrade. To calculate the measurement of the angle, place
                                                 the instrument on the center of the circle and move it until
                                                 the blade lines up with one line on the ruler. This measure-
                                                 ment represents the angulation of the blade from the long
                                                 axis of the handle. To keep balance during working, tip of
                                                 blade is brought in the line of the long axis of the handle.
                                                 Example:
                                                 1. An instrument having instrument formula of 15-8-14
                                                    indicates following:
                                                                                                                             Fig. 5.6: First digit of formula indicates
                                                    • 15 represents the width of the blade in tenths of a                    width of blade in 1/10th of a millimeter
                                                        millimeter, i.e. 1.5 mm.
                                                    • 8 represents the length of the blade in millimeters,
                                                        i.e. 8 mm.
                                                    • 14 represents the blade angle in centigrades.
                                                 2. Instrument with formula 15-95-8-12 represents the
                                                    following:
                                                    • 15 represents width of the blade in tenths of a
                                                        millimeter, i.e. 1.5 mm.
                                                    • 95 represents the cutting edge angle in centigrades.
                                                    • 8 represents length of the blade, i.e. 8 mm.
                                                    • 12 represents blade angle in centigrades.                   Fig. 5.7: Third number indicates length of blade in millimeters
                                                                                                                                      77
                                                                     Instrument Motions




                                                                                                                                      Cutting Instruments
                                                                     Pulling: Here, instrument is moved towards operator’s
                                                                     hand.
                                                                     Scraping: Here, instrument is move side-to-side or back
                                                                     and forth on the tooth surface.
                                                                     Pushing: Here, instruments is moved away from operator’s
                                                                     hand.
                                                                     Cutting: Here, instrument is used parallel to the long axis
                                                                     of handle.

                                                                     EXPLORING INSTRUMENTS

                                                                     Mouth Mirrors
        Figs 5.8A and B: Different bevels of an instrument
   (A) Straight chisel with single bevel, (B) Bibeveled instrument   Mouth mirrors are used as supplement to improve access
                                                                     to instrumentation (Figs 5.9A to D).
Bevels in Cutting Instruments
                                                                     Types of Mirror Faces
Single Bevel Instruments
                                                                     1. a. Front surface reflecting mirror
Most of the instruments have single bevel that forms the
primary cutting edge. These are called single beveled                   b. Rear surface reflecting mirror
instruments. These can be right or left bevel and mesial or          2. a. Plane or flat surface
distal bevel instruments (Figs 5.8A and B).                             b. Concave surface: Reflecting surface on the front of
                                                                           lens and produce a clear image. It is mirror of choice
Right and left bevel instruments: Single-beveled direct              3. a. One sided—image on one side
cutting instruments such as enamel hatchets are made in
                                                                        b. Two sided—image on either side (Advantage—
pairs having bevels on opposite sides of the blade. These
                                                                           retraction with indirect vision simultaneously).
are named as right and left bevel instruments. During use,
move the instrument from right to left in right beveled
instrument and from left to right in left bevel instrument.
Identification of bevel: Hold the instrument in such a way
that the primary cutting edge faces downwards and pointing
away from operator. If bevel is on the right side of the
blade, the instrument is right sided and if bevel is on the left
side of the blade the instrument is left sided.
Mesial and distal bevel instrument: If we observe the inside
of the blade curvature and the primary bevel is not visible
then the instrument has a distal bevel and if the primary
bevel can be seen from the similar viewpoint the instrument
has a mesial or reverse bevel.

Bibeveled Instrument
If two additional cutting edges extend from the primary
cutting edges, then the instrument with secondary cutting
edges is called bibeveled instrument.

Triple-beveled Instrument
If three additional cutting edges extend from the primary
cutting edge, then the instrument is called triple-beveled             Figs 5.9A to D: (A) Photograph showing mouth mirror (B to D)
instrument.                                                                           Different sizes of mouth mirrors

                                                             Periodontal Probes
                                                             Though they almost look like explorers but they have blunt
                                                             end which is marked with graduations (Fig. 5.14). They

                                                             HAND CUTTING INSTRUMENTS

                                                             Instrument Families
                                                             Many dental procedures require the use of hand instruments
                                                             with sharp cutting edges. They are used in the tooth
                                                             preparation procedures for amalgam, composite and other
          Figs 5.12A to D: Different types of explorers
                                                             restorations. All instruments can be basically divided in into
                                                             two families:
Tweezers                                                     • The chisel family consisting of chisel, hoe, angle former
These have angled tip and are available in different sizes       and cleoid-discoid.
(Figs 5.13A and B). They are used to place and remove        • The hatchet family consisting of hatchet, gingival
cotton rolls and other small materials.                          margin trimmer and spoon excavator.

                                                             Chisels
                                                             Chisels are used for cleaving, planing and lateral scraping.
                                                             In other words, they are used to split tooth enamel, to
                                                             smooth preparation walls and to sharpen the preparations.
                                                             Chisels are used with a push motion.

                                                             Straight Chisel
                                                             In straight chisel, the cutting edge of the chisel makes a 90°
                                                             angle to the plane of the instrument. It is used for gingival
                                                             restoration of the anterior teeth (Fig. 5.15).



       Figs 5.13A and B: (A) Tweezers, (B) Diagrammatic
                   representation of tweezer                                        Fig. 5.15: Chisel
      80
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                          Figs 5.16A and B: Angled chisels; (A) Biangled,
                                                                      (B) Monoangle chisel


                                                 Angled Chisel
                                                 In angled chisels, the primary cutting edge is in a plane
                                                 perpendicular to the long axis of the shaft and may have                                 Fig. 5.18: Hoe
                                                 either a mesial or distal bevel. They are used with a push or
                                                 pull motion for anterior proximal restorations, smoothening
                                                 proximal walls and gingival walls for full coverage
                                                 restorations (Figs 5.16A and B).
                                                     The two most common types used in operative dentistry
                                                 are the Wedelstaedt and biangle chisels (Fig. 5.17). The
                                                 Wedelstaedts have slightly curved shanks. They are mainly
                                                 used on anterior teeth. The biangle chisels have two different
                                                 angles—one at the working end and other at the shank.
                                                 This design permits access to tooth structures which are
                                                 not be possible with straight chisels.
                                                 Hoes: Dental hoes resemble a miniature garden hoe. By
                                                                                                                           Figs 5.19A and B: Monoangle and biangle hoe
                                                 definition, the hoe is any instrument where the blade makes
                                                 more than a 12.5° angle with the plane of the instrument         Angle Former
                                                 (Fig. 5.18). Commonly hoe blades make 45 to 90° angle to
                                                 the long axis of handle. Its shank can have one or more          Angle former is a type of excavator which is monoangled
                                                 angles (Figs 5.19A and B). Hoe is used with a pulling motion.    with the cutting edge sharpened at an angle to the long axis
                                                 Hoe is used to smooth and shape the floor and form line          of the blade. Angle of cutting edge to blade axis lies between
                                                 angles in class III and V restorations.                          80 to 85 centigrades (Figs 5.20A and B). Blade of angle
                                                                                                                  former is beveled on sides as well as the end, this forms
                                                                         Chisel vs Hoe                            three cutting edges. It is used with a push or pull motion
                                                                                                                  for accentuating line and point angles, to establish retention
                                                      By definition chisel is an instrument where the blade
                                                                                                                  form in direct filling gold restoration.
                                                      makes up to 12.5° angle with the plane of the instrument,
                                                                                                                      There are two sets of angle formers, mesial and the
                                                      whereas in hoe, the blade is angled more than a 12.5°
                                                      with the plane of the instrument.                           distal angle former. Each instrument in the set is a double-
                                                                                                                  ended instrument.

                                                                                                                  angle former is used to plane the gingival cavosurface margin

                                                                                                                  It is modified chisel with different shape of cutting edges

                                                                                                                                      Cutting Instruments

                                                                    Hatchet
                                                                    Any instrument where the cutting edge is parallel or close
                                                                    to parallel to the plane of the instrument is called a hatchet.
                                                                    Basically, a hatchet is the similar to as an axe except that it
                                                                    is much smaller (Figs 5.22A and B).
                                                                        Hatchet is a paired instrument in which blades make
                                                                    45 to 90° angle to the shank. In paired right and left hatchets
                Figs 5.20A and B: Angle formers                     blades are beveled on opposite sides to form their cutting
                                                                    edges (Figs 5.23A and B).
                                                                        Some hatchets have single cutting ends and some have
it is disk-like, instead of a sharp edge, the edge is rounded.      cutting edges on both ends of the handle. Hatchets are used
These instruments have sharp cutting edges as spoon                 for cleaving enamel and planning the dentinal walls so as to
excavators but blade to shaft relationship is similar to chisels.   have sharp outline of the preparation.
They are used for removing caries and carving amalgam or                Some hatchets are bibeveled, i.e. blade has two bevels
wax patterns.                                                       with cutting edge in the center. These bibeveled biangle
                                                                    hatchets are used in a chopping motion to refine line and
                                                                    point angles.

RESTORATION INSTRUMENTS
Following are the commonly used instruments when                             Condensers
temporary or permanent restoration is being done.                            To deliver the restoration to the tooth preparation and
                                                                             properly condense it, condensers are used. The hammer-
Cement Spatulas                                                              like working end of condenser should be large enough to
Several types of spatulas are available in the market differing              pack the restoration without sinking into it. Condensers come
in shape and size (Fig. 5.28A). On the basis of size, cement                 in single and double-ended designs. They are available in
spatula can be classified into two types (Fig. 5.28B):                       differently shaped and sized working ends like round,
                                                                             triangular or parallelogram, which may be smooth or serrated.
                                                                             Condensers can be hand or mechanical in nature (Figs 5.30A
                                                                             and B).

                                                                             Amalgam Carriers
                                                                             To pack amalgam material into the tooth preparation,
           Fig. 5.28A: Different types of cement spatulas                    amalgam carriers are needed. They carry the freshly prepared
                                                                             amalgam restorative material to the prepared tooth. These
                                                                             carriers have hollow working ends, called barrels, into which
                                                                             the amalgam is packed for transportation (Figs 5.31A and
                                                                             B). Carriers can be both single and double ended. Barrel of
                                                                             amalgam carriers comes in a variety of sizes viz; small,
                                                                             large and jumbo. Lever of amalgam carrier is located on the
             Fig. 5.28B: Large and small cement spatula                      top of the carrier. When lever is depressed, the amalgam is
      84
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                                                                                 Figs 5.31A and B: (A) Amalgam carriers, (B) Diagrammatic
                                                                                                                             representation of amalgam carrier




                                                       Figs 5.30A and B: (A) Condensers, (B) Diagrammatic
                                                               representation of different condensers


                                                 expelled into the preparation. A poorly packed amalgam
                                                 carrier may result amalgam fall out before it is ejected into
                                                 the prepared tooth. After restoration is completed, expel
                                                 out any remaining amalgam alloy from the carrier into the
                                                 amalgam well otherwise carrier will no longer be serviceable
                                                 when the amalgam is allowed to harden in the carrier.

                                                 Carvers
                                                 Carvers are used to contour the restoration approximately
                                                 same to original tooth structure. Sharp cutting edges present
                                                 in carvers are used to shapen and form tooth anatomy from
                                                 a restorations. Carvers come in different shapes and sizes
                                                 in double ended designs (Figs 5.32A and B). Many carvers            Figs 5.32A and B: (A) Carvers, (B) Diagrammatic
                                                 are designed for carving specific tooth surfaces. For                          representation of carvers
                                                                                                                                 85
example, interproximal and hollenback carvers are used for




                                                                                                                                 Cutting Instruments
carving proximal surfaces and discoid cleoid and diamond-
shaped carvers are used for carving occlusal surfaces.

Burnisher
Burnishers are the kind of instruments which make the
surface shiny by rubbing. They are used to smoothen and
polish the restoration and to remove scratches present on
the amalgam surface after its carving. Burnishers have
smooth rounded working ends and come in single and
double-ended types (Figs 5.33A and B).                                         Fig. 5.34: Composite resin instruments

    Different types of burnishers are available but most
commonly used are:                                           •        Shaping of metal matrix bands.
1. PKT3—designed by Peter K Thomas                           •        Shaping of occlusal anatomy in posterior resin composite
    • Rounded cone-shaped burnisher.                                  before polymerization of resin.
2. Beavetail condenser—narrow type of burnisher.             •        Burnishing margins of cast gold restoration.
3. Ovoid burnisher—comes in various sizes such as 28,
    29, 31.                                                  Composite Resin Instruments

Uses of Burnishers                                           For composite resin restorations, a wide range of double-
                                                             ended instruments are used to transport and place resins.
Burnishers are used for:                                     The working ends on these instruments range from varying
• Final condensation of amalgam.                             small cylinders to angled, paddle like shapes (Fig. 5.34).
• Initial shaping of occlusal anatomy of amalgam.            Composite resin instruments are made of plastic or titanium
                                                             coating. Advantages of using plastic instruments are that
                                                             they do not discolor or contaminate the composite resto-
                                                             ration, also the composite resin material does not stick to
                                                             the instrument.

                                                             INSTRUMENT GRASPS
                                                             For accurate and precise control over the instrument certain
                                                             instrument grasps are suggested which help in increasing
                                                             efficiency of the operator, offer more flexibility of move-
                                                             ments and decrease strain on the operator. In other words,
                                                             correct instrument grasps are important for achieving
                                                             success in operative procedures.
                                                                 The correct grasp is selected according to the
                                                             instruments being used, position of instrument being used,
                                                             the operator, the area which is being operated and the specific
                                                             procedure to be done.

                                                                                 Commonly used instrument
                                                                                 grasps in operative dentistry

                                                                 1.    Modified pen grasp
                                                                 2.    Inverted pen grasp
                                                                 3.    Palm and thumb grasp
      Figs 5.33A and B: (A) Burnishers, (B) Diagrammatic
                  representation of burnishers                   4.    Modified palm and thumb grasp.
      86
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                                  Fig. 5.35: Modified pen grasp                                   Fig. 5.37: Palm and thumb grasp



                                                 Modified Pen Grasp                                               most commonly used for preparing a tooth in the lingual
                                                 This is the most commonly used grasp. The greatest               aspect of maxillary anterior and occlusal surface of maxillary
                                                 delicacy of touch is provided by this grasp. Normally, a pen     posterior teeth.
                                                 is held with the thumb and index finger, with the middle
                                                 finger placed under the pen. The modified pen grasp is similar   Palm and Thumb Grasp
                                                 to the pen grasp except the operator uses the pad of the
                                                 middle finger on the handle of the instrument rather than        This grasp is same as for holding the knife for peeling the
                                                 going under the instrument (Fig. 5.35). The positioning of       skin of an apple. The palm and thumb grasp is commonly
                                                 the fingers in this manner creates a triangle of forces or       used for bulky instruments. In this, instrument is grasped
                                                 tripod effect, which enhances the instrument control. It is      very near to its working end so that thumb can be braced
                                                 most commonly used in mandibular teeth. Here palm of the
                                                                                                                  against the teeth so as to provide control during instrument
                                                 operator faces away from the operator. This position
                                                 stabilizes the instrument and allows the middle finger to        movements. The shaft of the instrument is placed on the
                                                 help push the instrument down.                                   palm of the hand and grasped by the four fingers to provide
                                                                                                                  firm control, while the thumb is free to control movements
                                                 Inverted Pen Grasp                                               and provide rest on a adjacent tooth of the same arch (Fig.
                                                 In inverted pen grasp finger positions are the same as for       5.37). To achieve the thrust action with the fingers and
                                                 the modified pen grasp except that hand is rotated so that       palm, instrument is forced away from the tip of the thumb
