                                                                                                                  application of heavy force with greater control, it is used
                                                                                                                  for holding a handpiece while cutting incisal retention for a
                                                                                                                  class III preparation in maxillary incisor.

                                                                                                                  Modified Palm and Thumb Grasp

                                                                                                                  The instrument is held like the palm grasp but the pads of
                                                                                                                  all the four fingers press the handle against the palm and
                                                                                                                  pad and first joint of the thumb. Here tip of the thumb rests
                                                                                                                  on the tooth being prepared or the adjacent tooth. Modified
                                                                                                                  palm and thumb grasp provides more control to avoid
                                                                                                                  slipping of instrument. This grasp is commonly used in
                                                                  Fig. 5.36: Inverted pen grasp                   maxillary anterior teeth.

                                                 SHARPENING OF HAND INSTRUMENTS                                  Mechanical
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 Instrument sharpening is a critical component of operative      It is bench type piece of equipment in which honing disks
                                                 dentistry. It is impossible to carry-out procedures with dull   are mounted. On top disk rotates up to 7,000 rpm. It saves
                                                 instruments. A sharp instrument cuts more precisely and         time, e.g. honing machine.
                                                 quickly than dull instruments. Therefore to avoid wasting
                                                 time on using dull instruments, dentists must be thoroughly     Mounted Stones
                                                 familiar with principles of sharpening.                         In this, stones are mounted on metal mandrel and used with
                                                                                                                 slow speed handpiece. Most common mounted stones are
                                                 Goals of Sharpening                                             Arkansas and ruby. Various shapes such as cylindrical,
                                                 •   To produce a functionally sharp edge.                       conical or disk shaped are available. Mounted stones are
                                                 •   Maintain the contour (shape) of instrument.                 not preferred in routine because they:
                                                 •   Maintain the life of instrument.                            1. Tend to wear down quickly.
                                                                                                                 2. Result in generation in frictional heat.
                                                 Advantages of Sharp Instruments                                 3. Difficult to control during sharpening.

                                                 Use of well sharpened instruments results in:                   Unmounted/Handhold Stones
                                                 • Improved efficiency.
                                                                                                                 These are commonly used for instrument sharpening. These
                                                 • Improved tactile sensations.
                                                                                                                 come in variety of sizes and shapes. Stone can be rectangular
                                                 • Less pressure and force.
                                                                                                                 with flat, rectangular with grooved surfaces or cylindrical
                                                 • Improved instrument control.
                                                                                                                 in shape.
                                                 • Minimized patient discomfort.                                 • Flat stone is ideal for moving technique.
                                                 • Less treatment time.                                          • Cylindrical stone for removing wire edges.
                                                 Principles of Sharpening                                        Stone type can come in natural or synthetic form:
                                                                                                                 1. Natural–Arkansas (preferred)
                                                 Some basic principles used during sharpening are:               2. Synthetic
                                                 • Select the appropriate type of stone for type of                 • India stone
                                                   instrument to be used.                                           • Ceramic stone
                                                 • Instrument should be clean and sterile before sharpening.        • Composition stone
                                                 • Establish proper angle between stone and surface of
                                                   instrument on the basis of design.                            Guidelines for Sharpening
                                                 • Lubricate the stone during sharpening as it reduces the       Operative Instruments
                                                   clogging of sharpening stone and heat generated during
                                                                                                                 1. When sharpening GMT, chisels, hatchets and hoes, place
                                                   sharpening.
                                                                                                                    the cutting edge bond flat against the flat stone and push
                                                 • Stable and firm grip of both instrument and stone is
                                                                                                                    or pull the instrument so that acute cutting angle moved
                                                   required during sharpening. Maintain the proper
                                                                                                                    forward (Fig. 5.42).
                                                   angulation throughout sharpening strokes.
                                                 • Sharpening should be done with light stroke or pressure.
                                                   Avoid excessive pressure.
                                                 • When sharpening is completed observe the cutting edge
                                                   for wire edges. Wire edges should be removed. (Wire
                                                   edges are unsupported metal fragments that extend
                                                   beyond the cutting from the lateral side or face of blade).
                                                 • Resterilize the sharpened instruments.

                                                 Devices Used for Sharpening
                                                 •   Mechanical
                                                 •   Mounted
                                                 •   Handhold stones (Unmounted).                                           Fig. 5.42: Sharpening the bevel end of hoe
                                                                                                                                           89
                                                                           ROTARY CUTTING INSTRUMENTS




                                                                                                                                           Cutting Instruments
                                                                           Rotary cutting instruments are those instruments which
                                                                           rotate on an axis to do the work of abrading and cutting on
                                                                           tooth structure.

                                                                           Types of Rotary Cutting
                                                                           1. Handpiece: It is a power device.
                                                                           2. Bur: It is a cutting tool.

                                                                           Handpieces
                                                                           The first rotary instruments were drill or bur heads that
Figs 5.43A to C: Different bevels of sharpened instrument;
(A) Blunt bevel—incorrect, (B) Correct bevel with 45°, (C) Steep           were twisted with the fingers for crude cutting of the tooth
bevel—incorrect                                                            tissue. Drilling came as the modification (1728) where seat
                                                                           for the drill was provided by a socket fitting against the
2. Bevel of instrument should make 45° angle with face of                  palm and the ring was adapted to the index or middle finger.
   blade. So, while sharpening blade should make a 45°                     In the mid 19th century, there occurred the invention and
   angle with the sharpening surface (Figs 5.43A to C).                    deve-lopment of both mechanical and pedal powered
3. While sharpening spoon excavators, cleoid and discoid                   handpieces. In 1864, British dentist George Fellows invented
   carvers, rotate the instrument as the blade is moved on                 the “clockwork” drill. The bur was attached to it by a shaft
   the sharpening stone.                                                   with a rotating spindle inside. The drill was wound up like a
4. Move the instrument with bevel against the stone surface                clock, with a key inserted into the back. Drill used to spin
   and cutting edge placed perpendicular to the path of                    for 2 minutes before needing to be rewound.
   movement (Fig. 5.44).                                                       In 1868, American dentist GF Green developed a
5. For curved or round cutting edge instrument, handle of                  pneumatic handpiece powered by pedal operated bellows.
   edge instrument should be moved in an arc to keep the                       First “dental engine” to provide enough power to spin
   cutting edge perpendicular to direction of cutting stroke.              the bur with sufficient speed for tooth cutting was developed
                                                                           in 1871 by Dr James B Morrison. It was adapted from
           Advantages of hand cutting instruments                          sewing machine concept.
 •    Self-limited in cutting enamel.                                          In the 1950s and 1960s, maximum developments
 •    They can remove large pieces of undermined enamel                    occurred for improvements in design, mechanical operation
      quickly.                                                             and speed of the handpieces.
 •    No vibration or heat accompanies the cutting.
                                                                               In 1957, the Borden, Airotor was developed as the
 •    Efficient means of precise cutting.
 •    Create smooth surface on cutting.                                    prototype for today’s modern air-turbine handpiece. It had
 •    Long lifespan and can be resharpened.                                speeds up to 250,000 rpm.
                                                                               Air-turbine systems depend mainly on momentum to
                                                                           produce their power. Since, they are powered by the speed
                                                                           of airflow, there is no physical or mechanically connected
                                                                           power source. Thus, under load, they tend to slow down.
                                                                           Therefore, “touch-and-go” rule should be followed with
                                                                           these air-driven turbines. This means touch the bur to tooth
                                                                           and start cutting by applying pressure, when as the bur
                                                                           slows, release pressure until the bur resumes its speed.
                                                                           Because of their ease of use, simple design and patient
                                                                           acceptance air turbine handpieces are still very popular.
                                                                               Electrically driven handpieces were introduced in the
                                                                           1970s. They offer many advantages over their air driven
                                                                           predecessors. Though these handpieces are heavier and
Fig. 5.44: Sharpening of cleoid carver is done in such a way that handle
is moved in an arc to the rotate the blade as bevel end is pulled on       bigger than air-driven handpieces, but they have the
sharpening stone surface                                                   advantage of maintaining a constant speed during cutting,
      90
                                                 which does not decrease under load. Also these handpieces            and the larger outer tube returns the water to the

                                                 Classification of Handpiece
                                                 Dental handpiece are classified according to their driving
                                                 mechanisms.
                                                 1. Gear driven handpiece: Rotary power is transferred by
                                                    a belt which runs from an electric engine. Power is
                                                                                                                             Fig. 5.46: Micromotor contra-angle handpiece
                                                    transferred from the straight handpiece by a shaft and
                                                    gears inside the angle section. These handpieces are
                                                    capable of working with widespeed range, though they
                                                    work best at low speed because of so many moving
                                                    parts with metal to metal contact.
                                                 2. Water driven handpiece: They were discovered in 1953.
                                                    These handpieces operate at speeds up to 100,000 rpm.
                                                    In these handpieces, a small inner piece transport water
                                                    under high pressure to rotate the turbine in the handpiece                       Fig. 5.47: Straight handpiece

6. Blade angle: It is the angle between the rake face and
                                                                              Fig. 5.58: Relationship between length of
   the clearance face.                                                                  bur shank and run-out
   Significance: Among these rake angle is one of the most
   important feature of bur blade design. Negative rake
   angle increases the life of bur by reducing fracture of           case, there is trembling of bur during rotation, this effect
   cutting edges. Positive rake angle increases the cutting          of run-out is directly proportional to length of bur shank
   efficiency but since it reduces the bulk of bur blade, it         (Fig. 5.58). Run-out occurs if:
   becomes prone to fracture. Positive rake angle also               a. Bur head is off center on axis of the bur.
   causes clogging of debris in the chip space (Fig. 5.56).          b. If bur neck is bent.
         If blade angle is increased, it reinforces the cutting      c. If bur is not held straight in handpiece chuck.
   edge and thus reduces their fracture. But clearance angle,        Run-out causes:
   blade angle and rake angle cannot be varied independent           a. Increase in vibration during cutting.
   of each other. For example, increase in blade angle,              b. Causes excessive removal of tooth structure.
   decreases the clearance angle. Usually, the carbide burs
   have negative rake angles and 90° of blade angle so as         Factors Affecting Cutting Efficiency of Bur
   to reduce their chances of fracture. For better clearance      Burs remove the tooth tissue at different rates depending
   of debris, the clearance faces of carbide burs are made        upon various factors. It is always desirable to cut a large
   curved to provide adequate flute space.                        quantity of tooth in short-time. Following affect the cutting
7. Concentricity: It is a direct measurement of symmetry          efficiency of a bur:
   of the bur head. In other words, concentricity measures        1. Clearance angle, rake angle and blade angle: Clearance
   whether blades are of equal length or not. It is done              angle reduces the friction between cutting edge and the
   when the bur is static.                                            work. It also prevents the bur from digging excessively
8. Run-out: It measures the accuracy with which all the               into the tooth structure. But an increase in rake angle
   tip of blades pass through a single point when bur is              decreases the blade angle which inturn decreases the
   moving (Fig. 5.57). It measures the maximum dis-                   bulk of bur blade (see Fig. 5.56).
   placement of bur head from its center of rotation. In                  Positive rake angle increases cutting efficiency of
                                                                      bur, but increase in rake angle causes decrease in bulk
                                                                      of bur blade and clogging of flute space because of
                                                                      production of larger chips.
                                                                  2. End cutting or side cutting bur: According to particular
                                                                      task, choice of bur can be end cutting, side cutting or
                                                                      combination of both. For example, it is preferred to make
                                                                      entry to enamel by end cutting bur, while for making
                                                                      preparation outline, use side cutting bur.
                                                                  3. Neck diameter of bur: If neck diameter of bur is large,
                       Fig. 5.57: Run-out                             it may interfere with accessibility and visibility. But if
      96
                                                     diameter is too short, it will make bur unable to resist
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                     the lateral forces.
                                                 4. Spiral angle: Burs with smaller spiral angle have shown
                                                     better efficiency at high speeds.
                                                 5. Linear surface speed: Within the limit, faster the speed
                                                     of cutting instrument, faster is the abrasive action and
                                                     more efficient is the tooth cutting instrument. Bur speed
                                                     should be increased in limits because with ultrahigh
                                                     speed, centrifugal force comes into the play.
                                                 6. Application of load: Load is force exerted by a operator
                                                     on tool head. Normally for high speed instruments, load
                                                     should range between 60 and 120 gm and for low
                                                                                                                            Figs 5.60A and B: Flute end designs; (A) Star, (B) Revelation
                                                     rotational speeds, it should range between 1000 and
                                                     1500 gm. Cutting efficiency decreases when load is
                                                     applied, there is increase in temperature at work face                 •   Star cut design: Here the flutes come together in a
                                                     which results in greater wear and tear of handpiece                        common point at the axis of bur.
                                                     bearings.                                                              •   Revelation design: Here the flutes come together at
                                                 7. Concentricity and run-out: The average clinically                           two junctions near diametrical cutting edge. It has
                                                     acceptable run-out is 0.023 mm. Increase in run-out                        better efficiency in direct cutting.
                                                     causes increase in vibrations of the bur and excessive
                                                     removal of tooth structure.                                        RECENT ADVANCES IN ROTARY INSTRUMENTS
                                                 8. Lubrication: Lubricant/coolant applied to tooth and bur             1. Fiberoptic handpiece.
                                                     during cutting increases the cutting efficiency and                2. Smart prep burs.
                                                     decreases the rise in temperature during cutting. Absence          3. Chemical vapors deposition (CVD) diamond burs.
                                                     of coolant can result in increase in surface temperature
                                                                                                                        4. Fissurotomy burs.
                                                     which may produce deleterious effects on pulp.

                                                     the cutting edges and increases shelf life of the bur.

                                                     efficiency but causes faster clearance of debris because           have been made available. This fiberoptic delivers a high
                                                     of larger chip space (Fig. 5.59).                                  beam of light to the handpiece head directly on working
                                                 11. Visual contact with bur head: For efficient tooth cutting,         site.
                                                     it is mandatory to maintain visual contact with bur head
                                                     while working.                                                     Smart Prep Burs
                                                 12. Design of flute ends: There are two types of flute ends
                                                                                                                        Smart prep instrument is also known as polymer bur or
                                                     (Figs 5.60A and B):
                                                                                                                        smart bur.
                                                                                                                            This type of instrument is made from polymer that safely
                                                                                                                        and effectively remove decayed dentin without affecting
                                                                                                                        the healthy dentin.
                                                                                                                            Smart prep bur has property of self-limiting, this means
                                                                                                                        it will not cut the healthy dentin. It cuts dentin only when
                                                                                                                        large amount of force is applied.

                                                                                                                        Availability
                                                                                                                        •   Sizes 2, 4, 6.
                                                                                                                        •   Used with slow speed handpiece (500-800 rpm).
                                                 Fig. 5.59: As the number of blades reduce, it results in increase in   •   Single patient use.
                                                    chip size and faster clearance because of larger chip space

Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD)
Diamond Burs                                                    Advantages

In 1996, CVD diamond burs attached to an ultrasonic             1. Minimum heat build up and vibration
handpiece were introduced to eliminate problems faced with      2. Conservation of tooth structure
diamond burs.                                                   3. Increased patient comfort.
    These diamond burs are obtained by chemical vapor
                                                                Disadvantages
deposition of diamond film over a molybdenum substrate.
    These tips are made in a reactor in which mixture of        1. Should be used with suitable restorative materials
methane and hydrogen gas results in the formation of            2. Costly.
artificial diamond layer over the molybdenum substrate.
    These tips require only slight touch to promote tooth       ABRASIVE INSTRUMENTS
grinding.                                                       The head of these instruments consists of small angular
    If too much pressure and force is applied during cutting,   particles of a hard substance held in a matrix of softer
the effects would be:                                           material called as the binder. Different materials used for a
1. Excessive heat generation.                                   binder are ceramic, metal, rubber, shellac, etc.
2. Decrease in cutting efficiency.                                 Abrasive instruments can be divided into: (i) Diamond
3. Excessive noise production.                                  abrasives, (ii) Other abrasives.
4. Pain.
5. Fracture of the molybdenum substrate.                        Diamond Abrasive Instruments
                                                                They were introduced in 1942. They have greater resistance
Advantages                                                      to abrasion, lower heat generation and longer life to be
1. Less noise                                                   preferred over tungsten carbide burs. Diamond instruments
2. Greater durability                                           consist of three parts:
                                                                1. A metal blank.
3. Better access and visibility
                                                                2. Powdered diamond abrasive: Abrasive diamond can be
4. Better cooling
                                                                    natural or synthetic which is crushed to a powder of
5. Effective tooth preparation
                                                                    desired particles.
6. Improved proximal access                                     3. The bonding agent: It serves the purpose of holding
7. Reduced risk of metal contamination                              the abrasive particles together and binding the particles
8. Preservation of tooth structure and also minimal damage          to the metal blank. Most commonly used binding agents
   to gingival tissues.                                             for diamond instruments are ceramic and metal.

Disadvantages                                                   Classifications
1. Technique sensitive                                          •   Coarse grit diamonds burs (125-150 µ particle size)

                                                                                                                     a low density compared to fine grit burs.

                                                 Efficiency and Effectiveness                                     7. Miscellaneous like individual dental techniques,
                                                                                                                     difference in pressure, differences in handpieces, etc.
                                                 1. Size of the abrasive particles: Abrasive nature is directly      also affect abrasive efficiency of instrument.
                                                    proportional to size of abrasive particle. Rapid removal
                                                    of material occurs with coarse grit burs compared to          Other Abrasive Instruments
                                                    medium or fine grit burs (Fig. 5.62).
                                                                                                                  They are used for shaping, finishing and polishing
                                                                                                                  restorations in the clinic and in the laboratory. They are of
                                                                                                                  two types:
                                                                                                                  1. Moulded abrasive instruments: These have heads made
                                                                                                                      by moulding mixture of abrasive and matrix around the
                                                                                                                      roughened end to the shank. They are of two types:
                                                                                                                         Soft moulded instruments use flexible materials like
                                                                                                                      rubber as matrix while rigid moulded instruments use
                                                                                                                      ceramic as matrix. Soft moulded instruments are used
                                                                                                                      for finishing and polishing procedures while the rigid
                                                                                                                      ones are used for grinding and sharpening procedures.
                                                                                                                  2. Coated abrasive instruments: These are mostly disks
                                                                                                                      which have a thin layer of abrasive cemented to a flexible
                                                                                                                      backing. They are used in the finishing of enamel walls
                                                                                                                      of tooth preparations and restorations. The abrasives
                                                                                                                      used here can be silicon carbide, aluminium oxide, garnet,
                                                          Fig. 5.62: Larger particles cause deeper cutting            quartz, pumice, cuttle bone, etc.

carbide. Bur should be at least 12 fluted (Fig. 5.64A). The      instruments should always be used with light force and

                                                                 Cloth
                                                                 Cloth, carried on metal wheel can be used in final stages of
                                                                 polishing with or without polishing medium.

                                                                 Felt
                                                                 Felt is used for obtaining luster for metallic restorations
                                                                 with polishing agent. It is available in the different shapes
                                                                 such as wheel, cones and cylinders (Fig. 5.64 E).

Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                ULTRASPEED CUTTING INSTRUMENTS
                                                                                                                High speed rotary cutting instruments can result in many
                                                                                                                hazards, can be avoided or reduced by taking the certain
                                                                                                                precautions. These are as following:

                                                                                                                Pulpal Damage
                                                                        Fig. 5.64E: Felt
                                                                                                                Pulp can be injured during tooth preparation because of
                                                 Advantages of Bur Cutting                                      mechanical vibration, improper tooth preparation and heat
                                                                                                                generation during cutting. Dull burs and diamond instruments
                                                 •   Well known procedure of tooth cutting.                     have poor efficiency and also produce more heat, further
                                                 •   Precision is obtained.                                     resulting in pulpal trauma.
                                                 •   Easy to control the cutting.
                                                 •   Tactile perception during cutting.                         Precautions to Avoid Pulpal Trauma
                                                 •   Debris can be removed by water and use of suction.         •   Tooth tissue should be done only with adequate finger
                                                                                                                    rests and good visibility of the operating field.
                                                 Disadvantages                                                  •   Debris clogging the burs should be cleaned before tooth
                                                 •   Pain occurs during cutting.                                    preparation. Coolant should be used while using rotary
                                                 •   Vibration caused by cutting may crack or fracture tooth        instrument to control the heat rise.
                                                                                                                •   For this, air-water spray should be used as it acts as a
                                                     structure.
                                                                                                                    coolant, moistens the tissues, lubricates and clean the
                                                 •   Noise production.
                                                                                                                    rotary cutting instruments and also cleans the operating
                                                 •   Constant use and sterilization can cause their breakage.
                                                                                                                    site.
                                                 •   Dull burs produce excessive heat and causes pulpal
                                                     damage.
                                                                                                                Damage to Soft Tissue
                                                 •   If operator loses control or the patient moves inadver-
                                                     tently, chances of overcutting.                            Lacerations may occur in the lips, tongue, cheeks and floor
                                                                                                                of the mouth, if proper precautions are not taken. During
                                                 ULTRASONIC INSTRUMENTS                                         cutting procedures, sudden movement by the patient due to
                                                                                                                gagging, swallowing or coughing can also result in soft
                                                 Ultrasound emerged for caries removal in 1950s. The            tissue injury.
                                                 ultrasonic dental unit consists of an ultrasonic generator
                                                 and transducer located within the handpiece. The generator     Precautions
                                                 transports the energy to the transducer which causes
                                                 vibrations for removal of tooth. A water cooling system is     •   Use good visibility and accessibility to the operative field.
                                                 incorporated into the equipment. But the conventional          •   Isolate the operating site preferably by the rubber dam.
                                                 technology for diamond powder aggregation with nickel          •   Patient should be instructed not to make sudden
                                                 metallic binders cannot withstand ultrasonic power. Recently       movement while working.
                                                                                                                •   All the burs and rotary instruments should be perfectly
                                                 an alternative approach using chemical vapor deposition
                                                                                                                    centric. Even a slightly eccentric bur can destructively
                                                 (CVD) resulted in synthetic diamond technology. CVD
                                                 diamond burs are obtained with high adherence of the               damage the surrounding dental tissues.
                                                 diamond on the metal surface with outstanding abrading
                                                                                                                Damage to Ear
                                                 ability. This technology allows diamond deposition with
                                                 coalescent granulation in different formats of substrates.     When compared to conventional rotary instruments, air-
                                                 When connected to an ultrasonic handpiece, CVD diamond         turbine handpieces produce high noise level and frequency
                                                 burs show following advantages while tooth preparation:        of vibration (ranges from 75 to 100 decibels with the
                                                 • Maximizing preservation of tooth structure.                  frequency more than 2000 cycles per second). But when
                                                 • Decreased noise.                                             noise level reaches 85 decibels with frequency ranging more
                                                 • Minimal damage to the gingival tissue.                       than 5000 cycles per second, it is always preferred to
                                                 • More bur life better proximal access.                        practice protective measures. These are:
                                                 • Decreased risk of touching the adjacent tooth.               • Sound proofing of the room with sound absorbing
                                                 • Minimal patient’s risk of metal contamination.                   materials.

Inhalation Problems                                               Q.   What is a hoe?
As we know, aerosols and vapors are produced during               Q.   What is difference between hoe and a chisel?
cutting of tooth structure and restorative materials by rotary
instruments. Aerosols are fine dispersions in air consisting      Q.   What is a GMT?
of water, cutting debris, microorganisms and restorative          Q.   What are types of GMT?
materials. While removal of amalgam restoration, mercury
vapors are released and while polishing, composite                Q.   What is difference between GMT and a hatchet?
restoration monomers are released. These aerosols can be          Q.   How do you differentiate right and left GMT?
inadvertently inhaled by the patient or dentist resulting in
alveolar (lung) irritation, tissue reactions or may transfer      Q.   How do you differentiate mesial and distal GMT?
infectious diseases. Their inhalation can be prevented by         Q.   What is angle former?
the use of rubber dam, use of disposable masks and eye
wear, etc.                                                        Q.   What is amalgam carrier?
                                                                  Q.   What is burnisher and its use?
Eye Injuries
                                                                  Q.   What is a cement spatula?
When tooth tissue, calculus or any old restorations are
removed at high speeds, injury to eyes can occur because          Q.   What are different types of cement spatulas?
of flying particles, microorganisms and other debris. These       Q.   What is a plastic instrument?
can be avoided by using protective glasses worn by the
                                                                  Q.   What is condenser? What are types of condensers?
patient and the dental personnel. Also plastic shields or
protective eyeglasses should be used while using laser            Q.   How many types of carvers are there?
equipment or light curing machine.

                                                                       used in operative dentistry?

INTRODUCTION

Teeth and periodontium are designed in such a manner that
mutually they significantly contribute to their own health
and support. They are complimentary to each other. Proper
form and alignment of teeth protect periodontium. During
mastication, the contours of teeth as a unit protect the                  Fig. 6.1: Interproximal spaces of anterior teeth
periodontium. A breach in the continuity of contacts of teeth
give rise to diseases of periodontium resulting in loss of      3. Interproximal space between the adjacent teeth is proper
teeth.                                                             triangular in shape with apex at the contact area and
                                                                   base towards the outer surface (Fig. 6.2). This triangle
Ideal tooth form of interproximal area is as follows:              increasingly widens out in from the contact area of all
1. Interproximal embrasures extend on all the four sides           the four directions—occlusal, lingual, gingival and facial.
   of a tooth with definite shape around each contact area.     Consequences of not restoring proximal areas
   These four embrasures are gingival, occlusal, lingual        • Food impaction leading to recurrent caries (Fig. 6.3).
   and facial.                                                  • Change in occlusion and intercuspal relations
2. Anterior teeth have less pronounced embrasures than          • Rotation and drifting of teeth
   posterior teeth (Fig. 6.1).                                  • Trauma to the periodontium.

                                                                                                                                      done proximal restoration


                                                 MATRICING                                                        (1/8") to 7.9375 mm (5/16") for deciduous teeth. Their
                                                                                                                  thickness may range between 0.0381 mm (0.0015") to
                                                 Restoration of a tooth requires great clinical acumen so as
                                                                                                                  0.0508 mm (0.002").
                                                 to reproduce the original contours and contacts of the tooth.
                                                 In case of large missing wall of the tooth, support has to be
                                                                                                                  Functions of a Matrix
                                                 provided while placing and condensing the restorative
                                                 material. Usually a metallic strip serves this function and is   1. To confine the restoration during setting
                                                 known as the matrix band. Matrix band which forms the            2. To provide proper proximal contact and contour
                                                 temporary walls is held in its place by means of a matrix        3. To provide optimal surface texture for restoration
                                                 band retainer which may be a mechanical device, floss,           4. To prevent gingival overhangs.
                                                 wire, thread or impression materials, etc.
                                                                                                                  Requirements of a Matrix Band
                                                  MATRICING: It is the procedure by which a temporary wall is
                                                  built opposite to the axial wall, surrounding the tooth         To achieve an optimal restoration, matrix band should have
                                                  structure which has been lost during the tooth preparation.     following requirements:
                                                  MATRIX: It is an instrument which is used to hold the
                                                                                                                  1. Rigidity: The matrix band should be rigid enough so as
                                                  restoration within the tooth while it is setting.
                                                                                                                      to withstand the pressure of condensation applied during
                                                                                                                      restoration, placement and maintains its shape during
                                                 Parts of Matrix                                                      hardening.
                                                 Retainer                                                         2. Adaptability: The matrix band should be able to match
                                                                                                                      to almost any size and shape of tooth.
                                                 It holds a band in desired position and shape.
                                                                                                                  3. Easy to use: The band should be simple in design so
                                                                                                                      that it does not cause any difficulty to the patient, or
                                                 Band
                                                                                                                      hindrance to the operator during restoration of the tooth.
                                                 It is a piece of metal or polymeric material, intended to give   4. It should be able to displace the gingiva and rubber dam
                                                 support and form to the restoration during its insertion and         for ease in working.
                                                 setting. Commonly used materials for bands are:                  5. Nonreactive: It should be inert to tissues and the
                                                 1. Stainless steel                                                   restorative material.
                                                 2. Polyacetate                                                   6. Height and contour: The matrix band should not extend
                                                 3. Cellulose acetate                                                 more than 2 mm beyond the occlusogingival height of
                                                 4. Cellulose nitrate.                                                the crown of tooth. This facilitates vision and speeds
                                                      Matrix band should extend 2 mm above the marginal               up working. The matrix band helps in formation of a
                                                 ridge height and 1 mm below gingival margin of the                   physiologic proximal contact relationship.
                                                 preparation. Matrices range in width from 6.35 mm (1/4")         7. Application: The matrix band should be such that it
                                                 to 9.525 mm (3/8") for permanent teeth and 3.175 mm                  can be applied and removed easily.
                                                                                                                                105
8. Sterilization: It should be easy to sterilize.




                                                                                                                                Matricing and Tooth Separation
9. Inexpensive: It should be inexpensive.

Classification of Matrices
Depending upon their Method of Retention
1. Mechanically retained, e.g. Ivory matrix retainers
   no. 1 and 8, Tofflemire universal dental matrix band
   retainer.
2. Self-retained, e.g. copper or stainless steel bands.

                                                 Tofflemire Universal Matrix Band Retainer
                                                 It was designed by Dr BF Tofflemire. It is also well known
                                                 as ‘universal’ matrix because it can be used in all types of
                                                 tooth preparations of posterior teeth. In this, the matrix
                                                 band is fitted onto the retainer and then fitted loosely over
                                                 the tooth, which then can be tightened in position by means
                                                 of the screw (Fig. 6.7).                                                          Fig. 6.8: Angulated Tofflemire retainer

                                                 with greater diameter should be placed occlusally while with
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 lesser diameter should be placed gingivally.
                                                 Types of bands
                                                 Two types of bands are usually used:
                                                 1. Flat bands
                                                 2. Precontoured bands.
                                                 1. Flat bands
                                                    a. Available in two thicknesses
                                                             i. 0.0020 inches
                                                            ii. 0.0015 inches
                                                                Any of these thicknesses can be used, it
                                                                depends upon operators preference.
                                                    b. According to shapes, three shapes of flat bands are
                                                         available (Fig. 6.14)
                                                             i. No. 1 or universal band
                                                            ii. No. 2 or (MOD band): It has two extensions
                                                                projecting at gingival edge. It is commonly used
                                                                in molars.
                                                           iii. No. 3: Similar to No. 2 band in design but
                                                                narrower than No. 2.
                                                 • Flat band needs to be contoured before placing it in
                                                    retainer. Contouring of band can be done with the help
                                                    of:
                                                      i. Ovoid burnisher
                                                     ii. Spoon excavator (using its convex side).
                                                 2. Precontoured bands: They are also available but less
                                                    commonly used. While removing these bands, one must
                                                    take care of contour of band. Band should be rotated in
                                                    such a way that its trailing end should not fracture the
                                                    restoration.
                                                 Operative instruction for placement (Figs 6.15A to D)
                                                 1. First open the large knurled nut so that slide is at least
                                                    ¼ inch from the head (Fig. 6.15A).




                                                            Fig. 6.14: Three types of Tofflemire bands             Figs 6.15A to D: Placement of Tofflemire retainer
                                                                                                                                   109
2. Hold the knurled nut (large) with one hand, open the




                                                                                                                                   Matricing and Tooth Separation
   small knurled nut in opposite direction (counter clock-
   wise) for clearance of diagonal slot for reception of
   matrix band (Fig. 6.15B).
3. Two ends of matrix band are secured together to form
   loop or either use preformed loop (Fig. 6.15C).
4. Place the ends of band in diagonal slot.
                                                                                 Fig. 6.16: Siqveland matrix retainer
5. Then, small knurled nut is tightened to secure the band
   to the retainer.
6. After securing the band tightly to the retainer, it is placed   Steele’s Siqveland Self-adjusting
   around the tooth to restored.                                   Matrix Holder for Tapering Teeth
7. For final adaptation of matrix band to the tooth, tighten       It is especially used when there is a significant difference
   the large knurled nut (Fig. 6.15D).                             between the diameters of the cervical and occlusal one-
8. Wedge placement: Wedge should be placed after the               third of the tooth (Fig. 6.16). This matrix retainer can give
   retainer and band are snuggly fitted to the tooth. Always       two different diameters at the two ends of the matrix band.
   insert the wedge from widest embrasure area. Wedge              It is based on the principle of a movable slide which holds
   helps in developing the adequate contact and contour            and tightens the band in the required position.
   despite the thickness of material.

Procedure for removal
This is usually accomplished in two steps:                         All types of compound and complex tooth preparations in
1. Removal of retainer                                             posterior teeth.
2. Removal of band.

Removal of retainer
Small knurled knot is moved counter clockwise to free the          •   Can adapt to tooth contour properly
band from the retainer. While rotating the smaller knurled         •   Due to Steele’s siqveland self-adjusting matrix holder
knot, hold the larger knot. Keep the index finger on occlusal          anatomic adaptation of the band is possible without the
surface of tooth to stabilise the band.                                help of wedges.
Removal of band
1. Carefully remove the band from each contact point               Anatomical Matrix Band/Compound
2. Support the occlusal surface of the restoration. While          Supported Matrix
   removing the band, a condenser can be held against the          It was described by Sweeney. These are adapted over the
   marginal ridge of the restoration                               tooth with one healthy tooth on either side. To contour the
3. Do not pull band in occlusal direction rather move the          band according to tooth, pliers are used, though precon-
   band in facial or lingual direction                             toured anatomic matrix bands are also available. For further
4. Band can be cut near to the teeth on the lingual side and       adaptation of the band to surface of the tooth, wedges are
   then try to pull it from the buccal side.                       placed. Buccal and lingual embrasures are sealed with the
                                                                   help of self cure acrylic or impression compound cones.

3. Available with band thickness                                       II tooth preparation.

   • 0.0015 inch thick

                                                 Indications
                                                 •   Restoration of class II proximal tooth preparation

                                                               Full Circle or Ring Bands
                                                               Copper or stainless steel full circle or ring bands are generally
                                                               indicated for mesio-occlusodistal compound preparations
                                                               and complex preparations. Band is selected according to
                                                               required size, softened by heating to a red hot state and
                                                               quenching in water. After all these it is contoured using
                                                               pliers, trimmed by cutting pliers and finished by finishing
          Figs 6.18A and B: (A) T-shaped band, and             stones. Occlusal height of the band is also adjusted
                      (B) T-band matrix
                                                               accordingly. Proximal contact of the band may be thinned
                                                               using a small round fine, grinding stone. Wedges and
Advantages                                                     impression compound can also be used to further stabilize
                                                               the band.
•   Simple to use
                                                                   After condensation of restoration is done, the band can
•   Economical.
                                                               be cut by means of a bur at the same appointment or the
Disadvantage                                                   next day.

                                                               Plastic Matrix Strips
•   For restoring distal part of canine and premolar
•   Class II slot restorations.                                These are transparent matrix strips used for tooth colored
                                                               restorations. They can be of different types:
                                                               • Celluloid (Cellulose nitrate) strips are used for silicate
                                                                   cements
                                                               • Cellophane (Cellulose acetate) strips are used for resins.
                                                               • Mylar strips used for composite and silicate restorations
                                                                   (Fig. 6.20).
                                                                   For class IV tooth preparations, the strip is folded in “L
                                                               Shape”. The matrix is measured and cut so that one side is
                                                               as wide as the length of the tooth and the other side is as
               Fig. 6.19: S-shaped matrix band                 wide as the width of the tooth.The matrix strip is burnished
112
                                                                                                                      The “BITINE” springy ring wedge along with matrix is
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                   shaped to provide the proximal contours of a posterior tooth.

                                                                                                                   Steps of Application and Removal
                                                                                                                   •   Approximately 3 mm blob of impression compound is
                                                                                                                       applied to each of its tips.
                                                                                                                   •   The ring is held with rubber dam forcep.
                                                                                                                   •   Impression compound is warmed quickly over the flame
                                                                                                                       and carried into the oral cavity.
                                                                                                                   •   Beaks are placed into the embrasures of the preparation
                                                                                                                       side and ring is allowed to shrink. Ring tightly seals the
                                                                                                                       sectional matrix band around the tooth due to spring
                                                                                                                       action.
                                                                                                                   •   The matrix band is properly contoured with a ball
                                                                                                                       burnisher so as to adapt it to the tooth.
                                                                                                                   •   After this, gingival wedge is inserted under the contact
                                                                                                                       area.
                                                                                                                   •   After checking the fit of the matrix band, restoration is
                                                                                                                       completed.
                                                                      Fig. 6.20: Mylar strips
                                                                                                                   •   Then the ring is widened apart and removed.
                                                                                                                   •   The wedge is removed after this.

                                                 produce a convexity in the strip. This convex contoured           Indication

                                                                Anatomic Custom Made Matrix
                                                                This matrix offers best contours and contact for restoration
                                                                of compound or complex class II tooth preparations. In
                                                                this, the defective area is restored on study model to tooth
                                                                anatomy with the help of heat-resistant material like
                                                                plasticine, acrylic resin or impression compound.
                                                                    By using combination of heat to soften the template
                                                                material, followed by suction to draw the moldable material
                                                                onto the study model, a plastic template is made for the
                                                                restored tooth. After this, for fitting tooth this template is
                                                                trimmed gingivally. Template should hold at least one sound
         Figs 6.21A and B: (A) Copper band matrix, and          tooth on each side. The restorative material is loaded into
                 (B) Copper band matrix in place                the preparation, then the matrix filled with the material is
                                                                inserted and properly seated over the tooth and cured.

                                                                Indication
For restoring class V preparations.
                                                                For restoring class IV preparations and fractured teeth.

                                                                Advantages

•   Offers better contours.                                     •   Simple and easy to use

Transparent Crown Forms Matrices                                •   Costly.

These are “Stock” plastic crowns which can be contoured         TOOTH SEPARATION
according to tooth shape and size. These are specially used
for bilateral class IV preparation. After selecting the         Separation of teeth is defined as the process of separating
appropriate crown form, it is trimmed to fit 1mm beyond         the involved teeth slightly away from each other or bringing
the preparation margins. When composite restoration is          them closer to each other and/or changing their spatial
loaded in this crown form, it is positioned over the prepared   position in one or more dimensions.
tooth and cured. After the restoration is completed, this
crown form can be cut with the help of burs for its removal.    Reason for Tooth Separation
For unilateral class IV, the plastic crown is cut inciso-       Following are reasons for tooth separation:
gingivally to use one-half of the crown according to the        1. Examination: For examination of initial proximal caries
side of restoration.                                               which is usually not seen on the radiograph.
114
                                                 2. Preparation of teeth: For providing accessibility
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                    to proximal area during preparation of class II and
                                                    class III tooth preparations.
                                                 3. Polishing of restorations: Tooth separation helps in
                                                    providing accessibility to the proximal area of class II
                                                    and class III tooth preparations.
                                                 4. Matrix placement: Matrix can be placed easily during
                                                    restoration of class II restoration.
                                                 5. Removal of foreign bodies: Foreign bodies and objects,
                                                    forced interproximally, can be removed using tooth
                                                    separation.
                                                 6. Repositioning shifted teeth: It also helps to some extent
                                                    in repositioning of shifted teeth.

                                                 Methods of Tooth Separation
                                                 There are two methods which are usually used for tooth
                                                 separation. These are:
                                                 1. Slow or delayed separation                                                    Fig. 6.22: Separating rings
                                                 2. Rapid or immediate separation.

                                                 Slow or Delayed Separation                                      Rubber dam sheet (Fig. 6.23)
                                                                                                                 • It is stretched and placed interproximally between the
                                                 In this separation, teeth are slowly and gradually shifted        teeth.
                                                 apart by inserting some materials between the teeth. This       • Usually heavy or extra-heavy type is preferred due to
                                                 separation usually takes long time, i.e from several days to      thickness of sheet.
                                                 weeks.                                                          • Time for tooth separation may vary from 1 hour to
                                                 Indications: Tilted, drifted and rotated teeth in which rapid     24 hours or more.
                                                 separation is not useful.                                       • In case of pain and swelling, a floss may be used to
                                                                                                                   remove the sheet.
                                                 Advantages: One of the main advantages of slow tooth
                                                 separation is that tooth repositioning occurs without damage
                                                 to periodontal ligament fibers.
                                                 Disadvantages
                                                 1. Time consuming
                                                 2. May require many visits.
                                                 Methods for achieving slow separation
                                                 1. Separating rubber ring/bands
                                                 2. Rubber dam sheet
                                                 3. Ligature wire/copper wire
                                                 4. Gutta-percha stick
                                                 5. Oversized temporary crowns
                                                 6. Fixed orthodontic appliances.
                                                 Separating rubber ring/band (Fig. 6.22)
                                                 • Separating rubber band is usually used in orthodontic
                                                    cases.
                                                 • It is stretched and placed interproximally between the
                                                    two teeth to achieve separation.
                                                 • It may take 2-3 days to 1 week.                                               Fig. 6.23: Rubber dam sheet

116
                                                                                                          Functions of wedges
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                          • Help in rapid separation of teeth
                                                                                                          • Prevent gingival overhang of restoration
                                                                                                          • Provide space to compensate for thickness of
                                                                                                             matrix band
                                                                                                          • Help in stabilization of retainer and matrix during
                                                                                                             restorative procedures
                                                                                                          • Provide close adaptability in cervical portions of
                                                                                                             the proximal restorations, thereby help in achiev-
                                                                                                             ing correct contour and shape at cervical area
                                                                                                          • Help in retracting and depressing the inter-
                                                               Fig. 6.26: Elliot separator
                                                                                                             proximal gingival area, thus help in minimizing
                                                                                                             trauma to soft tissue
                                                 a. Elliot separator (Fig. 6.26)
                                                                                                          • Help in depressing rubber dam in interproximal
                                                    • Also known as “Crab claw” separator because            area.
                                                        of its design.

                                                                                                          2. Plastic wedges

                                                    • The separation should not be more than thickness
