          Light-transmitting wedge




                                                                                                                             Matricing and Tooth Separation
          • As the name indicates this type of wedge
             transmits 90-95% of incident light
          • It is a type of plastic wedge
          • Transparent in nature
          • Designed for use in cervical area of class II
             composite resin restoration.
          Advantages of light-transmitting wedges over
          other wedges in composite restorations
          – Help in reducing the polymerization shrink-
             age as these transmit light
          – Better adaptability.
          Important points regarding wedges
          – Select the type and shape according to
             requirement. These are:

    The tooth preparation includes all mechanical procedures
performed to remove all infected and affected tissues and           Dental caries is one of the most common diseases with
to give proper design to the remaining hard dental tissues,         approximately 80% of the population in developed countries

                                                                                                                  Teeth which are unesthetic and discolored can be treated
                                                                                                                  by esthetic restorations.

                                                                                                                  For Restoration of Loss of Tooth Material
                                                                                                                  Attrition, abrasion or erosion of teeth can be treated by
                                                                                                                  different restorative materials depending upon the extend
                                                                                                                  and location of the lesion.

                                                                                                                  is placed within a preparation made in the crown of a tooth

TERMINOLOGY OF TOOTH PREPARATION

Tooth Preparation
It is a mechanical alteration of a defective, injured or diseased
tooth in order to best receive a restorative material which
will re-establish the healthy state of the tooth including
esthetics correction when indicated along with normal form
and function (Fig. 7.4).                                                      Fig. 7.5: Simple tooth preparation involving
                                                                                        one tooth surface only
Simple, Compound and
Complex Tooth Preparation
Simple Tooth Preparation
A tooth preparation involving only one tooth surface is
termed simple preparation (Fig. 7.5). For example, mesial,
distal, occlusal, buccal, lingual tooth preparation.

Compound Tooth Preparation
A tooth preparation involving two surfaces is termed
compound tooth preparation (Fig. 7.6). For example,
mesio-occlusal (MO), disto-occlusal (DO), mesiolingual
(ML), or distobuccal (DB) tooth preparation.

Complex Tooth Preparation                                                       Fig. 7.6: Compound tooth preparation
                                                                                        involving two surfaces
A tooth preparation involving more than two surfaces is
called as complex tooth preparation (Fig. 7.7). For example,




                                                                                 Fig. 7.7: Complex tooth preparation
     Fig. 7.4: Photograph showing tooth preparation on molar                      involving more than two surfaces
122
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                            Fig. 7.8: Internal wall of tooth preparation                              Fig. 7.10: Pulpal wall

                                                 Tooth Preparation Walls
                                                                                                                 Dentinoenamel Junction
                                                 Wall
                                                 Any surface of the tooth preparation is referred to as a        Dentinoenamel junction is the line representing the junction
                                                 wall.                                                           of enamel and dentin.

                                                 Internal Wall                                                   Cementoenamel Junction
                                                 It is a wall in the preparation, which is not extended to the   Cementoenamel junction is the line representing the junction
                                                 external tooth surface (Fig. 7.8).                              of enamel and dentin.
                                                 External Wall
                                                                                                                 Pulpal Wall
                                                 An external wall is a wall in the prepared tooth surface that
                                                 extends to the external tooth surface (Fig. 7.9). External      A pulpal wall is an internal wall that is towards the pulp and
                                                 wall takes the name of the tooth surface towards which it       covering the pulp (Fig. 7.10). It may be both vertical and
                                                 is situated.                                                    perpendicular to the long axis of tooth.
                                                 Enamel Wall
                                                                                                                 Axial Wall
                                                 An enamel wall that portion of tooth preparation which is
                                                 composed of enamel.                                             It is an internal wall which is parallel to the long axis of the
                                                                                                                 tooth (Fig. 7.11).
                                                 Dentin Wall
                                                 A dentin wall that portion of tooth preparation which is
                                                 composed of dentin.




                                                            Fig. 7.9: External wall of tooth preparation                               Fig. 7.11: Axial wall
                                                                                                                                     123




                                                                                                                                     Principles of Tooth Preparation
 Fig. 7.12: Pulpal and gingival floors of a class V tooth preparation

Step
It is an auxiliary extension of the main tooth preparation on
to an adjoining surface. For example in class III tooth
preparation with lingual dovetail is called as lingual step.                           Fig. 7.14: Butt joint cavosurface
                                                                                              margin for amalgam

Floor
Floor is a prepared wall which is usually flat and
perpendicular to the occlusal forces directed occlusogin-               Angle
givally, for example, pulpal and gingival walls (Fig. 7.12).            A junction of two or more surfaces of tooth preparation is
                                                                        termed as an angle.
Cavosurface Angle Margin/Tooth
Preparation Margin                                                      Line Angle
Cavosurface angle is formed by the junction of a prepared               It is a junction of two surfaces of different orientations
tooth surface wall and external surface of the tooth                    along the line and its name is derived from the involved
(Fig. 7.13). The acute junction is referred to as preparation           surfaces.
margin or cavosurface margin. The cavosurface angle may
differ with the location of tooth and enamel rod direction of
the prepared walls and also differ according to the type of
restorative material to be used (Figs 7.14 and 7.15).




                                                                                       Fig. 7.15: Beveled cavosurface
                  Fig. 7.13: Cavosurface margin                                        margin for cast gold restoration
124
                                                 Point Angle
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 It is a junction of three plane surfaces or three line angles of
                                                 different orientation and its name is derived from its involved
                                                 surfaces or line angles.

                                                 Pulpal Line Angle
                                                 Any angle perpendicular to long axis of tooth is called pulpal
                                                 line angle.

                                                 Axial Line Angle
                                                 Any angle parallel to long axis of tooth is called axial line
                                                 angle.
                                                                                                                              Fig. 7.16: Class I tooth preparation showing
                                                                                                                                       line angle and point angles
                                                 How to Combine Different terms?
                                                 When one word is to be formed by combination of two or
                                                                                                                    •   Linguopulpal line angle
                                                 more walls or surfaces, the “al” word of prefix word is
                                                                                                                    •   Mesiopulpal line angle
                                                 replaced with “O”. For example, if distal and occlusal words
                                                                                                                    •   Distopulpal line angle.
                                                 are to be combined, the combined term will be distocclusal.
                                                 The combined word of mesial, distal and occlusal surface           Point Angles
                                                 is mesio-occlusodistal.

                                                                                                                    •   More liking towards gold and silver fillings in teeth.

                                                                                                                        Nowadays because of change in following conditions,
                                                                                                                    design of the tooth preparation has become most conser-
                                                                                                                    vative:
                                                                                                                    • Use of preventive measures like fluoridation of water

                                                                                                                    • Understanding of the fact that the remineralization of
                                                                                                                        enamel and affected dentin can take place.
                                                                                                                    • Advances in tooth colored, adhesive, fluoride releasing
                                                                                                                        restorative materials.

                                                 •   Axioincisal
                                                 •   Axiomesial                                                     Tooth preparations may be classified according to the
                                                 •   Axiodistal                                                     location where the carious lesion initiates. Caries oftenly
                                                 •   Mesioincisal                                                   initiate in the developmental pits and fissures of the teeth.
                                                 •   Mesiogingival                                                  These areas are morphologically deeper than the surrounding
                                                 •   Distoincisal                                                   tooth substance and are thus sites for food impaction and
                                                 •   Distogingival.                                                 nearly impossible to clean thoroughly, forming ideal
                                                                                                                    conditions for bacterial plaque formation (Fig. 7.21).
                                                 Point Angles                                                       Commonly seen locations of pit and fissure in teeth are:
                                                                                                                    • Palatal pits of maxillary incisors.
                                                 •   Axiodistogingival point angle                                  • Palatal grooves and pits of maxillary molars.
                                                 •   Axiodistoincisal point angle                                   • Occlusal surfaces of posterior teeth.
                                                 •   Axiomesiogingival point angle                                  • Facial grooves and pits of mandibular molars.
                                                 •   Axiomesioincisal point angle.                                  • Pits occurring in teeth because of irregularities in the
                                                                                                                        enamel formation.
                                                 TOOTH PREPARATION
                                                 Black gave following guidelines for tooth preparation:
                                                 • Providing definite mechanical retention in the pre-
                                                    paration.
                                                 • Extension of preparation in adjacent pits and fissures
                                                    for prevention of recurrent caries.
                                                 • Removal of infected and affected dentin from all
                                                    surfaces.
                                                 • Removal of even healthy tooth structure to gain access
                                                    and good visibility.
                                                    When Black gave classification, following conditions
                                                 and considerations were prevalent at that time:
                                                 • Poor oral hygiene habits.
                                                 • Poor properties of the existing restorative materials.
                                                 • The expected longer life of the restoration.                            Fig. 7.21: Deep pits and fissures are primary areas
                                                 • Hard and fibrous food.                                                         for food impaction and caries formation
                                                                                                                                     127




                                                                                                                                     Principles of Tooth Preparation
                                     Figs 7.22A and B: (A) Clinical presentation of class I lesion,
                                            (B) Diagrammatic presentation of class I lesion

                                                                 Earlier when the affected tooth was prepared because of




                                                                                                                                   Principles of Tooth Preparation
                                                                 caries, cutting of tooth was referred to as cavity preparation.
                                                                 But nowadays many indications other than caries lead to
                                                                 preparation of the tooth. Hence, the term cavity preparation
                                                                 has been replaced by tooth preparation.

                                                                     Tooth preparation is divided into two stages, each
                                                                 consisting of many steps. Though each step should be done
                                                                 to perfection, but sometimes modifications can be made in
                                                                 steps.
                                                                 A. Stage I

                                                                 Initial Tooth Preparation
    Tooth preparation involves a systemic approach based
on the mechanical and physical principles which should be        Outline Form and Initial Depth
followed in an orderly sequence. The design of the tooth
                                                                 The outline form means:
preparation for either a tooth with initial caries or replace-
                                                                 • Placing the preparation margins to the place they will
ment restoration depends upon location of the caries, the
                                                                    occupy in the final tooth preparation except for finishing
amount and extent of the caries, the amount of lost tooth
structure, and the restorative material to be used. But there       enamel walls and margins.
are some basic principles which should be followed while         • Maintaining the initial depth of 0.2 to 0.8 mm into the
doing tooth preparation.                                            dentin.
                                                                       Outline form defines the external boundaries of the
                                                                    preparations.
                                                                 The following factors affect the outline form and initial
                                                                 depth form of tooth preparation:
                                                                 • Extension of carious lesion.
                                                                 • Proximity of the lesion to other deep structural surface
                                                                    defects.
                                                                 • Relationship with adjacent and opposing teeth.
                                                                 • Caries index of the patient.
                                                                 • Need for esthetics.
       Fig. 7.28: Class VI lesion are present on cuspal tips     • Restorative material to be used.
130
                                                                                                                 “Extension for prevention means the placing the margins
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                 of preparations at areas that would be cleaned by the
                                                                                                                 excursions of food during chewing. It is done with the
                                                                                                                 objective of preventing the recurrence of caries at the
                                                                                                                 margins of fillings where the recurrence of decay is most
                                                                                                                 commonly seen. His concept also included extending
                                                                                                                 preparations through enamel fissures to allow cavosurface
                                                                                                                 margins to be placed on nonfissured enamel”.
                                                                                                                 For This
                                                                                                                 • Margins of the restoration are placed on line angles of
                                                                                                                     the tooth.
                                                                                                                 • Occlusal surface is extended through pits and fissures.
                                                                                                                 • Proximal line angles extended buccally and lingually
                                                                                                                     through embrasures and cervically below the gingival
                                                                                                                     margin.
                                                             Fig. 7.29: Outline form should include all
                                                                                                                 Advantages
                                                                    defective pits and fissures
                                                                                                                 • Prevents recurrence of decay in the tooth surface
                                                                                                                     adjoining restoration.
                                                                                                                 • Results in self-cleaning embrasure areas.
                                                                                                                 Contraindications
                                                     Before initiating the tooth preparation, outline must be    • Natural remineralization (via calcium and phosphate
                                                 visualized to access the proposed shape of the preparation          from saliva).
                                                                                                                 • Fluoride-induced remineralization (through water,
                                                 (Fig. 7.29). The outline form includes the external outline
                                                                                                                     dentifrices, restorative materials).
                                                 form and internal outline form.
                                                                                                                 • Advancements in instrumentation.
                                                     The external outline form is established first to extend    • Advancements in restorative materials.
                                                 all margins into sound tooth tissue while maintaining the       • Modifications in tooth preparation designs.
                                                 initial depth of 0.2 to 0.8 mm into the dentin towards the
                                                 pulp (Fig. 7.30). In small or localized carious lesion,
                                                 preparation design should be conservative in dimensions        Following principles are kept in mind while preparing an
                                                 whereas in moderate to large lesion, the outline form may      outline form:
                                                 be more extensive. During tooth preparation, the margins       • Removal of all weakened and friable tooth structure.
                                                 of preparation not only extend into sound tooth tissue but     • Removal of all undermined enamel (Fig. 7.31).
                                                 also involve adjacent deep pits and fissures in preparation.   • Incorporate all faults in preparation.
                                                 This was referred to it as “extension for prevention” by GV    • Place all margins of preparation in a position to afford
                                                 Black.                                                            good finishing of the restoration.




                                                               Fig. 7.30: Initial depth of preparation                    Fig. 7.31: Removal of all undermined enamel
                                                                should be 0.2 to 0.8 mm into dentin
                                                                                                                                   131
Features for establishing a proper outline form are:




                                                                                                                                   Principles of Tooth Preparation
• Preserving cuspal strength.
• Preserving strength of marginal ridge.
• Minimizing the buccolingual extensions.
• If distance between two faults is less than 0.5 mm,
   connect them.
• Limiting the depth of preparation 0.2-0.8 mm into dentin.
• Using enameloplasty wherever indicated.
Outline form for pit and fissure lesions:
• Remove all defective portion and extend the preparation
  margins to healthy tooth structure.
• Remove all unsupported enamel rods or weakened
  enamel margins.                                                  Fig. 7.33: Preparation depth should be at least 1.5-2 mm from
• If the thickness of enamel between two preparation sites           the cavosurface margin and atleast 0.2-0.5 mm into dentin
  is less than 0.5 mm, connect them to make one pre-
  paration, otherwise prepared as separate tooth pre-           good adaptation of restorative material to tooth preparation
  parations.                                                    walls and margins difficult. The enamel which is unsuppor-
• Avoid ending the preparation margins in high stress areas     ted by dentin as well as the demineralized enamel should be
  like cusp eminences.                                          removed, since it is liable to fracture.
• Extend the preparation margins to include all pits and
  fissures which cannot be managed by enameloplasty.            Internal outline form: It includes the relationship of occlusal
• Limit the depth of preparation to 0.2 mm into the dentin,     walls from cavosurface angle to the pulpal floor.
  though the actual depth of preparation may vary from          Unnecessary loss of tooth structure should be avoided from
  1.5 mm depending on steepness of cuspal slopes and            the inner dimensions of the preparation. Since, enamel is
  thickness of the enamel.                                      brittle and dentin is elastic, one should avoid placing pulpal
• Extend the outline form to facilitate the convenience for     floor in enamel. The preparation depth should be at least
  preparation and restoration.                                  1.5 to 2.0 mm vertical from the cavosurface margin to the
• If indicated because of esthetic reasons, make the            pulpal floor and at least 0.2 to 0.5 mm in dentin so as to
  preparation as conservative as possible.                      provide adequate strength to resist fracture due to masti-
                                                                catory forces (Fig. 7.33).
External outline form: It should consist of smooth curves,
straight lines and rounded line and point angles (Fig. 7.32).   Outline form for smooth surface lesions: Outline form of
Sharp and irregular projection of tooth tissue should be        proximal caries (Class II, III and IV lesions): Class II are
removed because they are not only fragile but also make         generally diagnosed using bitewing radiographs. It should
                                                                be noted that a proximal lesion which appears to be 2/3 or
                                                                more toward the dentin has actually penetrated the
                                                                dentinoenamel junction.
                                                                Following factors affect the outline
                                                                form of proximal preparations:
                                                                • Extent of the caries on the proximal side (Figs 7.34A
                                                                   and B).
                                                                • Dimensions of the contact area in the affected tooth.
                                                                • Contact relationship with adjacent tooth.
                                                                • Caries index of the patient (Fig. 7.35).
                                                                • Age of the patient.
                                                                • Position of gingiva.
                                                                • Alignment of teeth and masticatory forces likely to fall
    Fig. 7.32: Outline form should consist of smooth curves,
                                                                   on restorative material (Fig. 7.36).
        straight lines and rounded line and pointed angles      • Esthetic requirement of the patient.

Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                                          Figs 7.34A and B: Outline form should include all the carious lesion and undermined enamel



                                                                                                                                 As we saw that class II tooth preparations varies
                                                                                                                              according to the morphology, anatomy and extent of carious
                                                                                                                              involvement of the individual tooth being restored. However,
                                                                                                                              some features are common to all class II tooth preparations.
                                                                                                                              A class II tooth preparation consists of:
                                                                                                                              • Occlusal segment
                                                                                                                              • Proximal segment.
                                                                                                                              Rules for making outline form for
                                                                                                                              proximal preparation:
                                                                                                                              • Extend the preparation margins until sound tooth
                                                                                                                                 structure is reached (Figs 7.34A and B).
                                                                                                                              • Remove all unsupported enamel rods, extending the
                                                  Fig. 7.35: In a patient with high caries risk it is always preferred           margins to allow sufficient access for restoration.
                                                          to place gingival margin further into the embrasure
                                                                                                                              • Restrict the depth of axial wall 0.2 to 0.8 mm into dentin
                                                                                                                                 (Fig. 7.37).

Enameloplasty
Enameloplasty is the careful removal of sharp and irregular
enamel margins of the enamel surface by “rounding” or
“saucering” it and converting it into a smooth groove making
it self-cleansable, finishable and allowing conservative
placement of margins (Figs 7.40A and B). Enameloplasty
                                                                      Figs 7.40A and B:Enameloplasty; (A) Tooth with deep pit and fissure,
is done when caries are present only in the superficial part          (B) Removal of superficial enamel resulting in rounding of deep pit and
of the enamel or a fissure is present in less than one-third          fissure caries making it self-cleansable

                                                 pulpal and gingival floor, (B) In case of rounded pulpal floor, the rocking
                                                 motion of restoration results in wedging force which may result in
                                                 failure of restoration

                                                 • Inclusion of weakened tooth structure to avoid fracture
                                                    under masticatory forces.                                                  Primary Retention Form
                                                                                                                               Definition: Primary retention form is that form, shape and
                                                                                                                               configuration of the tooth preparation that resists the
                                                                                                                               displacement or removal of restoration from the preparation
                                                                                                                               under lifting and tipping masticatory forces.
                                                                                                                                   Usually, resistance and retention forms are obtained by
                                                                                                                               providing same features, hence they are sometimes described
                                                                                                                               together.
                                                                                                                                   The retention form is affected by the type of the resto-
                                                                                                                               rative material used. The common factors affecting retention
                                                                                                                               form are as follows:
                                                                                                                               • Amount of the masticatory stresses falling on the
                                                                                                                                   restoration.
                                                                                                                               • Thickness of the restoration.
                                                                                                                               • Total surface area of the restoration exposed to the
                                                          Fig. 7.42: Restrict the extensions of external wall
                                                                                                                                   masticatory forces.
                                                               so as to have strong marginal ridge area                        • The amount of remaining tooth structure.

                                                                                                                                    137
Pulp Protection




                                                                                                                                    Principles of Tooth Preparation
Pulp protection is a very important step in adapting the
preparation for final restoration although actually it is not a
step of tooth preparation. When remaining dentin thickness
is less, pulpal injury can occur because of heat production,
high speed burs with less effective coolants, irritating
restorative materials, galvanic currents due to fillings of
dissimilar metals, excessive masticatory forces transmitted
through restorative materials to the dentin and ingress of
microorganisms and their noxious products through
microleakage.
    Pulp protection is achieved using liners, varnishes and
bases depending upon:
• The amount of remaining dentin thickness
• Type of the restorative material used.                              Fig. 7.48: Grooves are placed in axiofacial and axiolingual
    Liners and varnishes are used where preparation depth              line angles so as to increase retention of the restoration
is shallow and remaining dentin thickness is more than
2 mm. They provide:                                               walls (Fig. 7.49). For cast restorations these are prepared
• Barrier to protect remaining dentin and pulp                    by tapered fissure bur to avoid undercuts and for plastic
• Galvanic and thermal insulation.                                restorative materials like amalgam, these are prepared by
    Bases are the cements used on pulpal and axial walls in       inverted cone bur to create slight undercuts in dentin.
thickness of about 0.5 to 2 mm beneath the permanent
restorations. They provide thermal, galvanic, chemical and        Locks: Locks are usually prepared for amalgam class II
mechanical protection to the pulp. Commonly used                  restoration in the proximal or occlusal box of class II
restorative materials as base are zinc phosphate cements,         prepared. These are made smaller in size measuring 0.25 to
glass ionomers, polycarboxylate cements, zinc oxide               0.5 mm wide and 0.5 to 1.0 mm deep in dentin.
eugenol, and calcium hydroxide cement.                            Pins: Different types of pins of various shapes and sizes
                                                                  are used to provide additional retention. They can be used
Secondary Resistance and Retention Forms                          in all types of restorations like amalgam, composite and
This step is needed in complex and compound tooth                 cast restorations.
preparations where added preparation features are used to         Skirts: Skirts are prepared for providing additional retention
improve the resistance and retention form of the prepared         in cast restorations. They increase the total surface area of
tooth. These are as following:                                    the preparation. Skirts can be prepared on one to all four
Grooves and coves: Wherever bulk of dentin is present,            sides of the preparation depending upon the required
grooves are prepared without undermining the adjacent             retention (Fig. 7.50). Skirts have shown to improve both
enamel (Fig. 7.48). Coves are small conical depressions           resistance and retention form.
prepared in healthy dentin to provide additional retention.
These are normally prepared in the proximal walls of class
II preparations at the axiofacial and axiolingual line angles,
thus reducing proximal displacement of the restoration. More
than one groove per wall should be avoided as they may
weaken the wall. Grooves are especially useful for cast
restorations. They are kept parallel to the line of withdrawal
of the wax pattern.
Slots or internal boxes: These are mainly used in amalgam
restorations. They are 1.0 to 1.5 mm deep box like grooves
prepared in dentin to increase the surface area. These are
prepared in occlusal box, buccoaxial, linguoaxial and gingival                              Fig. 7.49: Slot
138
                                                                                                              Dentin conditioning (etching and priming): Etching and
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                              priming of the dentin surface done in some restorative
                                                                                                              materials increases the retention.
                                                                                                              Adhesive luting cements: Adhesive luting cements increase
                                                                                                              the retention of indirect restorations.

                                                                                                              Procedures for Finishing the External
                                                                                                              Walls of the Tooth Preparation
                                                                                                              Finishing of the enamel margins should be done irrespective
                                                                                                              of restorative material used. During finishing there occurs
                                                                                                              the further enhancement of the cavosurface design and
                                                                                                              smoothness that produces the maximum adaptation of
                                                                                                              restoration to the walls and the margins and maximum
                                                                                                              effectiveness of restoration.
                                                                                                              The finishing of the preparation walls results in:
                                                                                                              • Better marginal seal between restoration and tooth
                                                             Fig. 7.50: Skirt in cast restoration helps           structure.
                                                                      in increasing retention
                                                                                                              • Increased strength of both tooth structure and restoration
                                                                                                                  at and near the margins.
                                                 Amalgampins: Amalgampins are vertical posts of amalgam       • Strong location of the margins.
                                                 anchored in dentin. Dentin chamber is prepared by using      • Increase in degree of smoothness of the margins.
                                                 inverted cone bur on gingival floor 0.5 mm in dentin with
                                                                                                              Degree of smoothness of walls: It depends upon type of
                                                 1 to 2 mm depth and 0.5 to 1 mm width (Fig. 7.51).
                                                                                                              restoration used. For example, for cast metal restorations,
                                                 Amalgampins increase the retention and resistance of
                                                                                                              a very smooth surface is required whereas for direct gold,
                                                 complete restoration.
                                                                                                              amalgam and composite restorations, slight roughness is
                                                 Beveled enamel margins: Beveling of the preparation          needed in the preparation walls.
                                                 margins increases the surface area and thus, the retention   Location of the margins: During finishing of the preparation
                                                 in composite restorations.                                   walls and margins, one should follow the principles of
                                                 Enamel wall etching: Etching results in microscopic          paralleling the direction of enamel wall. The knowledge of
                                                 roughness, which increases the surface area and thus helps   enamel rods is necessary for proper finishing of the
                                                 in enhancing the micromechanical retention.                  preparation margins. At the margins, all the enamel walls
                                                                                                              should have full length rods supported by dentin. To remove
                                                                                                              unsupported enamel rods near gingival margins it should be
                                                                                                              slightly beveled. In case of cast gold restorations a short
                                                                                                              bevel is given and an ultrashort bevel is given in case of
                                                                                                              gold foil.
                                                                                                              Features of finished preparation: The design of cavosurface
                                                                                                              angle depends on type of restorative material being used.
                                                                                                              For example, for amalgam restoration, cavo-surface angle
                                                                                                              of 90 degrees affords maximum strength to tooth restoration.
                                                                                                                  In case of cast metal restoration beveling of external
                                                                                                              wall is done to produce stronger enamel margin, as the
                                                                                                              marginal metal is more easily burnished and adapted.

                                                                                                              Final Procedures; Cleaning, Inspecting and Sealing
                                                                                                              The final step in tooth preparation is cleansing of the
                                                                                                              preparation. This includes the removal of debris, drying of
                                                                Fig. 7.51: Amalgampins increase               the preparation, and final inspection before placing
                                                                   retention of the restoration               restorative materials.

   The debridement of the preparation serves the following       Advantages of Air Abrasion




                                                                                                                                     Principles of Tooth Preparation
objectives:                                                      1. Precise and rapid enamel cutting.
• Cleaning of preparation walls, floors and margins from         2. Produce less heat and pressure.
   enamel and dentin chips resulting during tooth
                                                                 3. Generate less vibrations.
   preparation: Remove all the debris from the preparation,
                                                                 4. Patient requiring air abrasion do not need local anesthesia.
   especially on the margins, otherwise deposits left on
                                                                 5. Less discomfort to patient.
   them consequently dissolve, resulting in a microleakage
                                                                 6. No sound production while tooth preparation.
   which further can result in secondary caries. Cleaning
   of preparation can be done by using warm water.               Disadvantages
   Immovable particles of debris can be removed with the
   help of a small cotton pellet dampened with water or          •   Large and heavy air abrasive units.
   hydrogen peroxide.                                            •   Over preparation of tooth can occur.
• Drying the tooth preparation before insertion of the           •   High cost of the equipment.
   restorative materials: It can be done using air, dry cotton   •   Loss of tactile sense.
   pellets and commercial cleaners. It is important that teeth   •   Can result in soft tissue injury like gingival hemorrhage.
   are not dehydrated by overuse of air or hot air.              •   If handled improperly can damage sound tooth structure.
• Sterilization of preparation walls using very mild             •   Inhalation of particles can cause systemic problems.
   alcohol free disinfectant: Use of mild disinfectant in
   tooth preparation serves the purpose of disinfection.         Uses of Air Abrasion Technology

Polymer reinforced zinc oxide eugenol cement: In this




                                                                                                                                  Dental Cements
mixture, resin helps in improving strength, smoothness of
the mix and decreasing flow, solubility and brittleness of
the cement.

Manipulation of Zinc Oxide
Eugenol (ZOE) Cement
•   ZOE are available as: (i) powder and liquid system,
    (ii) paste-paste system.

Manipulation of Powder and Liquid System
Powder is measured and dispensed with a scoop where as
                                                                                 Fig. 8.3: Dispensing of zinc oxide
liquid is dispensed as drops on glass slab.                                          eugenol powder and liquid
• Powder is dispensed at one end of glass slab, using
    cement spatula. The powder is divided in main bulk
    increment, followed by smaller increments (Figs 8.3
    and 8.4). While dispensing liquid, bottle should be held
    90° to the mixing pad. It lets the fluid fall under its own
    weight.
• Start the mixing by incorporating half of the powder
    into the liquid with a heavy folding motion and pressure.
• When powder particles are wet with the liquid, add the                      Fig. 8.4: Diagrammatic representation of
    remaining powder to the mix and continue to use a heavy                       increments of zinc oxide powder
    folding motion to attain a putty consistency.
• For base, when mixing is done, bring the mix together
    and role it. One should be able to pick up the mix without
    deformation (Fig. 8.5).
• Pick-up a piece of mixed cement and place it into the
    preparation using a condenser.
• If the mix sticks to the condenser, powder the condenser
    head with cement powder to prevent the instrument from
    sticking during condensation.
• Use the condenser head and merge the restoration to
    the margin of the preparation.
• For smoothening, clean up and hardening of the
    restoration, use a wet cotton pellet.
• For luting consistency, “1 inch” string should be formed                     Fig. 8.5: Right consistency of ZOE mix
    when flat surface of spatula is pulled from the mixed
    cement.
                                                                  down the setting reaction (unless the temperature is below
                                                                  the dew point).
Paste-paste System
                                                                      Setting time of this cement is long but since water
In this two pastes are dispensed in equal lengths on paper            accelerates the setting reaction, it sets faster in mouth
pad. Two pastes have different colors, mixing is done till a          than outside.
homogeneous color is obtained.

Working Time and Setting Time
                                                                  ZOE is the best known obtundent. pH of cement is 7. This
These are usually not specified. In general, higher is the        makes it least irritating cement. Because of this it is
P:L, faster the materials sets. Cooling of glass slab slows       considered most palliative agent to the pulp.

                                                 Types of ZOE
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 Type I – Temporary luting
                                                 Type II – Long-term luting
                                                 Type III – Temporary restoration
                                                 Type IV – Intermediate restoration

                                                 Type I
                                                 Main features:
                                                 • Strength of the cement is low so it can be easily removed.
                                                 • It is used for short-term restorations.
                                                 • Free eugenol interferes with the setting of resin bonded
                                                                                                                                 Fig. 8.6: Zinc phosphate cement
                                                   composites so carboxylic acids can be used to replace
                                                   eugenol making it non eugenol cement.

                                                 Type II                                                         Disadvantages
                                                 Main features:                                                  •   Highly soluble
                                                 • This cement has improved strength and abrasion                •   Low strength
                                                   resistance.                                                   •   Long setting time
                                                 • In this cement the part of eugenol liquid substituted by      •   Low compressive strength.
                                                   ortho-ethoxybenzoic acid (EBA) and alumina is added
                                                   to powder.                                                    ZINC PHOSPHATE CEMENT (FIG. 8.6)
                                                                            or
                                                                                                                 One of the oldest and most widely used cements, zinc
                                                 • Powder is made up of 20 wt percent to 40 wt percent
                                                                                                                 phosphate cement is the standard against which new
                                                   of fine polymer particles and zinc oxide particles that
                                                                                                                 cements are compared. It was first introduced in 1878 and
                                                   have been surface treated with carboxylic acid, in this
                                                                                                                 still used today because of excellent clinical track record.
                                                   the liquid remains eugenol.

                                                 Type III                                                        Two Types

                                                 It is used for temporary restorations which last for a few      Type I: Used for cementation. Specification requires the
                                                 days to few weeks.                                              film thickness of less than 25 microns.
                                                                                                                 Type II: Used as a base and for luting. Specification requires
                                                 Type IV                                                         a film thickness between 25 and 40 microns.
                                                 It lasts for atleast up to 1 year. In this more powder has to
                                                 be added for achieving better strength.                         Composition
                                                                                                                 Powder: The primary ingredients of zinc phosphate cement
                                                 Clinical Uses
                                                                                                                 powder are zinc oxide and magnesium oxide.
                                                 •   Base                                                        • ZnO—90.2%.
                                                 •   Temporary cementation                                       • MgO—8.2%—condenses the ZnO during the sintering
                                                 •   Temporary restoration                                           process
                                                 •   Root canal sealer                                           • SiO2—1.4%—acts as an insert filler
                                                 •   Liner                                                       • Bi2O3—0.1%—imparts smoothness to the mixed cement
                                                 •   Pulp capping agent                                          • Miscellaneous—(BaO, Ba2SO4, CaO) – 0.1%.
                                                 •   Permanent cementation                                           All the ingredients are sintered at temperatures between
                                                                                                                 1000oC and 1400oC into a cake that is subsequently ground
                                                 Advantages                                                      into fine powder.
                                                 •   Soothing effect on the pulp                                 Liquid: The liquid is phosphoric acid and water in the ratio
                                                 •   Good short-term sealing.                                    of two parts acid to one part water. It may also contain

Manipulation of Cement

Manipulation of Zinc Phosphate Cement
•   Working time ~ 5 minutes
•   Setting time ~ 2.5 to 8 minutes
                                                                              Fig. 8.8A: Diagrammatic representation of
•   Powder is measured and dispensed with scoop a liquid                        increments of zinc phosphate powder
    is dispensed as drops. Cement mixing should be done
    on cool glass slab with a narrow bladed stainless steel
    spatula. Lower the temperature of the slab during mixing,
    the longer will be the working time. This is advantageous




                                                                              Fig. 8.8B: Photograph showing increments
        Fig. 8.7: Structure of set zinc phosphate cement                              of zinc phosphate powder
150
                                                     presence of less amount of unreacted acid, this step is
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                     not affected by heat released from the reaction.
                                                 •   In the end the smaller increments of powder are added
                                                     so as to achieve optimum consistency
                                                 •   After dividing powder, dispense liquid on the glass slab.
                                                     While dispensing, the liquid bottle should be held vertical
                                                     and close to the powder (Fig. 8.9). Repeated opening
                                                     of the liquid bottle or early dispensing of the liquid prior
                                                     to mixing should be avoided because evaporation of
                                                     liquid can result in changes in water/acid ratio which
                                                     can further result in decrease in pH and an increase in
                                                     viscosity of the mixed cement.
                                                 •   For luting, mixing is continued until a “1 inch string” is
                                                                                                                           Fig. 8.9: While dispensing liquid, the bottle should be
                                                     formed when spatula is pulled away from the glass slab                        held vertical and close to the powder
                                                     (Fig. 8.10). For base, consistency should be such that
                                                     it can be rolled into a ball without sticking (Fig. 8.11).
                                                 •   While setting of cement is taking place, water
                                                     contamination should be avoided because on moisture
                                                     contamination, the phosphoric acid leaches out of the
                                                     cement and solubility greatly increases.

                                                 Mechanical Properties
                                                 Strength of the cement is almost linearly depends on its
                                                 powder-to-liquid ratio; zinc phosphate cement achieves 75%
                                                 of its ultimate strength within 1 hour.                                   Fig. 8.10: For luting, “1 inch string” should be formed
                                                 • Compressive strength of cement is 104 Mpa                                 when spatula is pulled away from the glass slab
                                                 • Tensile strength - 5.5 Mpa
                                                 • Modulus of Elasticity is 13.7 gigapascals. This high
                                                     MOE makes the cement quite stiff and resistant to elastic
                                                     deformation.
                                                 • Retention of cement is by mechanical interlocking not
                                                     chemical interaction.

                                                 Biocompatibility
                                                 Because of presence of phosphoric acid, acidity of cement
                                                 is quite high making it irritable. pH of cement liquid is 2.0.
                                                 two minutes after mixing the pH is almost 2 and after 48                  Fig. 8.11: For base, consistency should be such that
                                                 hours it is 5.5.                                                               mix can be rolled into a ball without sticking


                                                 Clinical Uses
                                                                                                                        It holds tooth and restoration together by mechanical
                                                 It is used both as an intermediate base and as a cementing             interlocking, filling the space between the irregularities
                                                 medium.                                                                between the two.
                                                 1. Intermediate base: A thick mix of zinc phosphate cement
                                                      is used as an intermediate base beneath a permanent                          Uses of zinc phosphate cement
                                                      metallic restoration.                                         •    Luting agent for crowns, inlays
                                                 2. Cementing medium: It is used to cement crowns, inlays,          •    Intermediate base
                                                      orthodontic appliances and fixed partial dentures. A          •    Temporary restoration
                                                      creamy mix of cement is applied to place the restoration.     •    Luting orthodontics band

                                                                                                                                  Dental Cements

•   Long record of clinical acceptability

•   High compressive strength
•   Thin film thickness.

                                                                                                                   Classification of Glass Ionomer Cements
                                                 Solubility
                                                                                                                   A. Traditional classification (Based on application)
                                                 •   It is low in water. But in acidic environment with pH of
                                                                                                                   1. Type I—Luting cements (Fig. 8.13)
                                                     less than 4.5, solubility increases. Reduction in P:L ratio
                                                                                                                   2. Type II—Restorative cements (Fig. 8.14)
                                                     also increases solubility.
                                                                                                                       a. Type II.1—Restorative esthetic
                                                 Biological Considerations                                             b. Type II.2—Restorative reinforced
                                                                                                                   3. Type III – Liner or base
                                                 pH of the liquid is 1.7 but increases rapidly after mixing.       B. Newer classification
                                                 Zinc polycarboxylate cement shows excellent biocompa-             a. Type I—Luting cements
                                                 tibility with the pulp because of following reasons:              b. Type II—Restorative esthetic or reinforced cements
                                                 • The size of polyacrylic acid molecule is bigger, this makes     c. Type III—Liner or base
                                                     it less favorable to disperse into the dentinal tubules.
                                                 • The pH of the cement rises more rapidly when compared
                                                     to that of zinc phosphate.

                                                 Uses of Zinc Polycarboxylate Cement
                                                 •   Cement inlays or crowns
                                                 •   Used as base
                                                 •   Temporary restorations
                                                 •   Lute the stainless steel crown.

                                                 Advantages
                                                 •   Adhesion to tooth structure
                                                 •   Rapid rise in pH upon cementation
                                                 •   Lack of penetration of the large molecules into the
                                                     dentinal tubules make it a biocompatible cement.              Fig. 8.12: GIC, hybrid of silicate and zinc polycarboxylate cements

                                                 Disadvantages
                                                 •   Short working time (2-3 minutes)
                                                 •   Does not resist plastic deformation under high
                                                     masticatory stresses.

                                                 GLASS IONOMER CEMENT
                                                 Glass Ionomer Cement were introduced to the dentistry 35
                                                 years ago (in 1972) by Wilson and Kent.
                                                     The invention of the glass ionomer cement resulted from
                                                 previous fundamental studies on silicate cements and studies
                                                 where the phosphoric acid in dental silicate cements was
                                                 replaced by organic chelating acids. It was supported by
                                                 work on the zinc polycarboxylate cement in which Smith
                                                 showed that dental cements exhibiting the property of
                                                 adhesion could be prepared from polyacrylic acid. Glass
                                                 ionomer cement for that reason has been described as a
                                                 hybrid of dental silicate cements and zinc polycarboxylates                           Fig. 8.13: Type I luting GIC
                                                                                                                                   153
                                                                 GIC Liquid




                                                                                                                                   Dental Cements
                                                                 The liquid is an aqueous solution of polymers and copolymers
                                                                 of acrylic acid.
                                                                     Originally, the liquids for GIC were aqueous solutions
                                                                 of polyacrylic acid in a concentration of about 40 to 50%.
                                                                 The liquid was quite viscous and had tendency to gel
                                                                 overtime.

                                                                 Composition of Liquid
                                                                 •   Polyacrylic acid                    40-55%
                                                                      (Itaconic acid, Maleic acid)
                                                                 • Tartaric acid                         6-15%
                Fig. 8.14: Type II restorative GIC               • Water                                 30%
                                                                     To decrease the viscosity of liquid, itaconic, and
C. Classification of GICs according to their use                 tricarboxylic acids were added to the liquid. These acids
• Type I—For luting cements                                      tend to:
• Type II—For restorations                                       • Decrease the viscosity.
• Type III—Liners and bases                                      • Promote reactivity between the glass and the liquid.
• Type IV—Fissure sealants                                       • Prevent gelation of the liquid which can result from
• Type V—Orthodontic cements                                         hydrogen bonding between two polyacrylic acid chains.
• Type VI—Core build up                                              Polymaleic acid is often present in the liquid. It is a
                                                                 stronger acid than polyacrylic acid and causes the cement
Composition of Glass Ionomer Cement                              to harden and lose its moisture sensitivity faster. This occurs
                                                                 because polymaleic acid has more carboxyl (COOH) groups
Glass ionomer cement usually comes in mixtures of a powder
                                                                 which lead to more rapid polycarboxylate crosslinking. This
and a liquid.
                                                                 also allows more conventional, less reactive glasses to be
GIC Powder                                                       used which results in a more esthetic final set cement.
                                                                     Tartaric acid is also present in the liquid. It improves
The powder is an acid-soluble calcium fluoroaluminosilicate      handling characteristics and increases the working time,
glass similar to that of silicate but with a higher alumina-     but it shortens the setting time. The viscosity of tartaric
silicate ratio that increases its reactivity with liquid. The    acid-containing cement does not generally change over shelf
fluoride portion acts as a “ceramic flux”. Lanthanum,            life of the cement (Figs 8.15A and B). However, a viscosity

These powders are combined and fused (at temperatures
1100 to 1500°C) with a fluoride flux that serves to reduce       Water Settable Glass Ionomer
