                                                                                                                   Cermet Cement
                                                                                                                   It is introduced by Mclean and Gasser in 1987. This cement
                                                                                                                   is fusion of glass ionomer to metal powders like silver or
                                                                                                                   gold through sintering. Here the cement ionomers are
                                                                                                                   manufactured by sintering compressed pellets made from
                                                                                                                   fine metal powder and glass ionomer powder at temperature
                                                                                                                   of 800°C. The sintered metal and glass fit is then ground
                                                                                                                   into fine form which results in ceramicometal particles of
                                                                                                                   fused metal and ground glass. Most accepted metal for
                                                                                                                   sintering with glass ionomer is silver or gold. Titanium
                                                                                                                   dioxide (5%) is added to improve the color.

                                                                                                                   Advantages
                                                                                                                   •   Better abrasion resistance.
                                                                     Fig. 8.16: Miracle mix                        •   Higher flexure strength.

                                                                                                                   Disadvantage
                                                                                                                   Poor esthetics.
                                                 Miracle Mix (Silver alloy admix glass ionomer
                                                 cement) (Fig. 8.16)                                               Resin Modified Glass Ionomer
                                                                                                                   It was first introduced as vitrebond (3M) in powder—liquid
                                                 It was introduced by Simmons in 1983. In this, silver alloy
                                                                                                                   system to incorporate the best properties of both glass
                                                 powder is blended with glass ionomer powder in ratio of
                                                                                                                   ionomer cement and composite resin. In this system, powder
                                                 1:6 and mixed with glass ionomer liquid. This increases the
                                                                                                                   is fluorosilicate glass with photoinitiator or chemical initiator.
                                                 compressive strength, tensile strength and abrasion
                                                                                                                   The liquid contains 15 to 25% resin component in the form
                                                 resistance to some extent.
                                                                                                                   of HEMA, a polyacrylic acid copolymer along with
                                                 Disadvantages                                                     photoinitiator and water.

                                                 •   Difficult to achieve homogeneous mix of silver alloy          Advantages of Resin Modified Glass Ionomer Cements
                                                     and glass.                                                    RMGIs show combined advantages of both composites and
                                                 •   Poor esthetics.                                               glass ionomers. These are:
                                                 •   Poor burnishing.                                              • Extended working time
                                                 •   Sensitive to moisture contamination during setting.           • Control on setting

                                                                          time for glass ionomer cement is 60-90 sec.
Powder and Liquid                                                     •   Loss of gloss on the surface of the mixed cement shows

    Mixing should be done                                                 cement should be used before it loses its glossiness. If
    • At room temperature 21 to 25°C
                                                                          the glossiness is lost, the cement won’t wet the tooth

                         Figs 8.17A and B: Mixing of GIC; (A) Dispensing of powder and liquid of GIC for mixing;
                                        (B) Freshly mixed GIC ready to be used for restoration
156
                                                                                                                      CaF2 dissociates and reacts with acrylic copolymer to
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                      form a stable matrix.
                                                                                                                  •   At this stage, the mix appears glossy in nature and it can
                                                                                                                      adhere to the tooth structure.

                                                                                                                  Hydrogel Phase
                                                                                                                  •   In this phase, calcium ions are released rapidly. These
                                                                                                                      liberated ions react with the acid and cross-link with the
                                                                                                                      polyacrylic acid, i.e. calcium bridges to form a calcium
                                                                                                                      polycarboxylate gel in which the non-reacted glass is
                                                                                                                      embedded.
                                                                                                                  •   The initial setting of the cement is because of this
                                                                                                                      reaction. At this stage, the cement appears rigid and
                                                                                                                      opaque.
                                                                                                                  •   Water plays a critical role in the setting of GIC. It serves
                                                                                                                      as the reaction medium initially and then slowly hydrates
                                                                                                                      the crosslinked agents thereby yielding stable gel
                                                                                                                      structure which is stronger and less susceptible to
                                                                                                                      moisture contamination.
                                                                                                                  •   If freshly mixed cement is exposed to ambient air without
                                                                                                                      any protective covering the surface will craze and crack
                                                                                                                      as a result of desiccation. Any contamination by water
                                                                                                                      that occurs at this stage can cause dissolution of the
                                                                                                                      matrix forming cations and anions to the surrounding
                                                                                                                      areas. Both desiccation and contamination are water
                                                                                                                      changes in the structure during placement and for a
                                                        Fig. 8.18: Setting reaction of glass ionomer cement
                                                                                                                      few weeks after placement is possible.

                                                 SETTING REACTION                                                 Polysalt Gel Phase
                                                                                                                  •   This phase occurs when the mix reaches its final set.
                                                 Setting Reaction of Autocure Glass Ionomer
                                                                                                                      This stage is continued for many months.
                                                 Cement
                                                                                                                  •   In this stage continued attack of hydrogen ions cause a
                                                 Basically in autocure glass ionomer cement, setting reaction         delayed release of Al ions from silicate glass in the form
                                                 is an acid-base reaction between the acidic polyelectrolyte          of AlF ions which are deposited in the already preformed
                                                 and the aluminosilicate glass. It occurs in three different          matrix to form a water-insoluble Ca-Al-Carboxylate gel.
                                                 but overlapping stages (Fig. 8.18).                                  It is the Al ions which provide strength to the cement.
                                                                                                                  •   The structure of the fully set cement is a composite of
                                                 Three Stages of GIC Setting Reaction                                 glass particles surrounded by silica gel in a matrix of
                                                                                                                      polyanions crosslinked by ionic bridges (Fig. 8.19).
                                                 1. Ion leaching phase
                                                 2. Hydrogel phase
                                                 3. Polysalt gel phase.

                                                 Ion Leaching Phase
                                                 •   This phase occurs when powder and liquid are mixed.
                                                     When the powder and aqueous acidic solution are mixed,
                                                     the polyacid attacks the glass particles (called leaching)
                                                     to release cations like Ca2+ and Al3+.
                                                 •   These ions react with the fluoride ions to form CaF2
                                                     and AlF3–. Soon because of continued increase in acidity,         Fig. 8.19: Diagrammatic representation of finally set GIC

INDICATIONS OF GLASS IONOMER CEMENT                               3. In patients with xerostomia.
  1. Restoration of permanent teeth                               4. In mouth breathers because restoration may become

                                                                  Advantages of GIC
                                                                  •     Inherent adhesion to tooth structure because of chemical
                                                                        bonding to enamel and dentin through ion exchange.
                                                                  •     Biocompatible because large sized polyacrylic acid
                                                                        molecules prevent the acid from producing pulpal
                                                                        response.
                                                                  •     Little shrinkage and good marginal seal.
                                                                  •     Anticariogenic because of fluoride release. This fluoride
                                                                        can also be recharged from topical fluoride applications.
   Fig. 8.20: Setting reaction of resin modified glass ionomers   •     Good color matching and translucency makes it esthetic.
158
                                                 •   Minimal tooth preparation required hence easy to use
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                     on children.
                                                 •   Less soluble than other cements.
                                                 •   Less technique sensitive than composite resins.

                                                 Disadvantages of GIC
                                                 •   Brittle and low fracture resistance
                                                 •   Low wear resistance
                                                 •   Water sensitivity during setting phase affects physical
                                                     properties and esthetics.
                                                 •   Some newer products release less fluoride than
                                                     conventional GIC.
                                                 •   Opaque which makes glass ionomer cement less esthetic           Fig. 8.21: GIC shows sensitivity to water uptake and loss during
                                                     than composites.                                                   initial setting stage. This may affect its physical properties
                                                 •   Not inherently radiopaque.
                                                 •   Require moisture control during manipulation and
                                                                                                                 •   If moisture contamination occurs in first 24 hours of
                                                     placement.
                                                                                                                     setting, calcium and aluminum ions leach out of the
                                                 PROPERTIES OF GLASS IONOMER CEMENT                                  cement, thus they are prevented from forming
                                                                                                                     polycarboxylates. This results in formation of chalky
                                                 Physical Properties                                                 and eroded rough surface of restoration with low surface
                                                                                                                     hardness.
                                                 •   Glass ionomer cements have high compressive strength,
                                                                                                                 • If early desiccation occurs during initial setting of the
                                                     but low fracture toughness, flexure strength, high
                                                                                                                     cement, it retards the setting reaction since water plays
                                                     modulus of elasticity and wear resistance, thus we can
                                                                                                                     an important role in setting reaction.
                                                     mark them as hard but brittle material. Because of this
                                                                                                                 • If desiccation occurs in later stages, it prevents increase
                                                     nature, glass ionomer cements should not be used in
                                                                                                                     in strength of the cement because hydration of the silica
                                                     high stress bearing areas.
                                                                                                                     based hydrogel and the polycarboxylates cannot occur.
                                                 •   Modified GICs like cermet cements have more strength
                                                                                                                     It can also result in crazing, decreased esthetics and
                                                     but their fracture resistance remains low.
                                                                                                                     early deterioration of the cement.
                                                 •   The resin modified glass ionomers have more flexural
                                                                                                                     Therefore, one should always apply a low viscosity
                                                     and tensile strength and lower modulus of elasticity when
                                                                                                                 bonding resin, varnish or vaseline as a protective agent as
                                                     compared to conventional glass ionomer cements. This
                                                                                                                 soon as possible following cement placement to prevent
                                                     makes them more resistant to fracture but their wear
                                                                                                                 both moisture contamination and desiccation across the
                                                     resistance is still not improved much.
                                                                                                                 surface of the GIC.
                                                 Biocompatibility
                                                                                                                 Adhesion
                                                 Glass ionomer cements are considered as biocompatible
                                                                                                                 •     Glass ionomer cements are known chemical adhesives
                                                 dental materials because of following reasons:
                                                                                                                       to tooth structure. The exact mechanism by which glass
                                                 • Polyacrylic acid present in the liquid is a weak acid
                                                                                                                       ionomer cements bond to tooth structure is not known,
                                                 • Dissociated hydrogen ions present in GIC are further
                                                                                                                       though it is said that chelation between the carboxyl
                                                    bound to the polymer chains electrostatically.
                                                                                                                       groups of the cement and calcium of the tooth structure
                                                 • The long polymer chains tangle on one another, this
                                                                                                                       is responsible for their bonding.
                                                    prevents their penetration into the dentin tubules.
                                                                                                                 •     According to Wilson, adhesion of the glass ionomer
                                                                                                                       cement is due to displacement of calcium and phosphate
                                                 Water Sensitivity
                                                                                                                       ions of the tooth structure because of the action of the
                                                 Conventional glass ionomer cement is very sensitive to                carboxylate ions of cement. This results in formation of
                                                 moisture contamination during the initial stage of setting            an intermediate aluminum and calcium phosphate layer
                                                 reaction and to desiccation when the cement begins to harden          which forms bond at the tooth/cement interface (Figs

                                                 tooth and restoration, (3) Fluoride enters in saliva, (4) Both tooth and restoration are short of fluoride, (5) Topical application of fluoride

                                                                Technique for Using Resin Cements
                                                                1. Isolate the area, preferably with rubber dam.
                                                                2. Apply etchant, wait for 15 seconds, rinse for 10 seconds
                                                                   with distilled water. Remove excess water, leaving tooth
                                                                   surface moist.
                                                                3. Apply adhesive to enamel and dentin, dry for
                   Fig. 8.25: Resin cement                         5 seconds and light cure for 10 seconds.

INTRODUCTION                                                             Historical development of amalgam

The first form of silver mercury mixture was given by           1650   Stocker              Copper amalgam
M Taveau in 1826 at Paris. Crawcour brothers in US              1818   Dr Louis Regnart     Father of amalgam
                                                                1959   Dr Wilmer Eames      1:1 ratio of mercury: alloy
introduced dental amalgam to the dentistry in 1833. Since
                                                                1963   Innes and Youdelis   High copper alloy
1850, dental amalgam has been used more than any other                                      (Admixed type)
restorative material. The dental amalgam alloys consist of      1974   Asgar                Single composition high
silver and other alloys like tin, copper and smaller amounts                                copper alloy
of zinc which are mixed with mercury.                           1980   Showell              Amalgapin
164
                                                  Alloy: Alloy is a union of two or more metals
                                                                                                                  •     Increases setting expansion
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                  Amalgam: Amalgam is an alloy in which mercury occurs            •     Reduces setting time
                                                  as a main constituent.                                          •     Resists tarnish and corrosion
                                                  Dental amalgam: The dental amalgam is an alloy of mercury       •     Decreases flow.
                                                  with silver, tin, and varying amounts of copper, zinc and
                                                  other minor constituents.                                       Tin: Tin helps in formation of a silver/tin compound (AgSn).
                                                                                                                  This is the gamma phase which readily undergoes an
                                                 COMPOSITION OF AMALGAM POWDER                                    amalgamation reaction with mercury. Tin causes following
                                                                                                                  effects:
                                                 Amalgam consists of amalgam alloy and mercury. Amalgam           • Increases setting time
                                                 alloy is composed of silver-tin alloy with varying amounts       • Reduces strength, hardness, and setting expansion.
                                                 of copper, zinc, indium and palladium (Fig. 9.1). Dental
                                                 amalgam alloys are mainly of two types—low copper and            Copper: It has the following effects on the properties of
                                                 high copper alloys.                                              amalgam:
                                                     Low copper alloys contain up to 6% by weight of copper.      • Reduces tarnish and corrosion
                                                 In high copper alloys, copper content lies between 6-30%.        • Reduces creep
                                                     In general, amalgam alloy consists of silver 40%             • Strengthening effect on the set amalgam
                                                 minimum, tin 32% maximum, copper 30% maximum, zinc               • Helps in uniform comminution of the alloy.
                                                 2% maximum, and sometimes traces of indium or palladium.         Zinc: Its presence is not essential. It may vary from 0 to
                                                 In preamalgamated alloys, mercury 3% is used which react         2% by weight. It has the following effects on the properties
                                                 more rapidly when mixed with mercury. Mercury used for           of amalgam:
                                                 dental amalgam is purified by distillation.                      • Scavanges the available oxygen to impede oxidization
                                                                                                                      of Ag, Sn or Cu during alloy ingot manufacture.
                                                 Effects of Constituent Metals                                    • If zinc-containing alloys are contaminated with moisture,
                                                 on the Properties of Amalgam                                         Zn gives rise to delayed or secondary expansion.
                                                 Silver: It has the following effects on the properties of        Palladium (0 to 1% by weight)
                                                 amalgam.                                                         • Improves the corrosion resistance and the mechanical
                                                 • Increases strength                                                properties.
                                                                                                                  Indium (0 to 4% by weight)
                                                                                                                  • It decreases the evaporation of mercury and the amount
                                                                                                                     of mercury required to wet the alloy particles.

                                                                                                                  Proportioning
                                                                                                                  Usually Alloy/mercury ratios range between 5 : 8 and
                                                                                                                  10 : 8. But to achieve optimum properties of the amalgam,
                                                                                                                  mercury should be less than 50%. For lathe cut alloys, it is
                                                             Fig. 9.1: Composition of amalgam powder              45%. For spherical alloys, it is 40% Hg.

                                                                 On mixing amalgam alloy with mercury, the alloy particles
   a. Binary alloys: Contain 2 metals, i.e. silver and tin.
                                                                 get dissolved in the mercury. In the initial reaction, mercury
   b. Ternary alloys: Contain 3 metals, i.e. silver, tin and
                                                                 reacts with tin and silver without involving copper and zinc.
      copper.

   Out of these, quaternary alloys are most acceptable.          matrix of reaction products with mercury. The reaction is

high copper alloy is mixed with conventional alloy.                •   Creep is the time-dependent response of an already set
                                                                       material to stress. This response is in form of plastic
PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF AMALGAM                                         deformation. It can be of two types depending on the
                                                                       stresses involved, viz. static and dynamic.
Dimensional Change
                                                                   •   By ADA specification no. 1, creep is limited to 3% in a
Small amount of contraction occurs in the first half an hour           set amalgam.
after trituration because mercury diffuses into the silver         •   Creep/flow usually occurs near the melting temperature
and tin and the mix dissolves in the mercury. After this,              of the material. In amalgam, creep happens because
expansion occurs because of crystallization of the new                 gamma 1 is a fine grained structure, also these particles
phases. According to ADA specification no. 1 dimensional               “slide” across each other resulting in slipping of grain
change should be limited to 20 microns/cm measured                     boundaries.
between 5 minutes and 24 hours after trituration.                  •   Creep is unfavorable to amalgam because it causes
                                                                       amalgam. To flow out over margins where the thin
Factors affecting Dimensional                                          amalgam fractures. This results in marginal deterioration.
Changes of Amalgam                                                 •   Factors affecting creep:
                                                                       – Low copper alloys have higher creep than high
•   Type of alloy being used, for example, single composi-
                                                                           copper alloys because in latter copper binds tin and
    tion spherical alloys contract more than single
                                                                           forms eta phase, and this prevents formation of
    composition lathe-cut or admixed alloys.
                                                                           gamma 2 phase. Crystals of eta phase interlock and
•   Condensation technique, i.e. more mercury removed                      check slippage at gamma 1 grain boundaries, resulting
    from the alloy, the more it will contract.                             in less creep.
•   Trituration time, overtrituration causes contraction.              – Higher the residual mercury levels, more is the creep.
•   Presence of zinc can result in delayed expansion after             – Increased condensation pressure reduces creep
    3-5 days of restoration, if during condensation or                     because it reduces residual mercury level.
    trituration, zinc-containing amalgam comes in contact              – Marginal areas show more creep because they have
    with moisture or saliva. This occurs due to formation                  higher levels of residual mercury.
    of zinc oxide and hydrogen gas when zinc react with                – A delay between trituration and condensation
    water. This expansion can result in extrusion of                       increases creep.
    restoration beyond preparation margins and pulpal pain.
                                                                   Corrosion
Strength
                                                                   •   Amalgam restoration shows corrosion and tarnish over
•   Strength of amalgam develops slowly. It takes 24 hours             a period of time. Though corrosion causes decrease in
    to reach maximum. In first hour, only 40 to 60% of its             strength of a restoration by 50% in five years, the
    maximum compressive strength is achieved.                          advantageous fact of corrosion is that the byproducts
•   According to ADA specification no. 1, amalgam                      that form, act to seal the preparation margin, responsible
    should have minimum 1 hour compressive strength of                 for self-sealing feature of amalgam (Fig. 9.2).
    11,600 psi (80 MPa).                                           •   In low copper amalgams, the most corrosion-prone
•   Amalgam has much higher compressive strength than                  phase is gamma 2 (Sn7-8Hg3) phase. In these alloys,
    tensile or shear strength making it brittle material.              corrosion products are tin oxides and tin chlorides. Here
•   Compressive strength of amalgam is seven times more                the corrosion proceeds from outer surface to interior of
    than that of its tensile strength. Being a brittle material,       restoration making it porous and spongy.
168
                                                                                                                      Biocompatibility
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                      Though there has been great debate related to mercury
                                                                                                                      toxicity, yet if careful handling of mercury is taken, amalgam
                                                                                                                      proves to be a biocompatible material.

                                                                                                                      Thermal Conductivity
                                                                                                                      Because of good thermal conductivity, amalgam can transmit
                                                                                                                      temperature changes readily to the pulp. Hence, its closeness
                                                                                                                      to pulp should be avoided without adequate pulp protection.

                                                                                                                      Coefficient of Thermal Expansion
                                                                                                                      It is three times more in amalgam than that of dentin. This
                                                                                                                      large difference is responsible for microleakage.

                                                                                                                      Microleakage in Amalgam
                                                                                                                      Microleakage occurs when there is 2 to 20 micron wide
                                                                                                                      gap between the amalgam and tooth structure.
                                                                                                                         Following factors are responsible for microleakage in
                                                                                                                      amalgam:
                                                                                                                      • Poor condensation techniques that cause marginal
                                                          Fig. 9.2: Sealing of restorative margins because               voids.
                                                                  of corrosion products of amalgam
                                                                                                                      • Lack of corrosion byproducts which are necessary for
                                                                                                                         sealing of margins.
                                                 •   In high copper amalgams, corrosion products are similar          • High coefficient of thermal expansion of amalgam.
                                                     to that of low copper alloys, in addition there is formation     • Use of single composition spherical alloys which show
                                                     of copper chloride which corrode slower than low                    more leakage than lathe-cut or admixed alloys.
                                                     copper amalgams. High copper alloys corrode slower               Microleakage can lead to (Figs 9.3A and B):
                                                     because they contain little or none of gamma 2 phase.            • Pulpal inflammation

RECENT ADVANCES IN AMALGAM                                        •   Increased retention




                                                                                                                                Dental Amalgam
                                                                  •   Conservative tooth preparation
Mercury-free Direct Filling Alloy                                 •   Improved marginal seal
The American Dental Association, in combination with              •   Elimination of use of retention pins and other modes of
National Institute on Standard and Technology (ADA-NIST)              retention.
has patented a mercury-free direct filling alloy which is         •   Reduction in microleakage, secondary caries and
based on Ag-coated Ag-Sn particles that can be self-welded            postoperative sensitivity.
by compaction to create a restoration. To keep the surface        •   Cost effective for extensively carious tooth
of alloy particles clean, a fluoroboric acid solution is used.    •   Can be done in single appointment.
These alloys can be condensed in the same manner as direct
filling gold restoration.                                         Limitations of Amalgam Bonding
                                                                  •   Reduction in bond strength over years because of
Low Mercury Alloy                                                     repeated thermocycling in the oral cavity.
In this approach, alloy particles are carefully selected so       •   Technique sensitive system, amalgam must be condensed
that they can pack together well. Then it is possible to reduce       over wet adhesive resin.
the mercury content for mixing to the 15-25% range.               •   Expensive than nonbonded amalgam restoration.
However, the clinical properties of these alloys are not yet
known.                                                            Technique of Bonded Amalgam
                                                                  Bonding agents used in amalgam bonding system:
Bonded Amalgam System                                             Although many products are available for adhesion to enamel
One of the major disadvantages of the amalgam is that it          and dentin, most of these are meant for use with resin
does not adhere to the preparation walls. To conquer this         composites. Some of them have metal bonding capabilities
problem, bonding systems to bond the amalgam to tooth             thus can be used for amalgam bonding. These are
structure have been developed. In the bonded amalgam              Amalgambond Plus with HPA (High Performance Additive)
technique, a dentin bonding system is used along with a           powder (Parkell), Optibond 2 (Kerr), All Bond 2 (Bisco),
viscous resin liner which physically mixes with the amalgam       Panavia EX and Panavia 21 (Kuraray).
and forms a micromechanical union to increase amalgam’s           Bonding interface (Figs 9.4 and 9.5): The bonding
retention to tooth structure.                                     interface constitutes tooth, amalgam and adhesive resin
    Since amalgam is hydrophobic, and tooth is hydrophilic,       present in between them.
therefore, to achieve optimal wetting, bonding systems must       The bonding interface may consist of the following:
have dual properties. For this monomer molecule having            1. Tag formation
hydrophilic and hydrophobic ends of 4-methyloxy ethyl             2. Precipitates on pretreated dentin surfaces to which
trimellitic anhydride (4-META) based systems are used.                adhesive resin binds mechanically or chemically.
                                                                  3. Formation of hybrid layer of reinforced dentin.
Indications of Bonding
•   When remaining tooth structure, after tooth preparation
    is weak.
•   In extensively carious posterior teeth where it acts as
    cost effective alternate for cast metal and metal ceramic
    restorations.
•   In cases with deep bite where short clinical crown is
    present, here pin-retained restorations are not possible.
    In these cases, bonding provides auxiliary retention.
•   As core for foundation of cast crown restoration.

Advantages of Using Bonded Amalgam System
•   Adequate dentin sealing                                               Fig. 9.4: Bonding interface of amalgam and tooth:
•   Increased resistance form                                                     Conventional amalgam restoration

                                                                                                                 has been tried in mercury-free amalgam restoration. Use of
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                 alternative containing gallium, instead of mercury, was first
                                                                                                                 suggested in 1928 in Germany.

                                                                                                                 Advantages of Gallium Amalgam
                                                                                                                 •    Gallium amalgam can be manipulated with same
                                                                                                                      instruments used for silver amalgam.
                                                                                                                 •    Its strength is almost equal to silver mercury amalgam,
                                                                                                                      and like latter its strength also increases with time.
                                                                                                                 •    The creep resistance complies with ISO requirements.
                                                                                                                 •    Since gallium amalgam expands after trituration, it
                                                                                                                      provides better marginal seal than silver amalgam.
                                                         Fig. 9.5: Bonding interface of amalgam and tooth        •    Setting time is less than silver mercury amalgam,
                                                                   in bonded amalgam restoration
                                                                                                                      therefore, can be finished and polished after one hour.
                                                 4. Chemical binding to the inorganic and organic                •    Most of the physical and mechanical properties of
                                                    components of dentin and enamel.                                  gallium alloy are similar to high copper mercury amalgam.

     occurs but if contaminated, uncontrolled expansion can
     result. This excessive expansion can cause cuspal            Selection of Amalgam Alloy
     fracture, and postoperative sensitivity.                     Following factors are considered while selecting an alloy
•    Creep value: In gallium alloys, creep value is less.         for restoration:
•    Gallium amalgam has very high wetting ability, hence         a. Type of alloy:
     the final restoration is highly resistant to microleakage.       • High copper or low copper alloys
•    Time consuming: Since their handling is difficult                • Zinc-free or zinc-containing alloys
     because of being sticky, it takes more time for                  • Size and shape of the particles.
     condensation and matrix band has to be removed very          b. If restoration undergoes high occlusal stresses, choose
     carefully to avoid fracture of restoration.                      amalgam with high resistance to marginal fracture.
•    Costly: Gallium amalgam is about 16 times costlier than      c. Patients with psychological problems or other diseases,
     the silver mercury amalgam.                                      requiring early disposal, indicate the use of fast setting
                                                                      alloy.

                                                                      values is preferred.

acid solution for keeping the surface of silver alloy particles
clean. The alloy is condensed in the preparation similar to       Trituration
direct filling gold. The main limitation of using this material   The purpose of trituration is to remove oxide layers from
is that alloy hardens due to repeated burnishing. This makes      the alloy particles so as to coat each alloy particle with
it difficult to compact in preparation. For good adaptation       mercury, resulting in a homogeneous mass for condensation.
of material and to avoid voids in the final restoration, an       Trituration can be done by hand or mechanical means.
excessive force is required for compaction.                       Mechanical method is done with the help of automatic

     1. Selection of amalgam alloy
     2. Mercury alloy ratio                                                          Objectives of trituration
     3. Trituration                                                1. Achieve a workable mass of amalgam within minimum
     4. Mulling                                                       time

Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                        Fig. 9.6: Amalgamator used for mechanical trituration                Fig. 9.7: Mortar pestle used for hand trituration



                                                     Time for which the trituration is carried out, speed and
                                                 force applied for trituration, affect the quality of trituration.
                                                     Sign of a good mix amalgam is shiny, homogeneous
                                                 mass that adheres together (Fig. 9.8). Undertrituration
                                                 results in a crumbly mix that is very weak (Fig. 9.9). It
                                                 causes decrease in the tensile and compressive strength
                                                 values and increase in creep.
                                                     Overtrituration results in a mix that is warm and has a
                                                 shiny surface. This overtriturated mix sticks to the capsule
                                                 which is difficult to remove (Fig. 9.10). There occurs fast
                                                 setting because the amalgam mass becomes heated.



                                                                                                                     Fig. 9.9: Undertriturated amalgam mix appears dry and crumbled




                                                         Fig. 9.8: Properly mixed amalgam should be shiny,                  Fig. 9.10: Overtriturated mix sticks to be capsule
                                                                    cohesive homogeneous mass                                          which is difficult to remove
                                                                                                                                 173
Overtrituration causes increase in contraction, creep, tensile




                                                                                                                                 Dental Amalgam
and compressive strength values for lathe-cut alloys,
decrease in tensile and compressive strengths for spherical
alloys.

                     Test for trituration
 1. Normal trituration
    • Good shiny mix
    • Homogeneous mass, adheres together
 2. Overtrituration
    • Mix is ‘warm’
    • Difficult to remove from capsule
    • Shiny wet and soft
 3. Undertrituration
    • Dry mix
    • Crumbled mix that is very weak

Mulling
Mulling is done so that all alloy particles are properly coated
with mercury, in other words it is continuation of the
trituration. Mulling of the amalgam can be done manually
or mechanically. By hand, it can be done by squeezing the
freshly mixed amalgam collected in the chamois skin. Mulling
should not be done by bare hands as it can be contaminated
by moisture. Mechanical mulling is done in the amalgamator
by triturating it for one to two seconds.

Application of Matrix Band
Placing a matrix for an amalgam restoration allows the dentist
to insert restoration without exceeding the limits of the                Figs 9.12A and B: (A) Class I preparation in 46, 47
                                                                            (B) Insertion of amalgam into the preparation
normal tooth structure. Place the matrix band in the matrix
retainer. Pass the matrix band between the contact points
so that its lower edge comes just over the cervical margin        the band because this will flex the cusps, resulting in
of the preparation. Tighten the band and stabilize it using       postrestoration sensitivity, and failure of the restoration.
wedges (Fig. 9.11). It is very important not to overtighten       Finally, burnish the contact area of the band against the
                                                                  adjacent tooth.

                                                                  Insertion of Amalgam (Figs 9.12A and B)
                                                                  Pick a small amount of amalgam alloy with the help of
                                                                  amalgam carrier and transfer it to the preparation. Proximal
                                                                  box should be filled before the occlusal part of the
                                                                  preparation.
                                                                      Place the first increment of amalgam in the deepest
                                                                  proximal part of the preparation and condense it with flat
                                                                  surface of condenser.
                                                                      Apply firm pressure on the amalgam mass for adequate
                                                                  condensation. After it, add next increment and again
                                                                  condense it.
                                                                      When the level of amalgam reaches the preparation
                                                                  margins, continue the packing of preparation to allow an
            Fig. 9.11: Placement of band and wedge                excess to build up for better finishing.

                                                 Condensation                                                         •       Type of alloy: Use larger condensers when condensing
                                                                                                                              spherical alloys because smaller condenser will displace
                                                 Various shapes (triangular, round, elliptical, trapezoidal and
                                                                                                                              the spherical particles rather than condensing them.
                                                 rectangular) and sizes of condensers are used for amalgam
                                                 condensation. Working end of a condenser is usually                                 Choice of condenser depending upon
                                                 serrated (Figs 9.13A and B) since the force delivered to                          type of amalgam alloy (Figs 9.14A and B)
                                                 the amalgam depends upon the area of condensing tips and                      Type of alloy                Type of condenser
                                                 selection of condenser depends on the outline form of tooth
                                                                                                                          •    Lathe-cut alloy              Small condenser
                                                 preparation.                                                             •    Blended alloy                Small condenser
                                                                                                                          •    Spherical alloy              Large condenser
                                                 Rules of Condensation
                                                 •       Start condensation within three minutes of trituration.      Burnishing
                                                 •       Condense continuously.                                       Precarve burnishing is done after condensation. It is the
                                                 •       Condense laterally as well as apically.                      process of rubbing, generally done to make the surface
                                                 •       Apply adequate force for condensation.
                                                 •       Have a constant supply of amalgam.

                                                                     Objectives of condensation
                                                     •    Brings excess mercury on the surface of restoration
                                                     •    Reduces the number and size of voids in the restoration
                                                     •    Prepares the surface of restoration for carving
                                                     •    Adapts amalgam to the preparation walls and floors.


                                                 Condensation Depends upon Following Factors
                                                 •       Plasticity of the mass.
                                                 •       Size of the amalgam increment: A larger mass results
                                                         in incomplete condensation.
                                                 •       Condenser size: The smaller the condenser working end,
                                                         the greater the force.
                                                 •       Direction of force.                                                             Fig. 9.14A: (A) Condensation of
                                                 •       Amount of force.                                                             nonspherical alloy using small condenser
                                                                                                                                  175
                                                                   Advantages of Postcarve Burnishing




                                                                                                                                  Dental Amalgam
                                                                   •   Reduces number of voids on surface of restoration.
                                                                   •   Produces denser amalgam at margins.
                                                                   •   Improves marginal seal.
                                                                   •   Increases surface hardness.
                                                                   •   Decreases rate of corrosion.

                                                                   Carving
                                                                   Objectives of carving are to achieve restoration with:
                                                                   1. No over-and under-hangs
                                                                   2. Proper size, location and good interproximal contact
                                                                   3. Adequate marginal ridges
                                                                   4. Proper contours
                                                                   5. Optimal occlusal anatomy
         Fig. 9.14B: (B) Condensation of spherical alloy           6. Adequate embrasures
                      with large condenser                         7. Enhancing the health of periodontium
                                                                       Amalgam should not be carved until it is sufficiently
shiny. Amalgam is overfilled and burnished immediately with        firm. For adequate carving, it is preferable to overpack the
heavy strokes so as to improve marginal adaptability of the        preparation and then carve it to the margins. Carving causes
restoration and remove excess mercury from overpacked              removal of mercury-rich surface layer. For proper carving,
amalgam (Fig. 9.15).                                               occlusal anatomy should be kept low to preserve bulk of
                                                                   the alloy at the margins. The carving instruments should
Advantages of Precarve Burnishing                                  have discoid and cleiod blade design (Fig. 9.16). Larger
1. Improves the marginal integrity of restoration.                 instrument is used first, followed by smaller instruments.
2. Shapes the restoration according to contours and                    In proximal tooth preparation, carving of the cervical
   curvatures of the tooth.                                        margins should begin following the removal of matrix band.
3. Helps in reducing the mercuric content of amalgam.              Loosen the band and then wedge before carving because
                                                                   axial and cervical margins become accessible after removal
Postcarve Burnishing                                               of band.

It is done after completion of carving with the help of small-
sized burnishers using light strokes.

                                                     Trim the axial margins towards the gingiva in downward
                                                 direction with a sharp carver (Fig. 9.17). Do not overcarve
                                                 amalgam as it can lead to acute angles and stress
                                                 concentration within the amalgam which can fracture the
                                                 restoration (Fig. 9.18).
                                                     Carve the occlusal surface with a sharp carver like
                                                 hollenback. Hold it in a way so that its blade lies across the
                                                 margin of the restoration, half on tooth and half on restoration
                                                 (Fig. 9.19). Define marginal ridge and occlusal embrasure
                                                 using a sharp explorer (Fig. 9.20). Remove any overhanging
                                                 margins in the interdental region, if present.
                                                     During carving, movement of instrument should be
                                                 parallel to the margin and edge of blade should be
                                                                                                                    Fig. 9.20: Sharp explorer is used to define marginal ridge
                                                 perpendicular to the margins, to avoid ditching of the metal
                                                 and to minimize the overlay (Figs 9.21A and B).

                                                                   cause fracture of restoration                                     Ditching of restoration

                                                                    appearance. It helps in reducing the surface roughness




                                                                                                                                        Dental Amalgam
                                                                    produced by carving. In high copper amalgam restoration
                                                                    postcarve burnishing has no significant effect on the clinical
                                                                    performance but in low copper amalgam, postcarve
                                                                    burnishing produces denser amalgam at the margins.

                                                                    Finishing and Polishing
                                                                    Finishing amalgam restorations involves removal of marginal
                                                                    irregularities, defining anatomical contours, and smoothening
                                                                    the surface roughness of the restoration. Polishing is done
                                                                    to achieve a smooth, shiny luster on the surface of the
                                                                    amalgam. Finishing is done before polishing by use of abrasive
                                                                    agents that are coarse enough to remove the bulk from the
                                                                    surface. Polishing requires mildly abrasive materials for
            Fig. 9.21B: Improper carving can result in              producing smooth and shiny surface of amalgam restoration.
                 restoration overlay and fracture
                                                                        Finishing and polishing of the restorations should be
                                                                    done at least 24 hours after the placement of the amalgam.
Checking the Contact Points                                         Premature finishing and polishing will interfere with the
Check the integrity of contact points using dental floss            crystalline structure of the hardening amalgam. The result
by passing it buccally, palatally and gingivally (Figs 9.22A        will be a weakened restoration. Polishing may not be essential
to C).                                                              for restorations with high-copper alloys because they have
                                                                    a tendency of self-polishing.

                          occlusal embrasure form (C) Too high contact and improper occlusal embrasure form
178
                                                 •   Maintenance of periodontal health.
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 •   Prevention of occlusal problems.
                                                     One of the most important precautions to be taken while
                                                 doing finishing and polishing is the minimization of heat
                                                 production. Heat generated during the polishing procedure
                                                 is potentially dangerous because:
                                                 • It can cause thermal damage to the pulp.
                                                 • Heat brings the mercury to the surface of the restoration
                                                     resulting in a dull, cloudy surface, and makes it more
                                                     susceptible to corrosion.

                                                 To Minimize Heat Production
                                                 1. Use light, intermittent pressure with rotary instruments.
                                                 2. Use slow speed with rotary instruments.
                                                 3. Use abrasive agents that are wet rather than dry.
                                                                                                                                 Fig. 9.23: Final polishing of amalgam
                                                     The most commonly rotary instruments used are abrasive                       restoration using abrasive stones
                                                 stones, disks and finishing burs available in different shapes,
                                                 sizes, degrees of abrasiveness, and in either high-speed or
                                                 slow speed. Pumice and tin oxide are two commonly used            •   Rinse and clean out all debris completely.
                                                 polishing agents. Pumice is usually mixed with water to           •   Evaluate all margins and surfaces of the restoration (Fig.
                                                 decrease the heat produced by the friction of the abrasive            9.24).
                                                 particles during polishing. Tin oxide or amalgloss is used as         A polished amalgam restoration should have following
                                                 the finest abrasive agent. It can be used in a slurry, dry, or    features:
                                                 both forms.                                                       • Surface is smooth with no scratches or graininess.
                                                                                                                   • Surface is lustrous, with a mirror-like shine.
                                                 Steps for Finishing and Polishing of Amalgam                      • There is no break between margins and the tooth surface.
                                                                                                                   • Restoration has proper contact and contour.
                                                 •   Using an explorer, evaluate the cavosurface margins for
                                                                                                                   • There is no damage to the restoration or adjacent tooth
                                                     marginal integrity.
                                                                                                                       structure.
                                                 •   Determine the presence of any marginal discrepancies
                                                     and evaluate the contour of the restoration.
                                                                                                                   FAILURES OF AMALGAM RESTORATIONS
                                                 •   Identify the occlusal pattern. Mark the occlusal contacts
                                                     in centric occlusion and excursive movements. Areas           Since 1860, amalgam has been the most widely used
                                                     that need to be reduced are identified by darker markings     restorative material in posterior teeth. But after 1970 because
                                                     on the restoration. Establish proper occlusion by             of development of newer restorative materials and mercury
                                                     grinding.                                                     toxicity, its use has been limited.
                                                 •   Smoothen the margins by using a round bur moving it
                                                     along all cavosurface margins. This procedure is done
                                                     to blend the tooth structure to amalgam.
                                                 •   Use a large round finishing bur to eliminate scratches
                                                     and graininess from the amalgam.
                                                 •   Using the side of the finishing bur, smoothen the occlusal
                                                     surface and marginal ridges. Move the bur mesiodistally,
                                                     overlapping each stroke, then do the same in a bucco-
                                                     lingual direction.
                                                 •   Use a finishing strip for smoothening and polishing of
                                                     the gingival cavosurface margins and interproximal
                                                     space.
                                                 •   Smoothen the facial and lingual surfaces with finishing
                                                     disks.
                                                 •   Finally polish the surface by using progressively finer
                                                     abrasive agents (Fig. 9.23).                                              Fig. 9.24: Completed amalgam restoration

                                                                      more than two-thirds of the intercuspal distance. Though
Reasons for Failure of Amalgam Restorations                           for cusp capping, only cast restoration is preferred. If
                                                                      amalgam is to be used for capping, it should be at least
      The reasons for failure of amalgam restorations                 2 mm thick over the functional cusp and 1.5 mm over

                                                                      nonfunctional cusp to prevent its fracture over the cusps

                                                                      for restoration acts as a wedge, which can result in

Defective Tooth Preparation                                           formation. They should be removed properly.

• Inadequate occlusal extension: Insufficient extension               sharp axiopulpal line angle because of concentration of
    to include adjacent deep pits and fissures increases              stresses in that area. So these angles should be rounded.

                                                                                                                     margins, tarnish, and corrosion.

                                                                                                                     during polishing may result in pulpal trauma. Heavy pressure
