MERCURY HYGIENE                                                      3. Organic mercury




                                                                                                                                   Dental Amalgam
                                                                        • Mainly in the form of methyl mercury
Mercury has been used in dentistry from a very long time.
                                                                        • Main route of entry is absorption through GIT
It is considered as major component in amalgam restorations
                                                                           (95-98%) through food
and also used in medicines such as skin, antibacterial ointment
                                                                        • Used in fungicide and pesticide
and laxatives.
                                                                        • Found in vegetables, fruits and grains
     Mercury has been considered to be hazardous if not
                                                                        • Toxic in nature
managed properly. Mercury vapors present in the dental
office are toxic if they cross the threshold limit. So,
                                                                     Mercury Exposure in Dental Office
management of free mercury is very important.
                                                                     In the dental office, mercury exposure can occur from the
History of Conflicts regarding Amalgam Use                           following sources (Fig. 9.26):
                                                                     1. Storage of amalgam raw materials for use.
1920      (First Amalgam war)—War between the dentists
                                                                     2. Mixed but unset amalgam during trituration, insertion
          using gold foil and dental amalgam.
                                                                         and intraoral hardening.
1980 Dr Hal Huggins—Amalgam responsible for cardio-
                                                                     3. Amalgam scrap containing insufficient alloy for
          vascular and nervous problem.
                                                                         consuming mercury completely.
1991 NIH–NIDR and FDA—National Institute of Health–
                                                                     4. Finishing and polishing of restoration.
          National Institute for Dental Research. Several
                                                                     5. Removal of old restoration.
          experts concluded that amalgam is not considered
          as a significant health hazard.
                                                                     Steps to Reduce Mercury
    Mercury is present in the environment which is taken
                                                                     Exposure in the Dental Clinic
into the body through water, air and food, daily in one or
another form.                                                        1. Storage of mercury: Storage of mercury is considered
    The mercury usually enters into the body every day no               difficult because it:
matter what type of restorative filling is present in oral cavity.      • Is very mobile
Very low amount of mercury is usually released from set                 • Has high diffusion rate
amalgam as compared to daily intake.                                    • Can penetrate extremely fine spaces
    It has been found that health hazards from the amalgam              Therefore, one should take care while storage of mercury
use are mainly to dental and its associated staff in dental             is concerned.
office than patient because of the long-term contact with               a. Precapsulated alloys should be preferred for avoiding
mercury usage.                                                              mercury spill
                                                                        b. If bulk mercury is purchased, store it in tight
Forms of Mercury                                                            container with tight lid in closed cabinets.
                                                                        c. Location of storage should be near the window/
Exists in three chemical forms:
                                                                            exhaust vent.
1. Elemental mercury
                                                                     2. Trituration of amalgam
   • Most volatile
                                                                        a. Use precapsulated alloy in amalgamator
   • Exist in liquid/vapor form
                                                                        b. Avoid manual mixing
   • Inhaled and absorbed into lungs (80%) and GIT
        (0.01%)
   • Most common form of entry in human body during
        amalgam restoration
   • Exposure to this form can occur due to accidental
        spillage of mercury in dental office.
2. Inorganic mercury
   • Normally mined as inorganic sulfide ore
   • Mainly in liquid form
   • Can also exist in other forms than sulfides
   • Potentially toxic
   • Irritating in nature
   • Main route of entry is through lungs (80%).                            Fig. 9.26: Sources of mercury in oral environment

                                                                                                                            183
                                                                                 Levels of Hg toxicity




                                                                                                                            Dental Amalgam
                                                               a. At level of 4 µg: This level is attributed as the upper
                                                                  limit in urine when extensive restoration of amalgam is
                                                                  present in patient’s mouth
                                                               b. At level 0-25 µg: No known health hazards are detected
                                                               c. At level 25-100 µg: Decreased response on tests done
                                                                  for brain conduction. Decreased response related to
                                                                  verbal skills
                                                               d. 100-500 µg: Mild-to-moderate effects can be seen:
                                                                  a. Irritability          b. Memory loss
                                                                  c. Depression            d. Tremors
                                                                  e. Nervous system disturbances
                                                               e. 500-1,000 µg: Pronounced symptoms
                                                                  • Inflammation of kidney
                                                                  • Tremors and pronounced nervous system distur-
                                                                       bances
                                                                  • Swollen gums

                                                              STEPS OF AMALGAM RESTORATION




TOOTH PREPARATION FOR CLASS I                                 1. Initial Tooth Preparation
AMALGAM RESTORATION
                                                              Outline Form
Class I: Pit and fissure preparations occur on the occlusal
                                                              The outline form means extending the preparation margins
surfaces of premolars and molars, the occlusal two-third
                                                              to the place they will occupy in the final preparation.
of buccal and lingual surface of molars, lingual surface of
                                                              Following facts, must be kept in mind while making outline
incisors and any other abnormal position.                     form:
                                                              • Removal of all carious and defective pits and fissures to
The basic principles of tooth preparation are as follows:         healthy tooth structure.
1. Initial tooth preparation:                                 • Removal of all unsupported enamel rods
   • Outline form                                             • To avoid ending preparation margins in high stress areas
   • Primary resistance form                                      like cusp tip and crest of the ridges.
   • Primary retention form                                   • Placing margins on sound tooth structure.
   • Convenience form                                         Steps
2. Final tooth preparation:                                   • With the help of no. 245 bur, establish the external
   • Management of remaining caries                              outline form to extend all margins into sound tooth tissue.
   • Secondary resistance and retention form                  • Bur should be kept parallel to long axis of the tooth to
   • Pulp protection, if required                                make a ditch in the carious portion of the tooth and it
   • Finishing of enamel margins                                 should be rotating when applied to the tooth and should
   • Final inspection of the preparation                         not stop rotating until removed.

Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                       Fig. 10.1: Initial depth of 1.5 mm should be maintained
                                                                      while preparing outline form



                                                 •   Maintain the initial depth of 1.5 mm, this is approxi-
                                                     mately one-half the length of the cutting bur. This should
                                                     be, at least 0.2 to 0.5 mm in dentin to provide adequate           Fig. 10.3: Sometimes slight divergence of mesial and distal wall is
                                                     strength to resist fracture due to occlusal forces (Fig.                 done so as to have dentinal support of marginal ridges
                                                     10.1). While maintaining the same depth and bur
                                                     orientation, move the bur to extend the outline to include     •     While working towards mesial and distal surface, orient
                                                     the central fissure. The margins of preparation not only             the bur towards respective marginal ridge. This will result
                                                     extend into sound tooth tissue but also involve adjacent             in slight divergence of mesial and distal walls which
                                                     deep pits and fissures in the preparation.                           helps to provide dentinal support for marginal ridges
                                                 •   Extend the margin mesially and distally but do not                   (Fig. 10.3).
                                                     involve marginal ridges. These walls should have               •     The isthmus width should be as narrow as possible, it
                                                                                                                          should not be wider than the intercuspal distance.
                                                     dovetail shape to provide retention to the restoration (Figs
                                                                                                                    •     The deep pit and fissure defects less than 0.5 mm apart
                                                     10.2A and B).
                                                                                                                          should be included within the outline form.
                                                                                                                    •     The external outline form should have smooth curves,
                                                                                                                          straight lines and rounded angles. All unsupported and
                                                                                                                          demineralized enamel should be removed.
                                                                                                                    •     Enameloplasty is the careful removal of sharp and
                                                                                                                          irregular enamel margins by “rounding” or “saucering”
                                                                                                                          it and forming a easily cleansable area. The enamelo-
                                                                                                                          plasty should not extend the outline form. The use of
                                                                                                                          enamelo-plasty should be done in ends of fissures
                                                                                                                          whenever needed.

                                                                                                                    Primary Resistance Form
                                                                                                                    Resistance form is that shape given to a preparation planned
                                                                                                                    to afford such a seat for the restoration so as to best enable
                                                                                                                    it to withstand the occlusal stresses. Primary resistance form
                                                                                                                    should have following features:
                                                                                                                    • Shape of the preparation should be like a box with flat
                                                                                                                         floor (Fig. 10.4). This helps the tooth to resist occlusal
                                                                                                                         masticatory forces without any displacement. Though
                                                          Figs 10.2A and B: (A) Sufficient marginal ridge,               it should be flat, at the same time it should follow the
                                                          (B) Overcutting of marginal ridge causes thinning              contour of occlusal surface (Fig. 10.5).
                                                                                                                                           187




                                                                                                                                           Tooth Preparation for Amalgam Restoration
    Fig. 10.4: Box shaped preparation to provide resistance form          Fig. 10.6: Amalgam-tooth interface should have butt joint


•   To provide adequate thickness of amalgam keep the
    minimum occlusal depth of 1.5 mm.
•   Provide the cavosurface angle of 90° (Fig. 10.6).
•   Restrict the extension of external walls so as to have
    strong marginal ridge areas with sufficient dentin
    support.
•   Include all the weakened tooth structure.
•   Round off all the internal line and point angles
    (Figs 10.7A and B).
•   Consider capping of cusp for preserving cuspal strength.

Primary Retention Form
                                                                      A                                 B
Primary retention form prevents the restoration from being
displaced.                                                           Figs 10.7A and B: Internal angles of preparation should be round;
                                                                     (A) Sharp angles lead to stress concentration, (B) Rounded internal
Retention can be increased by the following:                         angle
• Occlusal convergence (about 2 to 5%) of buccal and
   lingual walls (Fig. 10.8).
• Giving slight undercut in dentin near the pulpal wall (Figs
   10.9A and B).

                                                 •   Conserving the marginal ridges.

                                                                                                                      Protection of Pulp if Needed
                                                 Convenience Form                                                     Use of pulp protective materials depends upon following
                                                 The convenience form of the preparation facilitates and              factors:
                                                 provides sufficient visibility, accessibility and ease of            • A base is not needed in shallow preparations, as it
                                                 operation in preparation and restoration of the tooth. For               compromises thickness and thus compressive strength
                                                 amalgam restoration, it is the form or shape that also permits           of amalgam.
                                                 access of condensing and carving instruments.                        • In a deep preparation, a base is placed on the deepest
                                                                                                                          part in the thickness of 0.5 to 0.75 mm, so as to protect
                                                 2. Final Tooth Preparation                                               pulp (Fig. 10.12).
                                                                                                                          Be sure that no trace of the base material remains on
                                                 Removal of Remaining Carious Dentin
                                                                                                                      enamel walls of preparation (Fig. 10.13), as this would
                                                 In this, remaining caries, old restorative material and adjacent     eventually dissolve in the oral fluids leaving a gap between
                                                 deep pits and fissures are also removed and involved in the          the restoration and the tooth resulting in microleakage and
                                                 preparation.                                                         recurrent caries.
                                                     In the large preparations with soft caries, the removal of           The selection of bases for amalgam restorations are
                                                 carious dentin is done with spoon excavator or slow speed            based on two factors:
                                                 round bur (Figs 10.10A and B). In this, two-step pulpal              • It should have sufficient strength to support the forces
                                                 floor is made, i.e. only portion of tooth which is affected by           of amalgam condensation
                                                 caries is removed, leaving the remaining, floor untouched            • It should be able to strengthen the restoration under
                                                 (Figs 10.11A to C).                                                      masticatory stresses.




                                                                      Figs 10.11A to C: (A) Caries present beyond tooth preparation, (B) Overpreparation of tooth in
                                                                              an attempt to involve caries, (C) Stepped pulpal floor to involve carious lesion
                                                                                                                                                   189




                                                                                                                                                   Tooth Preparation for Amalgam Restoration
                                                                         Fig. 10.14: Conservative tooth preparation on occlusal surface of
         Fig. 10.12: In deep preparations, base is applied                   maxillary first molar showing preservation of oblique ridge
                on pulpal floor so as to protect pulp


    The strength of the bases depends upon the size,
thickness and mechanical properties of base along with
preparation design, position and amount of occlusal load.

Finishing of the Enamel Walls and Margins
Finishing of walls and margins is guided by the knowledge
of dental histology. At this stage all unsupported enamel is
removed. Cavosurface angle, i.e. angle between enamel wall
and amalgam interface should be made 90° butt joint type.
This provides bulk to restoration, which in turn provides
maximum strength.

Final Cleaning and Inspection of the Preparation
The final stage of tooth preparation is to clean the pre-                           Fig. 10.15: Conventional tooth preparation of
paration thoroughly with water and air spray. Then dry it                            maxillary first molar involving oblique ridge

with moist air and inspect it for final approval.

Tooth Preparation on Occlusal Surface of
Different Teeth (Figs 10.14 to 10.16)

                                                 CLASS II TOOTH PREPARATION FOR
                                                                                                                   • Give slight occlusal convergence to facial, lingual and
                                                 AMALGAM RESTORATION
                                                                                                                       proximal walls (in caries free side), this provides
                                                 Class II restoration involves the proximal (mesial or distal)         favorable retention for amalgam.
                                                 surfaces of premolars and molars.
                                                     Class II preparation is initiated same as Class I
                                                 preparation, i.e. entrance through occlusal surface.
                                                     Outline of proximal preparations is controlled by the
                                                 following factors:
                                                 • Caries susceptibility of the patient.
                                                 • Age of the patient.
                                                 • Position of gingiva
                                                 • Extent of the caries on the proximal side.
                                                 • Dimensions of the contact area
                                                 • Masticatory forces.
                                                 • Esthetic requirement of the patient.
                                                 Outline form: The outline form for occlusal portion follows                    Fig. 10.19: Make the occlusal box with
                                                 the same principles as given for pit and fissure lesions except                    the uniform depth of pulpal floor
                                                                                                                                         191




                                                                                                                                         Tooth Preparation for Amalgam Restoration
                                                                                  Fig. 10.21: Proximal cutting should
                                                                                    be sufficiently deep into dentin



        Fig. 10.20: Extend the preparation ending short by
             0.8 mm of cutting through marginal ridge


•   Consider enameloplasty wherever required to conserve
    tooth structure.
•   Visualize the proximal box relative to contact area before
    extending into proximal marginal ridge, this will prevent
    the over extension of the occlusal outline form.
•   Outline form in the proximal area is primarily determined
    by the faciolingual position of the contact area and the
    extent of carious lesion. External outline form on the
    occlusal portion is extended to just break contact with
    the adjacent tooth.
•   While maintaining the established pulpal depth and with            Fig. 10.22: Faciolingual dimension of proximal box are
    the bur held parallel to the long axis of the tooth, extend               more at gingival surface than at occlusal
    the preparation towards the contact area of the tooth,
    ending short by 0.8 mm of cutting through the marginal
    ridge (Fig. 10.20). The proximal cutting is sufficiently
    deep into the dentin (0.5-0.6 mm) so that retentive locks
    are prepared into axiolingual and axiofacial line angles
    (Fig. 10.21).
•   Widen the preparation faciolingually to just clear the
    contact areas. The proximal cut is diverged gingivally.
    In other words, faciolingual dimension at the gingival
    surface is greater than the occlusal surface, this provides
    good retention and conservation of marginal ridge
    (Fig.10.22).
•   Keep a small slice of enamel at the contact area to prevent
    accidental damage to the adjacent tooth (Fig. 10.23). If
    there is any doubt that accidental damage to the adjacent
    tooth can occur, use a metal matrix band interdentally.       Fig. 10.23: A small slice of enamel is kept at contact area so as to
    This will offer some protection to the adjacent tooth.                    prevent accident damage to adjacent tooth

                                                     area with a small chisel or enamel hatchet.                                  walls by curving them towards the contact area
                                                 • Proximal margins should have a cavosurface angle of
                                                     90° and when completed, the walls of the proximal box              for elimination of caries and breaking proximal contacts.
                                                     should converge occlusally (Fig. 10.24).                           But in teeth with broader contacts, reverse-S shape curve is
                                                 • It is important to conserve the tooth tissue so that the             given to both widen the box yet remove less tooth structure.
                                                     tooth remains as strong as possible and occlusal forces            Reverse curve is given to the proximal walls by curving
                                                     placed on the amalgam are as small as possible.                    them inwards towards the contact area (Fig. 10.26). If
                                                 • Ideal clearance of facial and lingual margins of the                 excessive flare is given in these teeth, proximal walls will
                                                     proximal box should be 0.2 to 0.5 mm from the adjacent             end past the axial angle of tooth through the cusps resulting
                                                     tooth (Fig. 10.25).                                                in weakening of tooth structure and fracture of restoration.
                                                     The directions of the buccal and lingual proximal walls            Reverse curve has following advantages:
                                                 are affected by morphology of tooth, anatomy and relation-             • Conserves the sound tooth structure.
                                                 ship with the adjacent tooth.                                          • Preserves the triangular ridge of the affected cusp.
                                                     In this buccal and lingual proximal margins are extended:          • Flare of the proximal wall leaves the tangent to that outer
                                                 1. To include all the defects                                              tooth surface at 90° angle, this causes further increase
                                                                                                                            in resistance for both tooth and restoration.
                                                 2. To break contact with the adjacent tooth so to provide
                                                     convenience form and accessibility.
                                                                                                                        Primary Resistance Form
                                                 Reverse Curve                                                          This can be obtained by incorporating following features in
                                                                                                                        the preparation:
                                                 In the preparation of a class II amalgam restoration,                  • Shape of the preparation like a box with flat pulpal and
                                                 extension of the preparation in the proximal area is important             gingival floor.
                                                                                                                        • Cavosurface angle of 90°.
                                                                                                                        • Include all the weakened tooth structure.
                                                                                                                        • Maintain minimal width of the preparation so as to
                                                                                                                            preserve tooth structure.
                                                                                                                        • Round off all the internal line and point angles.
                                                                                                                        • Consider capping of cusp for preserving cuspal strength.

                                                                                                                        Primary Retention Form
                                                                                                                        Primary retention form prevents the restoration from being
                                                                                                                        displaced.
                                                                                                                        Retention can be increased by the following:
                                                                                                                        • Occlusal convergence (about 2 to 5%) of buccal and

with minimum facial and lingual extensions. For retention,
                                                                     fissure is emanating from occlusal surface, dovetail is not
converge facial and lingual extensions. Proximal retention
                                                                     required.
locks are made for added retention in proximal box. These
have 0.5 mm depth gingivally and 0.3 mm occlusally.

                                                 seat is planned for partial denture. For abutment teeth, facial
                                                 and lingual walls are extended more for providing space
                                                 rest seat (Fig. 10.41). Also pulpal floor is deepened 0.5 mm

CLASS III TOOTH PREPARATION FOR




                                                                                                                                       Tooth Preparation for Amalgam Restoration
AMALGAM RESTORATION
Since amalgam is not esthetic restoration, it is not indicated
for proximal surface of incisors and mesial surface of
canines. Amalgam for class III restoration is indicated in
the distal surface of maxillary and mandibular canines
especially, if:
• Caries do not undermine distal slopes of canines.
• Labial axial angle is intact.
• Even after removal of caries, sufficient tooth structure
    is present.
• Restoration will not be directly loaded with occlusal
    forces.

Initial Tooth Preparation                                                      Fig. 10.44: Outline of class III preparation

•   Outline form includes only the proximal surface. Shape
    of preparation is like a triangle with round corners. Labial       later is indicated when lingual embrasure is not sufficiently
    side of triangle conforms more to the anatomy than with            wide to aid instrumentation.
    lingual side.
•   A no. 2 round bur is penetrated through enamel on              Final Tooth Preparation
    distolingual marginal ridge (Fig. 10.43). Preliminary          •   Removal of any remaining infected dentin is done
    shaping of preparation is completed with inverted cone             using a slow speed round bur or/and spoon excavator.
    bur with long axis of bur keeping perpendicular to the         •   Pulp protection is by using base or liner.
    lingual surface of the tooth.                                  •   Secondary resistance and retention form is achieved
•   Outline form is completed when facial, gingival and                by butt joint, rounded internal angles and sufficient bulk
    lingual walls are formed (Fig. 10.44).                             of amalgam. Retention is obtained by placing retention
•   Lingual wall should meet the axial wall at obtuse angle.           groove with a small round bur in the axiofaciogingival
•   Depth of bur should be 0.5 mm into the dentin.                     point angle and lingual dovetail (Fig. 10.45). Lingual
•   Cavosurface angle should be about 90° at all margins.              dovetail is not required for small sized class III
•   Lingual margins should be in confines of lingual                   preparation. It is needed for large preparations. Lingual
    embrasure except for incisal and gingival turn extension,          dovetail is prepared only when the preparation of

CLASS VI TOOTH PREPARATION FOR
                                                                  •   Patients with psychological problems or other diseases,
AMALGAM RESTORATION
                                                                      requiring early disposal, indicate the use of fast setting
Class VI tooth preparation involves restoration of incisal            alloy.
edge of anterior teeth or the cusp tip of posterior teeth. For    •   In wider and broader preparations, alloy with low creep
class VI preparations in anterior teeth, amalgam is usually           values is preferred.
not filled because of poor esthetics. For posterior teeth it is
indicated because of its satisfactory wear resistance.            Mercury-Alloy Ratio
    Indications of restoration of class VI lesions with           Mercury is basically required to wet the alloy particles before
amalgam:                                                          they can react. Eames has preferred 1:1 ratio of alloy/
• In teeth where because of too much wear, enamel is              mercury for best results. Lathecut amalgam alloys require
    gone and the underlying dentin has become carious,            more (45%) of mercury to wet than the spherical alloys
    commonly seen in geriatric patients.                          (40%).
• In the hypoplastic cusp tip as these are more prone to
    caries.                                                       Trituration
                                                                  The purpose of trituration is to remove oxide layers from
Steps of Tooth Preparation (Fig. 10.49)
                                                                  the alloy particles so as to coat each alloy particle with
•   Penetrate the enamel with a small tapered fissure bur         mercury, resulting in a homogeneous mass for condensation.
    extending to the depth of 1.5 mm.                             Trituration can be done by hand or mechanical means. Signs
•   Prepare a 90° cavosurface margin on enamel.                   of a good mix amalgam is shiny, homogeneous mass that
•   Make small undercuts along the internal line angles to        adheres together.
    provide retention.
                                                                  Mulling
STEPS OF AMALGAM RESTORATION                                      Mulling is done so that all alloy particles are properly coated
                                                                  with mercury. It can be done by squeezing the freshly mixed
               Steps of amalgam restoration                       amalgam collected in the chamois skin. Mechanical mulling
                                                                  is done in the amalgamator by triturating it for one to two
     1.   Selection of amalgam alloy
                                                                  seconds.
     2.   Mercury–alloy ratio
     3.   Trituration
                                                                  Application of Matrix Band
     4.   Mulling
     5.   Application of matrix bond                              Place the matrix band in the matrix retainer. Pass the matrix
     6.   Insertion of amalgam                                    band between the contact points so that its lower edge comes
     7.   Condensation                                            just over the cervical margin of the preparation. Tighten the
     8.   Burnishing                                              band and stabilize it using wedges.
     9.   Carving
    10.   Finishing and polishing                                 Insertion of Amalgam
                                                                  Pick a small amount of amalgam alloy with the help of
                                                                  amalgam carrier and transfer it to the preparation. Proximal
                                                                  box should be filled before the occlusal part of the
                                                                  preparation. Apply firm pressure on the amalgam mass for
                                                                  adequate condensation. After it, add next increment and
                                                                  again condense it.

                                                                  Condensation
                                                                  Different sizes of condensers are used for amalgam
     Fig. 10.49: Class VI preparation for amalgam restoration     condensation. Working end of a condenser is usually serrated.
200
                                                 One should shrinkage start condensation within three                 Finishing and polishing of the restorations should be
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 minutes of trituration and apply adequate force for              done at least 24 hours after the placement of the amalgam.
                                                 condensation.                                                    Premature finishing and polishing will interfere with the
                                                                                                                  crystalline structure of the hardening amalgam. The result
                                                 Burnishing                                                       will be a weakened restoration.
                                                 Precarve burnishing is done after condensation. Amalgam
                                                                                                                  VIVA QUESTIONS
                                                 is overfilled and burnished immediately with heavy strokes
                                                 so as to improve marginal adaptability of the restoration

                                                 and remove excess mercury from overpacked amalgam.

                                                 because axial and cervical margins become accessible after
                                                 removal of band.                                                 Q.   What is reverse curve?

                                                 direction with a sharp carver. Carve the occlusal surface

                                                 Finishing amalgam restorations involves removal of marginal      Q.   What is shape of class V tooth preparation for

                                                 the surface roughness of the restoration. Polishing is done      Q.   What are indications of class VI tooth preparation

                                                 amalgam. Finishing is done before polishing by use of abrasive

                                                 INTRODUCTION                                                           By definition, a composite is a compound composed of
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                    atleast two different materials with properties which are
                                                 The modern history of tooth colored restorative materials
                                                                                                                    superior or intermediate to those of an individual component.
                                                 was started with silicate cement which was introduced by
                                                                                                                        Dental composite resins have two primary components
                                                 Fletcher in the year 1878 in England, which was further
                                                                                                                    which are matrix phase and the filler phase and many
                                                 encouraged by Steenback and Ashor in 1903. Silicate
                                                                                                                    secondary components like polymerization initiators,
                                                 cements were discouraged later on because of their poor
                                                                                                                    pigments for providing different shades and silane coupling
                                                 strength, irritation to pulp tissue and brittleness. Moreover
                                                                                                                    agents. Though secondary components are required for
                                                 tooth preparations for silicate cement need to be of the
                                                                                                                    every composite material, most of the properties of material
                                                 conventional type.
                                                                                                                    are dependent upon filler and matrix phases.
                                                     Self-curing acrylic resins were developed in 1930 in
                                                                                                                        Although different composite materials have specific
                                                 Germany, but they became popular in dentistry in late 1940s.
                                                                                                                    composition and distribution of the matrix and filler parti-
                                                 They were used as veneers on the facial surface of metal
                                                                                                                    cles, they are often composed of bisphenol-A-diglycidyl-
                                                 restorations and as facings in crowns and bridges. But
                                                                                                                    methacrylate (Bis-GMA) or urethane di-methacrylate
                                                 they too showed poor physical properties like high
                                                                                                                    (UDMA) matrix polymers and glass filler particles. Both
                                                 polymerization, shrinkage and coefficient of thermal
                                                                                                                    the amount and the size of the filler particles determine
                                                 expansion (CTE), lack of wear resistance, poor marginal
                                                                                                                    mechanical properties of different composites.
                                                 seal, irritation to pulp and dimensional instability.
                                                     In an attempt to improve their properties, R Bowen, in              History of composite resins (From 1901 to 2007)
                                                 1962, developed a polymeric dental restorative material
                                                                                                                    1901    Synthesis and polymerization of methyl methacrylate
                                                 reinforced with silica particles used as fillers. These
                                                                                                                    1930    Use of PMMA as denture base resin
                                                 materials were called ‘composites’. Thus we can say that           1944    First acrylic filling material
                                                 composite resins have been introduced in operative dentistry       1951    Addition of inorganic fillers to direct filling materials
                                                 to overcome the drawbacks of the acrylic resins that               1955    Acidetch technique introduced by Buonocore
                                                 replaced silicate cements in the 1940s. Over the past two          1956    Bowen investigated dimethacrylates (Bis-GMA) and
                                                 decades, there has been a substantial progress in the                      silanized inorganic filler
                                                                                                                    1962    Introduction of silane coupling agents
                                                 development and application of resin-based composites.
                                                                                                                    1964    Marketing of Bis-GMA composites
                                                 Earlier composites were recommended only as a restorative          1968    Development of polymeric coatings on fillers
                                                 material for anterior restorations, but now they have become       1973    UV-cured dimethacrylate composite resins
                                                 one of the most commonly used direct restorative materials         1976    Introduction of microfilled composites
                                                 for both anterior and posterior teeth. This is because of          1977    Visible light cured dimethacrylate composite resins
                                                 better understanding of their application methods, including       1996    Development of flowable composites
                                                 composite placement and curing and improvement of their            1997    Development of packable composites
                                                                                                                    1998    Development of fiber reinforced, ion releasing
                                                 physical and mechanical properties. The principal reasons
                                                                                                                            composites and ormocers.
                                                 for the shifting from dental amalgam to composites are the
                                                 reduced need for preparation and the strengthening effect
                                                                                                                    COMPOSITION OF COMPOSITES
                                                 on the remaining tooth. Roeters et al have said once that the
                                                 introduction of resin composites is not just a change in           Composites are basically modified methacrylates or acrylates
                                                 materials and techniques but also a change in treatment            with other ingredients to produce different structures and
                                                 philosophy. Nowadays, composite resins are considered as           properties. The methacrylates are used because of their
                                                 an economical and aesthetic alternative to other direct and        refractive index of 1.3 which is close to tooth. This allows
                                                 indirect restorative materials. They can be used in different      metamerism (chameleon effect) giving the effect of
                                                 clinical conditions like diastema closures, veneers for anterior   similarity since methacrylates shrinks, inorganic inert filler
                                                 teeth and restorations for Class I, II, III, IV and V              particles of similar refractive index are added.
                                                 conservative restorations. If properly manipulated, they can           In general, dental composites are composed of following
                                                 prove the success rate and longevity equal to those of other       materials (Fig. 11.1):
                                                 materials. Since composite do not have self-adhering               • Organic matrix or organic phase
                                                 property, an adhesive is required before their placement.          • Inorganic matrix
                                                 Placement of a composite resin is very technique-sensitive         • Filler or disperse phase
                                                 than the placement of other restorations.                          • An organosilane or coupling agent
                                                                                                                                     203
                                                             TEGDMA have been tried in the ratio of 1:1 and 3:1, latter




                                                                                                                                     Composite Restorations
                                                             is preferred because an increase in TEGDMA increases the
                                                             chances of polymerization shrinkage.

                                                             Fillers
                                                             The dispersed phase of composite resins is made up of an
                                                             inorganic filler material. Since filler particles are added to
                                                             improve the physical and mechanical properties of the
                                                             organic matrix, the basic aim is always to incorporate high
                                                             percentage of filler. Commonly used fillers are silicon dioxide,
             Fig. 11.1: Composition of composite resin       boron silicates and lithium aluminium silicates. The filler
                                                             particles are silanated so that the hydrophilic filler can bond
                                                             to the hydrophobic resin matrix. The wear of composite
•    Activator–initiator system                              restorations depends on filler particle size, interparticle
•    Inhibitors                                              spacing and filler loading. Composites with smaller particles
•    Coloring agents.                                        show decreased wear due to fewer voids and smaller
                                                             interparticle spacing.
                 Composition of composites
    Organic resins                                                        Addition of filler causes following effects
    • Bis-GMA (Bowen’s resin)
                                                                 •    Reduces the thermal expansion coefficient
    • Dipentaerythritol pentaacrylate monophosphate
                                                                 •    Reduces polymerization shrinkage
    • Urethane dimethacrylate
                                                                 •    Increases abrasion resistance
    • Urethane tetramethacrylate
                                                                 •    Decreases water sorption
    • Hexamethylenediisocyanate
                                                                 •    Increases tensile and compressive strengths
    Fillers
                                                                 •    Increases fracture toughness
    • Fused or crystalline quartz
                                                                 •    Increases flexure modulus
    • Silicon dioxide
                                                                 •    Provides radiopacity
    • Borosilicate/Lithium aluminosilicate glass
                                                                 •    Improves handling properties
    • Ceramics
                                                                 •    Increases translucency
    • Ytterbium trifluoride
    • Radiopaque silicates
    • Organically modified ceramics (ORMOCERS)
                                                                 In some composites, the quartz is partly replaced with
    Others                                                   heavy metal particles like zinc, aluminium, barium, strontium
    • Triethyleneglycol dimethacrylate (TEGDMA)              or zirconium. Nowadays calcium metaphosphate has also
    • HEMA                                                   been tried. Since these are less hard than glass, they cause
    • Camphorquinone (CQ)                                    less wear on the opposing tooth.
    • META; phosphorated esters                                  Recently nanoparticles having the size of 25 nm and
    • Silane coupling agents                                 nanoaggregates of 75 nm, made up of zirconium/silica or
    • Antibacterial monomers
                                                             nanosilica particles have also been introduced. The smaller
    • Benzoyl peroxide and amine activator
                                                             size of filler particles results in better finish to the restoration.

Organic Matrix                                               Coupling Agent
The matrix base consists of polymeric mono-, di- or tri-     Interfacial bonding between the matrix phase and the filler
functional monomers like Bis-GMA or UDMA. The                phase is provided by coating the filler particles with silane
monomer system represents as the backbone of the             coupling agents. In other words a coupling agent is used to
composite resin system. Most preferred monomer is            bond the filler to the organic resin. This agent is a molecule
Bis-GMA either alone or in conjunction with urethane         with silane groups at one end (ion bond to SiO2 ) and
dimethacrylate UDMA. Since this resin is very viscous, in    methacrylate groups at the other.
order to improve clinical handling, it is diluted with low
viscosity monomers to control the viscosity. These can be    Functions of Coupling Agents
bisphenol A dimethacrylate (Bis-DMA), ethylene glycol        •       Bonding of filler and resin matrix.
dimethacrylate (EGDMA), triethylene glycol dimethacrylate    •       Transfer forces from flexible resin matrix to stiffer filler
(TEGDMA), methyl methacrylate (MMA). Bis-GMA and                     particles.

                                                               Microfilled composites were introduced in the early 1980s.
TYPES OF COMPOSITE RESINS                                      Average particle size of microfilled resins ranges from
Though composites have been classified according to            0.04-0.1 micrometer. Filler content of microfilled resins is
different characteristics, the most commonly followed          35-50% by weight. The small particle size results in smooth
classification is based on the type, distribution and filler   polished surface which is resistant to plaque, debris and
phase of composites (Table 11.1).                              stains.
    Composite resin can be divided into three types based          But because of less filler content, some of their physical
on the size, amount and composition of the inorganic filler    properties are inferior. They have low modulus of elasticity
(Figs 11.2A to C):                                             and high polishability, excellent translucency. However, they
1. Macrofilled composite resins                                exhibit low fracture toughness and increased marginal
2. Microfilled resins                                          breakdown.
3. Hybrid composite resins.                                        They are indicated for the restoration of anterior teeth
                                                               and cervical abfraction lesions (Table 17.2).
Macrofilled Composite Resins
                                                               Advantages
Average particle size of macrofill composite resins is from
5-25 micron. Filler content is approximately 75-80% by         •   Highly polishable
weight.                                                        •   Good esthetic.

                                                               Disadvantages
                                                               •   Poor mechanical properties due to more matrix content
                                                               •   Poor color stability
                                                               •   Low wear resistance.
                                                               •   Less modulus of elasticity and tensile strength
                                                               •   More water absorption
                                                               •   High coefficient of thermal expansion

Type
                                                                 Condensable (Packable) Composites
Filler content in flowable resins is 60% by weight. It is
usually silica which are 0.02 to 0.05 µm in size. Lower          Condensable composites have been developed in an attempt
filler content is responsible for poor mechanical properties     to improve the compressive, tensile and edge strength and
of these composites than conventional composites.                handling of the composite. The principle of the high viscosity
                                                                 of packable composites is that they can be pushed into the
Advantages                                                       posterior tooth preparation and have greater control over
•   Low viscosity                                                the proximal contour of class II preparations. Their basis is
•   Improve marginal adaptation of posterior composites          polymer rigid inorganic matrix material (PRIMM). In this
    by acting as an elastic, stress absorbing layer over which   components are resin and ceramic inorganic fillers which
    composite is placed                                          are incorporated in silanated network of ceramic fibers.
•   High wettability of the tooth surface                        These fibers are composed of alumina and silicon dioxide
•   High depth of cure                                           which are fused with each other at specific sites to form a
•   Penetration into every irregularity of preparation           continuous network of small compartments. Filler content
•   Ability to form layers of minimum thickness, thus            in packable composites ranges from 48-65% by volume.
    eliminate air entrapment                                     Average particle size ranges from 0.7-20 µm.
•   High flexibility, so less likely to be displaced in stress        Packable composites possess improved mechanical
    concentration areas                                          properties because of presence of ceramic fibers. They have
•   Radiopaque                                                   improved handling properties because of presence of higher
•   Availability in different colors                             percentage of irregular or porous filler, fibrous filler and
•   Require minimally invasive tooth preparations                resin matrix. The consistency of the condensable composites
•   For the pediatric patient to be used in narrow and deep      is like freshly triturated amalgam. Each increment can be
    pits and fissures.                                           condensed similar to amalgam restoration and can be cured
                                                                 to a depth of over 4 mm.
Disadvantages
                                                                 Indications
•   More susceptible to wear in stress-bearing areas
•   Weaker mechanical properties                                 •   Indicated for stress-bearing areas
•   More polymerization shrinkage and wear                       •   In class II restorations as they allow easier establishment
•   Sticks to the instrument, so difficult to smoothen the           of physiological contact points.
    surface.

                                                 •   Difficult handling
                                                 •   Poor aesthetics in anterior teeth.                             The first compomer was introduced in 1993 under the name

                                                 Giomers                                                            of glass-ionomers which offered fluoride release along with
                                                                                                                    improved physical properties. But in terms of clinical use
                                                 Giomer is hybrid of words “glass ionomers” and “compo-             and performance, these are considered as a type of
                                                 site”. These are relatively new type of restorative materials.     composite resin.

                                                 ionomer composites). Giomers have properties of both glass         duced.
                                                 ionomers (fluoride release, fluoride recharge) and resin
                                                 composite (excellent aesthetics, easy polishability, bio-

                                                 compatibility).
                                                                                                                    •   Resin matrix: Dimethacrylate monomers with two
                                                 Chemistry                                                              carboxylic groups present in their structure

                                                 Giomers are hybrid aesthetic restorative materials which
                                                 employ the use of PRG technology, in other words, they             •   Photoinitiators and stabilizers
                                                 are resin-based materials which contain prereacted glass           •   There is no water in the composition and ionleachable
                                                 ionomer (PRG) particles. The particles are made of                     glass is partially silanized to ensure bonding to matrix.
                                                 fluoroaluminosilicate glass that has been reacted with
                                                 polyalkenoic acid before incorporating into the resin matrix.      Setting Reaction
                                                 The prereaction may involve either the surface or full particle.   These materials set by free radical polymerization reaction.
                                                 Giomers are very much similar to compomers and
                                                                                                                    There are two stages in the polymerization reaction.
                                                 composite materials in that they are light activated and
                                                                                                                    1. Stage 1: Typical light activated composite resin
                                                 require the use of bonding agent for adhesion to tooth
                                                                                                                       polymerization reaction occurs which helps in forming
                                                 structure.
                                                                                                                       resin networks enclosing the filler particles. This reaction
                                                                                                                       causes hardening of products.
                                                 Properties of Giomers
                                                                                                                    2. Stage 2: It occurs after the initial setting of material.
                                                 1. Easier to polish than glass ionomers                               The restoration absorbs water and carboxyl groups
                                                 2. Optimum fluoride release                                           present in the polyacid and metal ions in the glass
                                                 3. Excellent aesthetics                                               ionomers show slow acid-base reaction. This results in
                                                 4. Better surface finish                                              formation of hydrogel. It is like glass ionomer cement
                                                 5. Chemical bonding to tooth structure                                within the set resin structure. There occurs slow release
                                                 6. Biocompatibility                                                   of fluoride also.
                                                 7. Sensitive to moisture and desiccation.

                                                                                                                    • Bond strength: It is similar to composite.
                                                 Compomers are class of dental materials that provide               • Adaptation at cervical margin is similar to composite
                                                 combined advantages of composites (term ‘Comp’ in their               resins.

                                                                 Properties
Advantages                                                       1. More biocompatible than conventional composites.
•   Optimal aesthetics                                           2. Higher bond strength.
•   Easy to handle                                               3. Polymerization shrinkage is least among resin-based
•   Easy to polishing                                               filling material.
                                                                 4. Highly esthetic, comparable to natural tooth.
•   Easy to place
                                                                 5. High compressive (410 MPa) and transverse strength
•   Require no mixing
                                                                    (143 MPa).
•   Bond strength is higher than glass ionomers.
                                                                 Indications
Disadvantages
                                                                 1. Restoration for all types of preparations.
•   Require use of bonding agent
                                                                 2. For esthetic veneers.
•   Technique sensitive                                          3. As orthodontic bonding adhesive.
•   Limited fluoride release
•   Microleakage more than resin modified glass ionomers         Antibacterial Composites/Ion
•   Expansion of matrix due to water sorption                    Releasing Composites
•   Physical properties decrease with time.

                                                                 have been made to develop caries-resistant antibacterial

     incorporated into the resin matrix and acid does not        of the following reasons:
