ORMOCER (Organically Modified Ceramic)
                                                                 Methacryloxydecyl Pyridinium Bromide (MDPB)
ORMOCER is an organically modified non metallic inorganic
composite material. It is three dimensionally cross-linked       Use of MDPB was recommended by Imazato in 1994. It
copolymer. First time, it was introduced as dental restorative   has following features:
material in 1998.                                                • Its antibacterial property remains constant and perma-
                                                                    nent.
Composition                                                      • It has shown to be effective against streptococci.
                                                                 • It does not have adverse effect on the physical properties
ORMOCERS have both organic and inorganic networks.                  of Bis-GMA based composites.
They are characterized by presence of three main units:          • On polymerization, it forms chemical bond to the resin
• Organic molecules segment having methacrylate groups              matrix, therefore, no release of any antibacterial
   which form a highly cross-linked matrix.                         component takes place.
210
                                                 Silver
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 Addition of silver ions in the composites has also been
                                                 suggested so as to make antibacterial composites. Silver
                                                 ions cause structural damage to the bacteria. In these
                                                 composites, the antibacterial property is due to direct contact
                                                 with bacteria and not because of release of silver ions.
                                                 Addition of silver into composite without silica gel does not
                                                 affect its physical properties like depth of cure, compressive
                                                 strength, tensile strength, color stability and polymerization.
                                                     Silver ions can be added in any of the following methods:       Fig. 11.3: Coefficient of thermal expansion can result in dimensional
                                                 a. Incorporated into inorganic oxide like silicone dioxides.        change in restoration which can cause gap between tooth and the
                                                 b. Incorporated into silica gel and the thin films are coated       restoration
                                                     over the surface of composites.
                                                 c. Hydrothermally supported into the space between the              Water Absorption
                                                     crystal lattice network of filler particles.
                                                                                                                     Composites have tendency to absorb water which can lead
                                                 “Smart” Composites                                                  to the swelling of resin matrix, filler debonding and thus
                                                                                                                     restoration failure.
                                                 In smart composites the micron size sensor particles are
                                                 embedded during manufacturing process into composite.               Factors affecting Water Absorption of Composites
                                                 These sensors interact with resin matrix and generate
                                                                                                                     •   More is the filler content, less is the water sorption.
                                                 quantifiable anions. This type of composites was introduced
                                                                                                                     •   Lesser degree of polymerization causes more sorption.
                                                 in 1998 under the name Ariston pHc (Vivadent).
                                                                                                                     •   Type and amount of monomer and dilutent also affect
                                                     It releases fluoride, hydroxyl and calcium ions if the pH
                                                                                                                         water sorption. For example, UDMA-based composites
                                                 falls in the vicinity of the restoration. The fall in pH value is       show less sorption and solubility.
                                                 attributed to the deposition of plaque in that area. Smart
                                                 composites work based on the recently introduced alkaline           Wear Resistance
                                                 glass fillers which inhibit the bacterial growth and thereby
                                                 reduce formation of secondary caries. The paste of smart            Composites are prone to wear under masticatory forces or
                                                 composites contain barium, aluminium fluoride and silicate          use of tooth brushing and abrasive food (Fig. 11.4). Wear
                                                 glass fillers with silicon dioxide, ytterbium trifluoride and
                                                 calcium silicate glass in dimethacrylate monomers. Filler
                                                 content in these composites is 80% by weight.
                                                     The fluoride release from smart composites is higher
                                                 than that of compomers but lower than conventional glass
                                                 ionomers.

                                                 PROPERTIES OF COMPOSITE
                                                 RESTORATIVE MATERIALS

                                                 Coefficient of Thermal Expansion
                                                 Coefficient of thermal expansion of composites is
                                                 approximately three times higher than normal tooth
                                                 structure. This results in more contraction and expansion
                                                 than enamel and dentin when there are temperature changes,
                                                                                                                     Fig. 11.4: Abrasive wear in composite restoration causes exposure
                                                 it can result in loosening of the restoration (Fig. 11.3). This     of filler-particles which get removed from the surface of composite
                                                 can be reduced by adding more filler content.                       restoration
                                                                                                                                         211
resistance is a property of filler particles depending on




                                                                                                                                         Composite Restorations
their size and quantity. The site of restorations in dental
arch and occlusal contact relationship, size, shape and
content of filler particles affect the wear resistance of the
composites.

Factors affecting Degradation/Wear
of Composites
•   Lesser is the polymerization, more is the degradation.
•   Microfilled composites show less of degradation.
•   Hydrolytic degradation of strontium or barium glass
    fillers can result in pressure built up at resin filler junc-
    tion. This may cause cracks and fracture of composite
    restoration.
•   Sudden temperature change can result in disruption is                Fig. 11.5: Polymerization shrinkage can result in gap between
    silane coating and thus bond failure between matrix and                             restoration and the tooth surface
    filler.

Surface Texture
                                                                    Polymerization Shrinkage
The size and composition of filler particles determine the
smoothness of the surface of a restoration. Microfilled             Composite materials shrink while curing which can result
composites offer the smoothest restorative surface.                 in formation of a gap between resin-based composite
                                                                    and the preparation wall (Fig. 11.5). It accounts for
Radiopacity                                                         1.67-5.68% of the total volume.
Resins are inherently radiolucent. Presence of radiopaque
                                                                                        Polymerization shrinkage
fillers like barium glass, strontium and zirconium makes the
composite restoration radiopaque.                                    •     In light-cured composites, about 60% polymerization
                                                                           occurs within 60 seconds, further 10% in next 48 hours;
Modulus of Elasticity                                                      remaining resin does not polymerize. Since the material
                                                                           nearest to the light sets first. Shrinkage in light cured
Modulus of elasticity of a material determines its rigidity or             composites occurs in the direction of light (Figs 11.6A
stiffness. Microfill composites have greater flexibility than              and B).
hybrid composite since they have lower modulus of                    •     For chemical-cured composites shrinkage occurs
elasticity.                                                                slowly and uniformly towards the center of restoration
                                                                           (Fig. 11.7).
Solubility
Composite materials do not show any clinically significant
                                                                    Polymerization shrinkage can result in:
solubility in oral fluids. Water solubility of composites ranges
from 0.5-1.1 mg/cm2.                                                • Postoperative sensitivity
                                                                    • Recurrent caries
Creep                                                               • Failure of interfacial bonding
                                                                    • Fracture of restoration and tooth (Fig. 11.8).
Creep is progressive permanent deformation of material
under occlusal loading. More is the content of resin matrix,        Polymerization shrinkage can be reduced by:
more is the creep. For example, microfilled composites show         • Decreasing monomer level
more creep since they contain more of resin matrix.                 • Increasing monomer molecular weight
212
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                                          Figs 11.6A and B: In light cured composites, shrinkage occurs towards source of light




                                                 Fig. 11.7: In chemical cured composites, shrinkage occurs towards
                                                                         center of restoration
                                                                                                                           Fig. 11.9: Incremental build-up of restoration results in decreased
                                                                                                                                               polymerization shrinkage


                                                                                                                       •     Improving composite placement technique: Placing
                                                                                                                             successive layers of wedge-shaped composite (1-1.5
                                                                                                                             mm) decreases polymerization shrinkage (Fig. 11.9).
                                                                                                                       •     Polymerization rate: “Soft-start” polymerization reduces
                                                                                                                             polymerization shrinkage.

                                                                                                                       Configuration or “C-Factor”
                                                                                                                       The cavity configuration or C-factor was introduced by
                                                                                                                       Prof Carol Davidson and his colleagues in 1980s. The
                                                                                                                       configuration factor (C-factor) is the ratio of bonded surface
                                                                                                                       of the restoration to the unbonded surfaces. The higher the
                                                 Fig. 11.8: Polymerization shrinkage can pull cusps together and can
                                                                                                                       value of C-factor, the greater is the polymerization shrinkage
                                                                           result in fracture                          (Fig. 11.10).

                                                 Working and Setting Times
                                                 Light Cure Composites
                                                 In case of light cure composites, application of light source
                                                                                                                       Fig. 11.11: As the distance between light source and tooth
                                                 to the composite material starts the polymerization. Usually,                    increases, polymerization decreases
                                                 70% of polymerization takes place during the first
                                                 10 minutes, though the polymerization reaction continues
                                                 for period of 24 hours.                                           distance is increased. If the cavity is deep, use highpower
                                                                                                                   density lamp (about 600 mW/cm2 ) so that deeper layer is
                                                 Mixing for Self-cure Composites                                   also cured (Fig. 11.11). Polymerization can also be achieved
                                                 Self-cure composites come in two syringes. One syringe            in tooth preparation with deep proximal box by curing from
                                                                                                                   proximal surface (Fig. 11.12).
                                                 contains the peroxide initiator or catalyst while other syringe
                                                                                                                       The angle of source should be 90° to the resin. If angle
                                                 contains the amine accelerator. They are dispensed in equal
                                                                                                                   diverges from 90°, intensity of light decreases.
                                                 amounts and then thoroughly mixed for 20-30 seconds.
                                                 For mixing, plastic or wooden spatulas are preferred. Use
                                                                                                                   Temperature
                                                 of metal spatula is avoided because inorganic filler particles
                                                 are abrasive, they can abrade small amount of metal and           Composite curing would be less if they are taken out
                                                 thus discolor the composite. The working time for self-           immediately from refrigerator. These materials should be
                                                 cure composite resins is 1-1½ minutes. Once the mix starts        at least held at room temperature 1 hour before use.
                                                 hardening, it should not be disturbed for 4-5 minutes (setting
                                                 time).                                                            Resin Thickness
                                                                                                                   Resin thickness is also one of the main factors during curing
                                                 POLYMERIZATION OF COMPOSITES                                      of resin. It should be ideally 0.5-1.0 mm for optimum
                                                 Complete polymerization of the composite is determined by         polymerization of resin.
                                                 degree of conversion of monomers into polymers. Degree
                                                                                                                   Inhibition of Air
                                                 of conversion of the composite is dependent on following
                                                 factors:                                                          Oxygen in the air also affects the polymerization of the
                                                                                                                   resin.
                                                 Curing Time
                                                 Curing time depends on different factors like shade of the
                                                 composite, intensity of the light used, temperature, depth
                                                 of the preparation, thickness of the resin, curing through
                                                 tooth structure, composite filling.

                                                 Shade of Composite
                                                 It has been seen that darker composite shades polymerize
                                                 slower when compared to lighter shades.

                                                 Distance and Angle between
                                                 Light Source and Resin
                                                 The recommended distance is 1 mm and should be at 90°               Fig. 11.12: Polymerized light should be directed from all sides of
                                                 to the resin material. Intensity of light decreases as the                proximal box so as to have complete polymerization
                                                                                                                                          215
                                                                       •   As core build up for grossly damaged teeth and




                                                                                                                                          Composite Restorations
                                                                           endodontically treated teeth.
                                                                       •   For cementation of indirect restorations like inlays, onlays
                                                                           and crowns.
                                                                       •   As a pit and fissure sealants.
                                                                       •   For periodontal splinting of weakened teeth or mobile
                                                                           teeth.
                                                                       •   For repair of fractured ceramic crowns.
                                                                       •   For bonding orthodontic appliances.

                                                                       CONTRAINDICATIONS OF COMPOSITES
                                                                       •   When isolation of operating field is difficult.
                                                                       •   Where very high occlusal forces are present.
Fig. 11.13: As the distance between light source and the restoration   •   Class V lesions where aesthetics is not the prime
             increases, the intensity of light decreases                   concern.
                                                                       •   When clinician does not possess the necessary technical
Intensity of Curing Light                                                  skill for the restoration.
                                                                       •   When lesion extends up to the root surface.
Intensity of curing light usually decreases as the lamp ages.          •   Small lesions on distal surface of canines where metallic
Decrease in intensity of light affects the properties of                   restoration is treatment of choice.
composites significantly.                                              •   Patients with high caries susceptibility.
    For optimal results, wavelength of light should range              •   When preparation extends subgingivally.
between 400-500 nm. To make it sure that 400 mW/cm                     •   Patients with poor oral hygiene.
reaches the first increment of the restoration, a power
density of 600 mW/cm is needed (Fig. 11.13).                           Advantages of Composites
                                                                       •   Since composite restoration requires minimal tooth

INDICATIONS OF COMPOSITE RESTORATIONS                                  •   Composite resin can be used in combination with other
                                                                           materials, such as glass ionomer, to provide the benefits
•   For restoration of mild to moderate class I and class II
                                                                           of both materials.
    tooth preparations of all teeth.
                                                                       •   Composites have low thermal conductivity, thus no
•   Restoration of class III, IV and V preparations of all                 insulation base is required to protect underlying pulp.
    teeth, especially when aesthetics is important.                    •   Restorations are bonded with enamel and dentin, hence
•   Restoration of class VI preparations of teeth where high               show good retention.
    occlusal stress is not present.                                    •   Restoration with composite resins can be finished
•   Esthetic improvement procedures:                                       immediately after curing.
    a. Laminates                                                       •   It can be repaired rather than replaced.
    b. Partial veneers                                                 •   Composite restoration shows low microleakage than
    c. Full veneers                                                        unfilled resins.
    d. Treatment of tooth discolorations                               •   Can be used almost universally.
    e. Diastema closures                                               •   They have extended working time, this makes their
•   To restore erosion or abrasion defects in cervical areas               manipulation easier.
    of all the surfaces of premolars, canines and incisors             •   Restoration can be completed in one dental visit.
    where aesthetics is the main concern.                              •   Composite restorations can bond directly to the tooth,
•   For restoration of hypoplastic or other defects on the                 making the tooth stronger than it would be with an
    facial or lingual areas of teeth.                                      amalgam filling.
216
                                                 •       Indirect composite fillings and inlays are heat-cured,
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                         increasing their strength.
                                                 •       No galvanism because composite resins do not contain
                                                         any metals.
                                                 •       Composite resins have adequate radiopacity to enable
                                                         their detection in radiographs.
                                                 DISADVANTAGES OF COMPOSITES
                                                 •       Because of polymerization shrinkage, gap formation on
                                                                                                                           Figs 11.14A and B: Conventional class III tooth preparation for
                                                         margins may occur, usually on root surfaces. This can                                    composites
                                                         result in secondary caries and staining.
                                                 •       More difficult, time consuming.
                                                 •       Expensive than amalgam.
                                                 •       More technique sensitive.
                                                 •       Low wear resistance.
                                                 •       Postoperative sensitivity due to polymerization shrink-
                                                         age.
                                                 •       High LCTE may result in marginal percolation around
                                                         composite restorations.
                                                 •       In large preparation, composites may not last as long as
                                                         amalgam fillings.
                                                 TOOTH PREPARATION FOR
                                                 COMPOSITE RESTORATIONS

                                                                Prerequisites for tooth preparation to
                                                                   receive composite restoration
                                                     •    Use rubber dam for optimal isolation of the working          Figs 11.15A and B: When caries extend to root surface, (A)
                                                          area.                                                        Conventional tooth preparation is made on root and (B) Bevelling is
                                                     •    Use yellow filter for the operating light or to keep it on   done in coronal portion
                                                          low intensity so as to avoid the premature
                                                          polymerization of the composite.
                                                     •    Take proper precautions to protect eyes from glare, so
                                                          use safety specs or for this a hand-held shield can be
                                                          used.
                                                     •    Use teflon coated composite filling instruments so as
                                                          to prevent the composite resin from sticking and ‘pulling
                                                          back’.

                                                 CLASS III TOOTH PREPARATION
                                                 Depending upon the type of dental tissues involved, the                   Fig. 11.16: For initial penetration, entry into tooth should be made
                                                                                                                                   from the palatal side so as to preserve esthetics
                                                 tooth preparation for the composites can be done in three
                                                 designs: conventional, beveled conventional and modified.
                                                                                                                       •     The extent of lesion determines the outline of tooth
                                                 Conventional Class III Tooth                                                preparation. For penetration into lesion, usually the
                                                 Preparation (Figs 11.14A and B)                                             direction for entry of bur is from lingual side except for
                                                 •       Indication for conventional tooth preparation is the lesion         a few cases (Fig. 11.16). This lingual approach helps in
                                                         present on the root surfaces.                                       preservation of aesthetics. Following are the indications
                                                 •       Usually most of the lesions occur partly on the root and            for labial approach:
                                                         partly on crown. The tooth preparation on the root is               1. Involvement of labial enamel.
                                                         done in conventional method whereas on the crown it is              2. In cases of rotated teeth where lingual approach is
                                                         prepared in beveled conventional or modified type (Figs                 difficult.
                                                         11.15A and B).                                                      3. In cases of malaligned teeth.
                                                                                                                                  217
•   When the damage is present only on the root surface,




                                                                                                                                  Composite Restorations
    the conventional preparation is made only on the root
    with 90° cavosurface margins. In the crown portion of
    the preparation, the retention is mostly achieved by
    adhesive bonding to enamel and dentin.
•   The external walls are made perpendicular to the root
    surface.
•   While preparing, there should be adequate removal of
    caries, old restoration or defective tooth structure. The
    external walls of the preparation should be located on
    sound tooth structure with a cavosurface angle of
    90° for butt joint relation.
                                                                          Fig. 11.17: Making grooves in class III preparation
•   If the carious lesion is not deep, the depth of the pre-                                for retention
    paration is kept 0.75 mm. After this, it is deepened
    wherever caries is present.
•   Retention in conventional tooth preparation is attained
    by:
    – Roughening of the preparation surface
    – Parallelism or convergence of opposing external walls
    – Giving retention grooves and coves (Fig. 11.17).
•   Grooves can be placed continuous or isolated. Conti-
    nuous groove is placed in external walls, parallel to tooth
    surface. It should be located at least 1 mm from the
    tooth surface and at least 0.5 mm deep into dentin.

Beveled Conventional Class III
Tooth Preparation
Indications of beveled class III preparation are following:                      Fig. 11.18: Completed class III tooth
                                                                                     preparation for composites
• For replacing an existing defective restoration on crown
   portion of an anterior tooth if a large carious lesion is
   present.

                                                                      infected dentin or defective restoration using spoon
•   Approach the area lingually with a no. 1/2, 1 or 2 round          excavator or slow speed round bur.
    bur. Penetrate the lesion and move the bur in                 •   For pulp protection, place a calcium hydroxide liner if
    incisogingival direction.                                         indicated.

    neck portion of the bur far into the embrasure.                   cular to the enamel surface with all enamel margins
•   Shape of the tooth preparation should be identical to the         beveled (Fig. 11.19). Prepare the bevels using flat end
    shape of existing carious lesion or the restoration.              tapering fissure diamond bur at cavosurface margins in
•   One should take care to include any secondary caries,             the areas of centric contacts. The bevel should be about
    friable tooth structure and defects while placing the             0.2 to 0.5 mm wide at an angle of 45° to the external
    external walls on sound tooth structure.                          tooth surface (Figs 11.20A and B).
•   Initial depth of the axial wall should be 0.75 mm deep        •   Bevels are not given in areas bearing heavy occlusal
    gingivally and 1.25 mm deep incisally. This results               forces or on cemental cavosurface margins.
    in the axial wall depth of 0.2 mm into the dentin             •   If required, prepare retentive grooves and coves along
    (Fig. 11.18).                                                     gingivoaxial line angle and incisoaxial line angle,
•   Shape of the axial wall should be convex outwardly,               respectively, with the help of no. 1/4 or 1/2 round burs.
    that is, it should follow the contour of the tooth.               Depth of these grooves should be 0.2 mm into the dentin.

                                                     the preparation (Figs 11.21A and B).                             CLASS V TOOTH PREPARATION

                                                 Steps                                                                Composites are material of choice for restoration of class
                                                                                                                      V lesions which are aesthetically prominent. Among
                                                 •   Make initial entry through the palatal surface with a small      composites, microfill composites are material of choice
                                                     round bur in the air rotor handpiece. It is always               because they provide better and more smooth surface and
                                                     preferred to use the lingual approach since it conserves         have sufficient flexibility to resist stresses caused by cervical
                                                     labial tooth structure which is more esthetic.                   flexure, when tooth flexes under heavy occlusal forces.
                                                 •   The bur should be kept rotating when being entered into
                                                     the tooth and should not stop rotating until being removed.
                                                                                                                      Conventional Class V Preparation
                                                 •   The design and extent of the preparation is determined
                                                     by the extent of the carious lesion (Fig. 11.22).                Conventional class V preparation is indicated if it is present
                                                 •   Keep all the internal line angles rounded to decrease            completely or mainly on root surface (Fig. 11.23). If the
                                                     internal stresses. It can be done using a half round bur         lesion is partly on crown and partly on root, the crown
                                                     head.                                                            portion is prepared using beveled conventional or modified
                                                                                                                                           219




                                                                                                                                           Composite Restorations
                                                                            Fig. 11.24: Placing retention grooves in class V preparation

Fig. 11.23: Conventional tooth preparation is indicated if caries are
                 present mainly on root surface



preparation design and the root surface lesion is prepared in
conventional method.
    In conventional class V tooth preparation, shape of the
preparation is a “box” type. Isolate the area well and use
a tapered fissure (no. 700, or 701) bur to make entry at
45° angle to tooth surface initially. After this keep long axis
of bur perpendicular to the external surface in order to get
a cavosurface angle of 90°.
    During initial tooth preparation, keep the axial depth of
0.75 mm into the dentin.

                                                    For class III restoration, a properly contoured wedge
                                                 supported, clear polyester mylar strip matrix is used (Fig.     As we know that greater the bulk of material, the greater is
                                                 11.31).                                                         the shrinkage and, thus more is the resultant stress on bonded
                                                                                                                 interfaces. Therefore, composite restoration should be

                                                                                                                 placed in small increments to reduce polymerization
                                                 • Contains the material

                                                 • Reduces oxygen contact with the surface of the compo-

                                                   site so ensures more complete polymerization.
                                                                                                                 material. Longer exposure to light is required for darker
                                                 Composite Placement                                             and opaque shades. Each increment is added and cured till
                                                                                                                 the complete preparation is filled.

                                                                                                                                                Composite Restorations
 Fig. 11.33: Gross proximal contouring of restoration can be done               Fig. 11.34: Contact area is polished with the help
 using small thin disc rotating from 90° towards the facial surface                        of abrasive finishing strips



1. For composite restorations, the amount of contouring
   required after final polymerization of the composite can
   be reduced by careful placement technique. Minimizing
   contouring retains the sealed margins of the restoration.
   It also helps minimizing microcracks which can be
   formed by using abrasives on the surface of restoration.
2. Remove flash with a sharp hand instrument. Any excess
   material can be trimmed with sharp scalpel blade
   no. 11, composite finishing diamond bur and/or
   multibladed tungsten carbide finishing bur. Use a coolant/
   lubricant in gross reduction to reduce production of heat
   and friction.
3. Gross contouring of proximal restoration can be done
   using a small and thin disc rotating from 90° towards
   the facial surface (Fig. 11.33).
4. Contact areas may be finished by using a series of
   abrasive finishing strips threaded below the contact point
   so as not to destroy the contact point (Fig. 11.34). In
   class III restoration, to avoid any damage to contact
   point, the finishing strip should be used in S-shaped
   pattern. If strip is pulled on same side it can lead to open
                                                                      Fig. 11.35: In class III restoration, to avoid damage to contact point,
   contact points (Fig. 11.35).                                       finishing strip should be used in S-shaped pattern. Pulling of strip on
5. Final contouring, finishing and polishing of a composite           same side can lead to open contact points
   restoration is done with finishing diamond points (Figs
   11.36A and B). Polishing is done using rubber-polishing
   points, abrasive disks or pumice-impregnated points.
                                                                      Checking the Occlusion
   Check the contours and margins on proximal area with
explorer and dental floss. A sharp no. 12 surgical blade in           After contouring of restoration, occlusion is evaluated in
BP handle or gold finishing knife contouring, is used for             centric position and during various mandibular movements
contouring and finishing of composite filling at gingival             for proper contacts. If occlusion is not proper, further
margin. It is specially important to avoid creating a ledge           adjustments are made and restorations are finished with
cervically as it is difficult to remove excess from this area.        fine rubber abrasive points or disks.

                                                                                                                     •   Lack of moisture control
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                     •   Contamination of composite with finger/saliva
                                                                                                                     •   Following bulk placement technique during poly-
                                                                                                                         merization of composite
                                                                                                                     •   Improper polymerization method
                                                                                                                     •   Incomplete finishing and polishing of composites
                                                                                                                     •   Inadequate occlusion of restored tooth

                                                                                                                     Following Failures are Commonly seen in
                                                                                                                     Composite Restorations with Time
                                                                                                                     •   Discoloration, especially at the margins
                                                                                                                     •   Fracture of margins
                                                                                                                     •   Secondary caries
                                                                                                                     •   Postoperative sensitivity
                                                                                                                     •   Gross fracture of restoration
                                                                                                                     •   Loss of contact after a period of time
                                                                                                                     •   Accumulation of plaque around the restorations.

                                                                                                                     Certain Guidelines should be followed which can
                                                   Figs 11.36A and B: Final contouring, finishing and polishing of
                                                    restoration is done with the help of finishing diamond points
                                                                                                                     Minimize the Chances of Composite Failure:
                                                                                                                     1. The tooth preparation should be kept as small as possible
                                                                                                                        since composite in bulk lead to failure
                                                                                                                     2. Avoid sharp internal line angles in tooth preparation,
                                                 Glazing                                                                which increases stress concentration
                                                 The surface smoothness and shine of a composite                     3. Deeper preparations should be given base of calcium
                                                 restoration can be increased by a “glazing”. Glazing is the            hydroxide or glass ionomer cement
                                                 process of placing of a thin layer of unfilled resin over the       4. Strict isolation regime is to be followed
                                                 finished composite resin. This is then light cured. The             5. Avoid inadequate curing, since it leads to hydrolytic
                                                                                                                        breakdown of composites
                                                 resultant surface is very smooth and shiny initially but it
                                                                                                                     6. Use small increments, holding each increment with
                                                 lasts only for a few weeks. Since it lacks the abrasive
                                                                                                                        teflons coated instruments.
                                                 resistance and adhesion, with time the surface is abraded
                                                                                                                     7. Fill proximal box separately and create proper contact
                                                 away during function. To improve the adhesion of glaze,
                                                                                                                        areas
                                                 before glazing the restoration, surface should be etched with
                                                                                                                     8. Composite, especially at the beveled areas, should be
                                                 low concentration of hydrofluoric acid.
                                                                                                                        finished and polished properly.
                                                 Glazing serves the following purposes:
                                                 • Improves aesthetics.                                              REPAIR OF COMPOSITE RESTORATIONS
                                                 • Creates a smooth glossy surface, resistant to plaque
                                                                                                                     When the area to a defective restoration is accessible, for
                                                    retention.
                                                                                                                     repair, the old restoration is roughened with a diamond stone
                                                 • Fills surface porosity.
                                                                                                                     and the enamel margins are etched. After this, primer and
                                                                                                                     adhesive are applied and finally composite is placed, finished
                                                 FAILURES IN COMPOSITE RESTORATIONS
                                                                                                                     and polished. In case, when the defective restoration is in
                                                 Composite restorations may show failure because of:                 area which is difficult to access, the defective restoration
                                                 • Incomplete removal of carious lesion                              should be exposed by tooth preparation. After this, place a
                                                 • Incomplete etching or incomplete removal of residual              matrix and wedge and etch the enamel margins. Apply primer
                                                   acid from tooth surface                                           and bonding agent and finally place composite. Cure it and
                                                 • Excess or deficient application of bonding agent                  do the final finishing and polishing.

INTRODUCTION                                                        structure is not present for the support of restoration, then
                                                                    cast metal restorations are indicated. Cast metal restorations
Though various defects of teeth can be restored using
different restorative materials like amalgam, composite             were introduced in dentistry about 100 years ago and soon
resins, direct filling gold and cast metal restorative materials.   they became a subject of great interest to both dentists and
Each material has its own indications, contraindications,           patients. Most advantageous properties of gold alloy is its
advantages and disadvantages. When sufficient tooth                 malleability, and when properly manipulated, it has wear
                                                                                                                                 227
similarly to that of tooth structure. Cast gold restorations




                                                                                                                                 Cast Metal Restorations
became most popular from the 1930s to the 1970s because
of their acceptable functions and restorative longevity. Most
of the cast metal restorations are made from alloys formed
by combination of gold with other metals such as silver,
copper, zinc, platinum and palladium. Casting procedures
have been used for replacement of teeth by means of fixed
and removable partial denture prosthesis, and full mouth
restorations.
    In operative dentistry, cast metal restorations are mainly
used in three forms:
1. Inlay                                                                             Fig. 12.1: Class II inlay

2. Onlay
3. Partial crown.                                                involve facial and/or lingual surface/s of a posterior tooth
    After 1970s, restorative materials providing esthetics       and covers all the cusps (Fig. 12.2).
came into light. And after that there was increase in
                                                                 Partial crown: In partial crown, a part of the crown remains
awareness of tooth colored restorations in comparison to
                                                                 uncovered and rest of the crown is covered like three quarter
cast gold restorations.
                                                                 crown and seven-eighth crown.
    History of casting of objects in gold by the wax
elimination process dates back to four or five thousand years    Crown: A crown completely covers the crown of the tooth
ago by Chinese. Italian artisan Benvenuto Cellini described      (Fig. 12.3).
the use of this technique to make statues and artistic pieces.
Dr Taggart developed a technique of casting gold inlays by
the invested wax pattern method, introduced this to the
profession in 1907.
    In 1897, Dr Philbrook read a paper “Cast Fillings”.
    In 1908, Dr JG Lane developed casting into a hot mold
using an investment with a high silica content.
    In 1909, Dr CS Van Horn evaluated wax expansion, this
was an attempt to overcome the effects of shrinkage of the
gold alloy.
    In 1930, Dr Carl Scheu discovered the phenomenon of
hygroscopic setting expansion.
    Dr GV Black’s principles of cavity preparation were                                 Fig. 12.2: Onlay
vital to success of cast metal restorations then as they are
today.
Inlay: An inlay is an indirect intracoronal restoration which
is fabricated extraorally and cemented in the prepared tooth.
Inlay may cover none, or all but one cusp of a tooth.
Onlay: An onlay is a combination of intracoronal and
extracoronal cast restoration which covers one or more
cusps.
Class II inlay: Class II inlay essentially involves proximal
surface or surfaces of a posterior tooth, usually may involve
occlusal surface and also may involve facial and/or lingual
surface(s) and covers none or may cover all but one cusp
of a tooth (Fig. 12.1).
Class II onlay: Class II onlay is a modification of the inlay
and involves the proximal surface or surfaces, and may                  Fig. 12.3: Crown given on root canal treated tooth

                                                 INDICATIONS OF METAL INLAY AND ONLAY                               •   Cast metal restorations are much more wear resistant
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                        than direct composite restorations, especially when
                                                 •   In extensive proximal surface caries in posterior teeth

                                                     distribute occlusal forces.                                        can be strengthened by the adhesive bonding of indirect

                                                     and contour and for occlusal plane correction.                     stresses.
                                                 •   When there are other teeth present already restored with       •   Extraoral polishing is easy.

Inlay Taper                                                         preparations, the axis of taper is perpendicular to the long

To have unhindered removal and placement of the wax                 the tapered preparation walls to a point of their intersection
pattern and seating of the final casting, intracoronal and
extracoronal tooth preparation should have some taper.
Ideally, a tooth preparation should have slight diverging walls
from gingival to occlusal surface. This is the concept of
taper (Fig. 12.6).

                                                 angle.
                                                                                                                         Objective of bevel is to form a metal wedge of 30° to
                                                                                                                     35°, thus enhancing the chance to achieve closure at the
                                                 Circumferential Tie
                                                                                                                     interface of cast gold and tooth (Fig. 12.9). By beveling, a
                                                 Circumferential tie refers to the design of cavosurface margin      strong enamel margin with an angle of 140° to 150° can be
                                                 of an inlay tooth preparation. This junction between tooth          produced.
                                                 cement inlay is the weakest part of the cast metal restoration.     Types of bevel (Figs 12.10A to G): According to shape and
                                                 For the success of restoration, the margins of restoration          type of tissue involved, bevels can be:
                                                 should be designed so as to achieve its maximum adaptation          a. Ultrashort or partial bevel
                                                 to tooth structure. Cavosurface margins of an inlay                     • Beveling of less than two-third of the total enamel
                                                 preparation can be of two types:                                            thickness.
                                                 1. Bevels                                                               • Used to trim the enamel rods from preparation
                                                 2. Flares.                                                                  margins.
                                                                                                                         • Used in type I casting alloys.
                                                 Bevels                                                              b. Short bevel
                                                 Bevel is defined as the inclination that one surface makes              • Beveling of full thickness of enamel wall but not
                                                 with another when not at right angles. An accurate wax                      dentin.
                                                 pattern and casting may not have précise adaptation to the              • Used mostly for restorations with types I and II
                                                 margins of tooth preparation if bevel is not given.                         casting alloys.




                                                                                   Figs 12.10A to G: Diagrammatic representation of different bevels
                                                                                                                                      231
c. Long bevel




                                                                                                                                      Cast Metal Restorations
   • Includes full thickness of enamel and half or less
       than half thickness of dentin.
   • Preserves the internal “boxed up” resistance and
       retention features of the preparations.
   • Used in types I, II and III of cast gold alloys.
d. Full bevel
   • Includes full enamel and dentinal wall.
   • It deprives the preparation of its internal resistance
   • Full bevel should be avoided except in cases where
       it is a must.
e. Hollow ground (concave) bevel
   • Hollow ground is concave in shape and not a bevel
       in true sense.
   • It is rarely used.                                              Fig. 12.12: Marginal bevels reduce the space between tooth
                                                                       structure and the restoration, thus help in better retention
f. Counter bevel
   • Used when capping of the cusps is done to protect
       and support them.
   • It is opposite to an axial wall of the preparation on
       the facial or lingual surface of the tooth.               •   Beveling increases retention, resistance, aesthetics and
   • It has a gingival inclination facially or lingually.            color matching.
g. Reverse or inverted bevel in anterior teeth: It is beveling   •   It improves junctional relationship between the resto-
   in the reverse or inverted shape given on the gingival            rative material and tooth (Fig. 12.12).
   seat in the axial wall toward the root in anterior teeth.     •   The types of margin of tooth preparation depends mainly
h. Reverse or inverted bevel in posterior teeth: In posterior        on the compressive strength, edge strength and tensile
   teeth (in MOD preparations for full cast metal resto-             strength of the restorative material.
   rations), it is used to prevent tipping of cast restoration   •   Bevels are the flexible extensions, i.e. they allow inclu-
   and to increase the resistance and retention form.                sion of faults, wear facets, etc. without overextending

• By beveling, weak enamel is removed.                           •   Gingival margins become finishable and cleansable

  cavosurface angle of 135° to 140° forms the strongest          •   Counter bevel increases the resistance form to remaining
  and the bulkiest configuration.                                    tooth structure.

                                                 Flares                                                          Advantages of secondary flare:
                                                                                                                 • Secondary flare encourages self-cleansing margins
                                                 Flares are concave or flat peripheral portions of the facial
                                                                                                                    because it is extended into the embrasures.
                                                 or lingual proximal walls. These are of two types:
                                                                                                                 • Permits easy finishing of the restoration.
                                                 Primary flare: It is basic part of circumferential tie. It is   • Allows better burnishing of the metal.
                                                 like a long bevel and is always directed 45° to the inner       • Produces more blunted and stronger margins.
                                                 dentinal wall proper (Fig. 12.14).
                                                 Indications:                                                    STEPS OF TOOTH PREPARATION FOR INLAY
                                                 • Primary flare is indicated when normal contacts are           The following steps are involved in the tooth preparation
                                                    present.                                                     for class II inlay:
                                                 • When there is minimal extension of caries in bucco-
                                                    lingual direction.                                           Occlusal Outline Form
                                                 Functions:                                                      Anesthetize the tooth and apply a rubber dam to give better
                                                 • Weak enamel is removed.                                       visibility, tissue retraction, and ease of operation. Penetrate
                                                 • Improves junctional relationship between the restorative      the tooth with no. 271 bur held parallel to long axis of the
                                                   material and tooth.                                           tooth. The entry point should be closest to the involved
                                                 • Maintains the marginal seal.                                  marginal ridge (for example, mesial) (Fig. 12.16). First
                                                 • Brings the facial and lingual margins to cleansable and
                                                   finishable areas.
                                                 Secondry flare:
                                                 • It is a flat plane superimposed peripherally to the primary
                                                    flare (Fig. 12.14).
                                                 • It may have different angulations, involvement and extent
                                                    depending upon requirement.
                                                 • Secondary flare is not given in the areas where esthetics
                                                    is more important.
                                                 Indications of secondary flares:
                                                 • When broad contact area is present.
                                                 • To include the faults present on facial and lingual walls

                                                 Resistance and Retention Form
                                                 •   A nicely designed inlay preparation should have proximal
                                                     box form for retention and flat pulpal and gingival walls
                                                     for resistance to dislodging forces.
                                                 •   The extrathickness of gold provided by the box form
                                                     and the occlusal step of the preparation helps in increasing
                                                     its retention and resistance.
                                                 •   The occlusal dovetail of the preparation also provides
                                                     added retention to the restoration.
                                                 •   The resistance and retention form of the occlusal step                     Fig. 12.23: Retention grooves are placed
                                                     of the preparation will often require variations in design                    in linguo- and facioaxial line angles

The Gingival Bevel                                                                   Fig. 12.26: Occlusal bevel
It is advantageous to place a gingival bevel of approximately
45° to inlay preparations (Fig. 12.24). It should be made         walls (Fig. 12.26). The purpose of the bevel is to remove
smooth and uniformly placed with the help of double ended         any irregularities in the preparation or unsupported enamel
gingival marginal trimmers. The gingival bevel should include     rods at the cavosurface margin (Fig. 12.27). This gives the
one-half the width of the gingival wall. A properly placed        cavosurface margin a smooth, flowing outline. When the
gingival bevel eliminates the possibility of leaving weak or      cusps are steep, little or no bevel is placed (Fig. 12.28), but
unsupported enamel on gingival wall. It provides a stronger       when shallow cusps are present, a more distinct bevel is
obtuse angle of tooth structure which aids in finishing of        placed.
the casting and a design which lends itself to a more efficient       When it is required to cover a cusp with cast metal,
sealing of the margins of the restoration. Failure to bevel       prepare a hollow ground bevel using a #7404 twelve-fluted,
the gingival margin can result in formation of weak margins       round ended bur. This allows bulk of the restoration at the
because of presence of undermined rods (Fig. 12.25).              cavosurface margin.
Gingival bevels more than 45° results in over extension of            Finally finishing of walls and margins is done by
the gingival and proximal margins which causes difficulty         removing all unsupported enamel.
in impression making, fabricating the wax pattern and                 The final stage of inlay preparation is to clean the
finishing of the restoration.                                     preparation thoroughly with water and air spray. Then dry

                                                                                                                            For Esthetic Reasons
                                                                                                                            In teeth which are esthetically important, for example,
                                                                                                                            maxillary premolars and first molars, the class II preparation
                                                                                                                            involving mesioproximal side indicates less mesiofacial flare
                                                                                                                            for the minimal or no metal exposure.

                                                                                                                            In Maxillary Molars with
                                                                                                                            Unaffected and Strong Oblique Ridge
                                                                                                                            In maxillary molars, oblique ridge provides strength to the
                                                                                                                            tooth. If the oblique ridge is sound and unaffected by caries,
                                                                                                                            then it is always preferred to preserve it while doing tooth
                                                                                                                            preparation. This helps in maintaining the strength of the
                                                             Fig. 12.29: Completed inlay tooth preparation                  tooth. In this way, if tooth preparation is to be done on both
                                                                                                                            mesial and distal sides, two separate preparations are made
                                                 being able to finish an acute angle of tough malleable gold                instead of one MOD (Fig. 12.31).
                                                 alloy against an obtuse angle of tooth structure.

                                                 MODIFICATIONS IN CLASS II TOOTH
                                                 PREPARATION FOR INLAY

                                                 In Mandibular First Premolar
                                                 As we know, anatomy of the mandibular first premolar is
                                                 different which requires special attention during tooth
                                                 preparation. For example:
                                                 • Small lingual cusp may require cusp capping whenever
                                                     indicated (Fig. 12.30).
                                                 • Occlusal depth should not be more than 2 mm.
                                                 • Occlusal transverse ridge is involved when it is defective
                                                     or when tooth is too small.
                                                 • If transverse ridge is strong, smooth and without a faulty
                                                     central groove, then it should be conserved while                      Fig. 12.31: If oblique ridge is unaffected by caries, two separate
                                                     preparing a proximal preparation.                                      preparations can be made on both sides of ridge instead of one MOD

Capping of Cusp
                                                                   1. Grooves (Figs 12.33A and B): Grooves are placed to
Cusp capping is indicated when occlusal caries is extensive            provide additional retention and resistance to lateral
involving most of the cusp, resulting in weakened cusps                displacement of mesial, distal, facial or lingual part of
and/undermined enamel. When removal of carious                         the restoration.
structures results in loss of the occlusal surface more than               Internal grooves are given when preparation is shallow
half the distance from primary groove to the cusp tip, the             and small. They are contraindicated when preparation
capping of the cusps is desirable and capping is mandatory             is deep with the danger of pulp involvement.
if two-thirds or more of this distance, is involved.
    Cusp capping prevents fracture of the underlying tooth
structure since occlusal margins of the preparation are
placed away from strong occlusal forces.

Steps
•   Cusp reduction should be started after making a groove
    (Fig. 12.32). Groove helps in accurate and uniform
    cutting. Different cusps require reduction according to
    the situation of a particular cusp, in other words all cusps
    do not require equal reduction.
•   While reducing the adjacent cusp, lingual or buccal
    developmental groove should be involved in cutting.

mum intercuspal position and in all lateral and protrusive
movements should be evaluated before and after tooth             Interim restoration is given to the prepared tooth for the
preparation. After the tooth preparation, the impression of      time period between tooth preparation and cementing the
the prepared and adjacent teeth is taken using an elastomeric    restoration so as to protect and stabilize it and to provide

gingival retraction cord should be applied first for better          An interim restoration should have the following features:
recording of gingival margins of the preparation.                • Nonirritating
    Requirements of a material to be used for final              • Esthetically satisfactory
impression are that it should:                                   • Easy to clean and maintain
                                                                 • Protect and maintain the health of periodontium
• Be able to become elastic after placement
                                                                 • Adequate strength and retention to withstand the
• Have adequate strength
                                                                     masticatory forces.
• Have dimensional accuracy, stability and reproduction
                                                                     Normally, the interim restorations are made up of acrylic
    of details.
                                                                 resin. They can be prepared by direct and indirect methods.

                                                                 Direct Techniques
                                                                 •   Take preoperative impression of the patient.
                                                                 •   Prepare the tooth.
                                                                 •   Pour the tooth colored self-cure acrylic resin in the
                                                                     preoperative alginate impression in the prepared tooth
                                                                     area.
                                                                 •   Seat the impression onto the prepared tooth and remove
                                                                     it after resin is cured.
                                                                 •   Do final finishing and polishing of temporary.
                                                                 Advantage: Takes less time.
                                                                 Disadvantage: Pulp and periodontal tissue may get trauma
                                                                 from heat produced by direct polymerization of the acrylic
          Fig. 12.38: Rubber base impression material            and its monomer.

                                                                                                                  • Have a smooth nonabradable surface.

                                                     no. 1). Preserve this impression in humid conditions by
