                                                                                                                  Electroformed Dies
                                                 Advantages
                                                                                                                  Electrodeposition of copper or silver on the impression gives
                                                 • Better marginal accuracy.                                      a high strength, adequate hardness and good abrasion
                                                 • Since polymerization takes place outside the mouth, pulp       resistance to the cast.
                                                    and periodontal tissues are not traumatized by heat of
                                                    polymerization and monomer.                                   Electroforming (Electroplasting/Electrodeposition): This
                                                 • Resin cannot be locked on preparation surface of tooth         is a process by which a thin coating of metal is deposited
                                                                                                                  on the impression after which a gypsum cast is poured into
                                                    in small undercuts and in the cervical areas.
                                                                                                                  the impression. The cast obtained will have hard metallic
                                                 • Less chair side time.
                                                                                                                  surface.

                                                                                                                  • Copper
                                                 Working cast is an accurate replica of the prepared and          • Silver
                                                 adjacent unprepared teeth over which cast metal restoration
                                                 can be fabricated.                                               Indications

                                                 are used since they have superior properties. For making a       •   Individual tooth impression
                                                 working cast with removable dies, twice pouring of cast is       •   Full (upper/lower) arch impression.
                                                 required from an elastic impression. The first cast prepares     Epoxy resins: They are supplied in two—paste and liquid

                                                 intraarch relationship called “master cast”. These casts are     impression. They are mixed just before using the material.
                                                 known as split casts.                                            On mixing, they form a viscous paste and poured into
                                                                                                                  impression. The abrasive resistance, strength, and repro-

Wax Pattern Fabrication                                        Direct Wax Pattern without Use of Matrix Band




                                                                                                                            Cast Metal Restorations
There are two methods for wax pattern fabrication:             Here the technique is same except that matrix band is not
• Direct wax pattern method: In this wax pattern is            used during fabrication of wax pattern. In this, after the
   prepared in the oral cavity.                                carving of occlusal portion is done, use dental floss to
• Indirect wax pattern method: In this wax pattern is          remove extra wax from the proximal portion and to produce
   prepared outside the oral cavity.                           proper contact and contour.
                                                               Advantages
Direct Wax Pattern Method
                                                               • Less chances of discrepancies.
Direct wax pattern produces better fitting than indirect       • Less laboratory time.
method. This method is possible only in inlays and onlays
                                                               Disadvantages
and not in crowns and bridges, etc.
                                                               • Requires more chair side time.
Direct wax pattern using matrix band:                          • Requires more skill.
• Isolate the tooth using cotton rolls.                        • Finishing and polishing done on prepared tooth.
• Apply matrix band and retainer. Coat the internal surface
   of band using separating media like vaseline.               Indirect Wax Pattern Method
• For making direct wax pattern, type I inlay wax is used.
                                                               Indications
• Soften the inlay wax by heating and moving it over a
                                                               • Large preparations like onlays, full coverage crowns
   alcohol flame.
                                                                  and MOD restoration.
• Compress the softened inlay wax into the prepared tooth
                                                               • Insufficient access and visibility.
   for few minutes with finger pressure. This technique is
                                                               • When minute details like skirts and collars are present.
   called “compression technique”.
• Since cooling of wax to the mouth temperature results        Steps for fabricating:
   in shrinkage, it can be compensated by holding the wax      • Use type II inlay wax for indirect wax pattern.
   in the preparation under finger pressure until it reaches   • Lubricate the die using any lubricating fluid. The
   mouth temperature.                                             lubricator should produce a very thin separator film.
• Remove excess of wax and do the carving. With a hot          • Adapt the inlay wax to the die by flowing or by the
   egg burnisher, contour the occlusal portion of the wax         compression technique.
   pattern.                                                    • Do the carving using a warm instrument.
• Now remove the matrix band and retainer carefully            • Attach a sprue former to the wax pattern to the thickest
   without disturbing the wax pattern.                            portion as in direct method.
• Ask the patient to bite in centric occlusion for a few       Advantages
   seconds after placing a thin layer of cotton soaked in      • Less chair side time.
   warm water.                                                 • Finishing and polishing can be done on die.
• Examine the occlusal surface for high points and remove
   them. Do the occlusal carving.                              Disadvantages
• Pass a floss through the contact area while holding the      • More laboratory work.
   pattern in place.                                           • Errors in cast can result in inadequate casting.
• Smoothen the proximal surface of the pattern with fine
   soft silk.                                                  Spruing (Fig. 12.39)
• Evaluate and correct all the margins of the pattern.         Principles of Optimal Sprue Design

   excess of wax over the gingival margin. Add positive        •   A sprue former can be made up of:

After completion of casting, the casting ring is removed         •   Evaluate the embrasures and judge the points where
from the casting machine and quenched.                               proximal recontouring is required. Contacts can be
    Quenching involves rapid cooling at room temperature             present too occlusally, broad faciolingually or
water bath or ice water bath. It does not allow sufficient           occlusocervically (Figs 12.42A to D).
time for atomic movements to form an ordered structure.          •   Pass the dental floss through the contact to find out the
This disordered structure is retained at room temperature,           tightness of the contact and its locations.
making it soft and ductile. This helps in final adjustments
easier.

Advantages of Quenching
•   Easy removal of casting from casting ring due to cracking
    of investment material.
•   Keeps the gold alloy in annealed state for easy burnishing
    and polishing.
Pickling: The surface of casting usually appears dark due
to presence of oxides and other contaminants. This type of
film can be removed by method known as “pickling”.
Pickling is process in which discolored casting is heated        Figs 12.41A and B: (A) Proper occlusion tends to stabilize the cast
with an acid in test tube or beaker.                                      (B) Improper occlusion tends to deflect the tooth
244
                                                                                                                             To prevent postcementation pain:
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                             • Do not desiccate the tooth.
                                                                                                                             • Use the proper powder-to-liquid ratio.
                                                                                                                             • Do not remove the smear layer.
                                                                                                                             • Use a base material on deep areas of the preparation.
                                                                                                                             • Apply a resin dentin-desensitizer.
                                                                                                                             • Avoid overfilling the casting with cement.
                                                                                                                             • Seat the casting gently.
                                                                                                                             • Protect the cement from moisture contamination.
                                                                                                                             • Clean up excess cement only after it has fully set; this
                                                                                                                                prevents the cement from being pulled out from
                                                                                                                                underneath margins.

•   The direction of sprue former should be adjusted to




                                                                                                                                 Cast Metal Restorations
    45°.
•   Several pattern should not be placed closely together in
    a single ring as expansion of wax can cause breakdown
    of investment material.
•   High temperature of molten alloy causes surface
    roughness.
•   Casting pressure should be according to manufacture’s
    recommendation given for various types of casting
    machines.
•   Foreign bodies should be avoided during investment of
    material.

Distortion
Distortion of casting usually occurs due to distortion of
inlay wax pattern. The coefficient of thermal expansion of                       Fig. 12.43: Incomplete casting

inlay wax is high. Distortion of wax pattern increases, if it
is improperly handled. Time lag between making of pattern
and investing is also crucial during casting.
                                                                Discoloration
Causes                                                          The casting usually appears dark after removing from the
                                                                investment due to presence of oxides. This can be usually
•   Distortion of wax pattern.
                                                                be removed by process known as “Pickling”.
•   Mishandling of pattern.
•   Due to unequal movement of walls of wax pattern while       Causes
    the investment is setting.
                                                                •   Prolonged heating: Heating the investment above 700°C
Preventions                                                         usually causes breakdown of investment as well as
                                                                    formation of sulfur compounds, which causes
•   Proper manipulation of wax pattern.                             blackening of the cast.
•   Wax pattern should be immediately invested after
                                                                •   Sulfur content of torch flame also affects the casting.
    fabrication.
                                                                •   Underheating of the investment also leaves the wax
                                                                    residues in the casting, affects the color of the casting.
Incomplete Casting and Rounded
                                                                •   Contamination with copper during the process of pickling
Margins (Fig. 12.43)
                                                                    causes discoloration.
Causes
•   Inadequate heating of the alloy.                            Preventions
•   Inadequate casting pressure.                                •   Avoid prolonged heating of the investment.
•   Improper length and diameter of sprue.                      •   Change the source of flame.
•   Improper burnout of wax pattern.                            •   Proper heating should be done.
•   Insufficient molten alloy.                                  •   Tips of tongues must be covered with rubber to avoid
                                                                    contamination with copper during pickling.
Preventions
•   Alloy should be heated above fusion temperature, i.e.       Porosity
    570°C.
                                                                Porosity is considered as a major defect in the casting which
•   Casting pressure should be adequate to force the molten
                                                                can occur on the internal as well as on the external surface
    alloy.
                                                                of the casting. It usually weakens the casting.
•   Proper length and diameter of sprue former.
•   Proper burnout of wax pattern should be done so that        Various types of porosities can be:
    no carbon residues left in the mold.                        • Solidification shrinkage porosity
•   Adequate amount of molten alloy should be available for         a. Localized shrinkage porosity
    casting.                                                        b. Microporosity

                                                 •   Gaseous defects                                                      Preventions
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                     a. Gas inclusion porosity
                                                                                                                          •   Increase the casting temperature.
                                                     b. Pinhole porosity
                                                                                                                          •   Increase the melting temperature of alloy.
                                                 •   Backpressure porosity
                                                 •   Subsurface porosity.
                                                                                                                          Gaseous Defects
                                                 Solidification Shrinkage Defects                                         Two types of defects are seen:
                                                                                                                          1. Gas inclusion porosity: Gas inclusion porosity is spherical
                                                 Localized shrinkage porosity (Figs 12.44A and B): This
                                                                                                                             voids larger in size than pinhole porosity.
                                                 type of porosity occurs due to shrinkage of molten alloy
                                                                                                                          2. Pinhole porosity: Spherical voids, smaller in size than
                                                 when alloy solidifies from molten state. This can be avoided                gas inclusion porosity.
                                                 by providing adequate molten alloy to compensate casting
                                                 shrinkage.                                                               Causes
                                                 Causes                                                                   These are usually caused by entrapment of gas in alloy
                                                                                                                          various causes are:
                                                 •   If direction of sprue former is at 90°, then it will cause           • Not using the reducing zone of flame.
                                                     “hot spot” in the casting, i.e. alloy will remain in molten          • Poor adjustment of torch flame.
                                                     state at that spot whilst solidifies everywhere else.
                                                 •   Diameter of sprue is too narrow.                                     Preventions
                                                 •   Length of sprue former is long, i.e. molten alloy
                                                     prematurely solidifies in the sprue before reaching to               •   Use reducing zone of the flame.
                                                     mold.                                                                •   Position of torch flame should be correctly adjusted.
                                                 •   Absence of reservoir.
                                                                                                                          Backpressure Porosity
                                                 Preventions                                                              It usually occurs on the inner surface of the casting due to
                                                 •   Direction of sprue former should be at 45°.                          entrapment of gases.
                                                 •   Avoid using excessively long and narrow sprue former.
                                                 •   Use reservoir.                                                       Causes
                                                 Microporosity: It is usually seen in fine grain molten metal             •   Use of dense investment material.
                                                 alloy castings. This usually happens due to solidification               •   Low casting temperature.
                                                 shrinkage of molten alloy.                                               •   Low casting pressure.
                                                                                                                          •   Improper wax burnout.
                                                 Causes
                                                 •   Too low casting temperature.                                         Preventions
                                                 •   Rapid solidification of molten alloy.
                                                                                                                          Use of porous investment material:
                                                                                                                          • Adequate casting temperature.
                                                                                                                          • Adequate casting pressure.
                                                                                                                          • Proper wax burnout.

                                                                                                                          Subsurface Porosity
                                                                                                                          Causes: Simultaneous nucleation of solid grains and gas
                                                                                                                          bubbles when the metal freezes at mold walls.
                                                                                                                          Prevention: Can be prevented by controlling the flow at
                                                                                                                          which molten alloy enters the mold space.

Indications for Pin Retained Cast Restorations

Pin retained cast restorations are indicated in following
cases:                                                          Q.   What are functions of primary flare?
• When occlusogingival height is very short.                    Q.   Where is primary flare indicated?

                                                                Q.   Where is secondary flare indicated?

   are to be prepared.                                          Q.   What are advantages of secondary flare?
• When the proximal box is very long. The pin channel is        Q.   How does on inlay achieve retention and resistance
   prepared at the other end of occlusal lock.                       form?
• In full crown preparation when one wall is very short
   and another wall is very long. In these cases, pin channel   Q.   What should be the angle of gingival bevel for
   is prepared towards the shorter wall.                             inlay?
• For shallow and wide preparations, when it is not possible    Q.   What are commonly used impression materials
   to place surface extensions for retention.                        for taking inlay impression?
• In very thin and fragile teeth where extensive tooth

   preparation can be detrimental.
• In absence of gingival floor, resistance and retention        Q.   What is working cast?
   can be achieved by use of pins.                              Q.   Define “Die”.

INTRODUCTION
By definition, pulp is a soft tissue of mesenchymal origin
residing within the pulp chamber and root canals of teeth.
    Some important features of pulp are as follows
(Fig. 13.1):
• Pulp is located deep within the tooth, so defies
    visualization.
• It gives radiographic appearance as radiolucent line.
• Pulp is a connective tissue with several factors making
    it unique and altering its ability to respond to irritation.
• Normal pulp is a coherent soft tissue, dependent on its
    normal hard dentin shell for protection and hence, once
    exposed, extremely sensitive to contact and temperature
    but this pain does not last for more than 1-2 seconds
    after the stimulus removed.                                         Fig. 13.1: Diagrammatic representation of dental pulp
250
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                      Fig. 13.2: Bacteria from caries resulting in pulpal irritation          Fig. 13.3: Involvement of pulp via periodontal pocket



                                                 •   Since pulp is totally surrounded by a hard tissue, dentin             – Thermal changes generated by cutting procedures,
                                                     which limits the area for expansion and restricts the                     during restorative procedures, bleaching of enamel,
                                                     pulp’s ability to tolerate edema.                                         microleakage occurring along the restorations,
                                                 •   The pulp has almost a total lack of collateral circulation,               electrosurgical procedures, laser beam, etc. can cause
                                                     which severely limits its ability to cope with bacteria,                  severe damage to the pulp, if not controlled.
                                                     necrotic tissue and inflammation.                                     – Orthodontic movement
                                                 •   The pulp possess unique cells the odontoblasts, as                    – Periodontal curettage
                                                     well as cells that can differentiate into hard-tissue                 – Periapical curettage
                                                     secreting cells that form more dentin and/or irritation               – Use of chemicals like temporary and permanent
                                                     dentin in an attempt to protect itself from injury.                       fillings, liners and bases and use of desiccants such
                                                                                                                               as alcohol.
                                                 PULPAL IRRITANTS                                                      •   Idiopathic
                                                                                                                           – Aging
                                                 Various pulpal irritants can be :                                         – Resorption—internal or external.
                                                 • Bacterial irritants: Most common cause for pulpal
                                                    irritation are bacteria or their products which may enter
                                                                                                                       EFFECT OF DENTAL CARIES ON PULP
                                                    pulp through a break in dentin either from:
                                                    – Caries (Fig. 13.2)                                               Dental caries is the most common route for causing irritation
                                                    – Accidental exposure                                              to the pulp. Dental caries is localized, progressive, decay of
                                                    – Fracture                                                         the teeth characterized by demineralization of the tooth
                                                    – Percolation around a restoration                                 surface by organic acids, produced by microorganisms.
                                                    – Extension of infection from gingival sulcus                      From the carious lesion, acids and other toxic substances
                                                    – Periodontal pocket and abscess (Fig. 13.3)                       penetrate through the dentinal tubules to reach the pulp.
                                                    – Anachoresis (Process by which microorganisms                     The following defense reactions take place in a carious tooth
                                                    get carried by the bloodstream from another source                 to protect the pulp:
                                                    localize on inflamed tissue).                                      1. Formation of reparative dentin.
                                                 • Traumatic                                                           2. Dentinal sclerosis, i.e. reduction in permeability of dentin
                                                    – Acute trauma like fracture, luxation or avulsion of                  by narrowing of dentinal tubules.
                                                         tooth                                                         3. Inflammatory and immunological reactions.
                                                    – Chronic trauma including parafunctional habits like                  The rate of reparative dentin formation is related to rate
                                                         bruxism.                                                      of carious attack. More reparative dentin is formed in
                                                 • Iatrogenic: Various iatrogenic causes of pulpal damage              response to slow chronic caries than acute caries. For dentin
                                                    can be:                                                            sclerosis to take place, vital odontoblasts must be present
                                                                                                                                       251
                                                                        1. Revolutions per minute (RPM), i.e. more the RPM more




                                                                                                                                       Pulp Protection
                                                                           is the heat production. In deep penetrations of dentin
                                                                           without using coolants, e.g. pin holes, the cutting speed
                                                                           must not exceed 3,000 rpm.
                                                                        2. Pressure: It is directly proportional to heat generation.
                                                                           Whenever, the RPM’s are increased, pressure must be
                                                                           correspondingly reduced.
                                                                        3. Surface area of contact: It is related to the size and
                                                                           shape of the revolving tool. The more the contact
                                                                           between the tooth structure and revolving tool, the more
                                                                           is the heat generation.
                                                                        4. Desiccation: If occurring in vital dentin, can cause
                                                                           aspiration of the odontoblasts into the tubules. The
                                                                           subsequent disturbances in their metabolism may lead
      Fig. 13.4: Formation of irritation dentin in response to caries      to the complete degeneration of odontoblasts. Coolant
                                                                           sprays should be used even in nonvital or devitalized
                                                                           tooth structures, since the heat will burn the tooth
within the tubules. In dentin sclerosis, the dentinal tubules              structures.
are partially or fully filled with mineral deposits, thus reduce
the permeability of dentin. Therefore, dentinal sclerosis act           Vibrations
as a barrier for the ingress of bacteria and their product
(Fig. 13.4).                                                            Vibrations are measured by their amplitude or their capacity
                                                                        and frequency (the number/unit time). Vibrations are an
EFFECT OF TOOTH PREPARATION ON PULP                                     indication of eccentricity in rotary instruments. The higher
                                                                        the amplitude, the more destructive may be the response of
                   Factors affecting response of                        the pulp.
                     pulp to tooth preparation                              In addition to affecting the pulp tissues, vibration can
 1.    Pressure                                                         create microcracks in enamel and dentin.
 2.    Heat production
 3.    Vibrations                                                       Remaining Dentin Thickness
 4.    Remaining dentin thickness
 5.    Speed of rotation                                                Remaining dentin thickness (RDT) between the floor of the
 6.    Nature of cutting instruments.                                   tooth preparation and the pulp chamber is one of the most
                                                                        important factor in determining the pulpal response. This
Pressure                                                                measurement differs from the depth of tooth preparation
The pressure of instrumentation on exposed dentin                       since the pulpal floor in deeper preparation on larger teeth
characteristically causes the aspiration of the nuclei of the           may be far from the pulp than that in shallow preparations
odontoblasts or the entire odontoblasts themselves or nerve             on smaller teeth.
endings from pulp tissues into the dentinal tubules. This
                                                                                    Remaining dentin thickness (RDT)
will obviously stimulate odontoblasts, disturb their
metabolism and may lead to their complete degeneration                   •   In human teeth, dentin is approximately 3 mm thick
and disintegration. This can occur by excessive pressure                 •   Dentin permeability increases with decreasing RDT
of hand or rotary instruments, especially in decreased                   •   RDT of 2 mm or more effectively precludes restorative
effective depths.                                                            damage to the pulp
                                                                         •   At RDT of 0.75 mm, effects of bacterial invasion are
Heat Production                                                              seen
                                                                         •   When RDT is 0.25 mm, odontoblastic cell death is seen.
Heat production is the second most damaging factor. If the
pulp temperature is elevated by 11°F, destructive reaction                 The amount of remaining dentin underneath the tooth
will occur even in a normal, vital periodontal organ. That              preparation plays the most important role in the incidence
“heat” is a function of;                                                of a pulp response. Generally, 2 mm of dentin thickness
252
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                            Fig. 13.5: As dentin thickness decreases,
                                                                   the pulp response increases


                                                 between the floor of the tooth preparation and the pulp will
                                                 provide an adequate insulting barrier against irritants (Fig.
                                                 13.5). As the dentin thickness decreases, the pulp response
                                                 increases. It is seen that response of cutting occurs only in
                                                 areas beneath freshly cut dentinal tubules not lined with
                                                 reparative or irregular dentin. In presence of reparative dentin
                                                                                                                                Fig. 13.6: Pathways of marginal leakage
                                                 only minimal response will occur.

                                                 Speed of Rotation                                                  •   Heat generated during setting
                                                                                                                    •   Poor marginal adaptation leads to bacterial penetration
                                                 Ultra high-speed should be used for removal of enamel and
                                                                                                                    •   Cytotoxicity of material.
                                                 superficial dentin. A speed of 3,000 to 30,000 rpm without
                                                 coolant can cause pulpal damage. It should be kept in mind         PULP PROTECTION PROCEDURES
                                                 that without the use of coolant there is no safe speed. High
                                                 speed without coolant can produce burning of dentin, which         Pulp needs protection against various irritants as following
                                                 in turn affect the integrity of the pulp.                          (Fig. 13.7):
                                                                                                                    • Thermal protection against temperature changes
                                                 Nature of Cutting Instrument                                       • Electrical protection against galvanic currents
                                                                                                                    • Mechanical protection during various restorative
                                                 Use of worn off and dull instruments should be avoided.
                                                                                                                       procedures
                                                 Damaged cutting edges cause vibration and reduced cutting
                                                                                                                    • Chemical protection from toxic components
                                                 efficiency.                                                        • Protection from microleakage interface between tooth
                                                     Use of dull instruments encourages the dentist to                 and the restoration.
                                                 use excessive operating pressure, which results in increased
                                                 temperature. This can result in thermal injury to pulp.            Pulp Protection in Shallow and
                                                                                                                    Moderate Carious Lesions
                                                 EFFECT OF CHEMICAL IRRITANTS ON PULP
                                                                                                                    In a moderate carious lesion, caries penetrates the enamel
                                                 The pulp is subjected frequently to chemical irritation from       and may involve one-half of the dentin, but not to the extent
                                                 materials generally used in dentistry. Various filling materials
                                                 produce some irritation ranging from mild-to-severe, as do
                                                 various medicaments used for desensitization or dehydration
                                                 of the dentin.
                                                     Properties of a material that could cause pulpal injury
                                                 are its cytotoxic nature, acidity, heat evolved during setting
                                                 and marginal leakage (Fig. 13.6).

                                                 Factors Influencing the Effect of
                                                 Restorative Materials on Pulp
                                                 •   Acidity
                                                 •   Absorption of water from dentin during setting                      Fig. 13.7: Need of pulp protection from various irritants

of endangering the pulp. In these cases, to protect the pulp,

Pulp Protection in Deep Carious Lesions                         • History of spontaneous toothache.
In deep carious lesion, caries can reach very near or up to     • Tooth sensitive to percussion.
the pulp, so treatment of deep carious lesion requires          • Mobility present.

Depending upon the condition, following methods for pulpal        graphically.
protection are employed.                                        Clinical techniques
                                                                • Band the tooth if tooth is grossly decayed.
In Moderately Deep Carious Lesions                              • Anesthetize the tooth.
If hard dentin is present between carious lesion and the        • Apply rubber dam to isolate the tooth.
pulp and there is no threat to pulpal health after caries       • Remove soft caries either with spoon excavator or round
removal, give protective cement base and complete the              bur.
permanent restoration as though it was a moderate lesion.       • A thin layer of dentin and some amount of caries is left
                                                                   to avoid exposure.
Indirect Pulp Capping                                           • Place calcium hydroxide paste on the exposed dentin.
                                                                • Cover the calcium hydroxide with zinc oxide eugenol
Indirect pulp capping is a procedure performed in a tooth
                                                                   base (Fig. 13.10).
with deep carious lesion adjacent to the pulp (Fig. 13.9). In
this procedure, all the carious tissue is removed except the
soft undiscolored carious dentin which is adjacent to the
pulp. Caries near the pulp is left in place to avoid pulp
exposure and preparation is covered with a biocompatible
material.
Indications
• Deep carious lesion near the pulp tissue but not involving
   it.
• No mobility of tooth.
• No history of spontaneous toothache.
• No tenderness to percussion.
• No radiographic evidence of pulp pathology.
• No root resorption or radicular disease should be present        Fig. 13.10: Placement of calcium hydroxide and zinc oxide
   radiographically.                                                    eugenol dressing after excavation of soft caries
254
                                                                                                                   Contraindications
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                   • Wide pulp exposure
                                                                                                                   • Radiographic evidence of pulp pathology
                                                                                                                   • History of spontaneous pain
                                                                                                                   • Presence of bleeding at exposure site.
                                                                                                                   Clinical procedures
                                                                                                                   • Administer local anesthesia.
                                                                                                                   • Isolate the tooth with rubber dam.
                                                                                                                   • When vital and healthy pulp is exposed, check the fresh
                                                                                                                      bleeding at exposure site.
                                                                                                                   • Clean the area with distilled water or saline solution and
                                                                                                                      then dry it with a cotton pellet.
                                                                                                                   • Apply calcium hydroxide (preferably Dycal) over the
                                                                                                                      exposed area.
                                                                                                                   • Give interim restoration such as zinc oxide eugenol for
                                                                  Fig. 13.11: Direct pulp capping
                                                                                                                      6-8 weeks.
                                                                                                                   • After 2 to 3 months, remove the cement very gently to
                                                                                                                      inspect the exposure site. If secondary dentin formation
                                                 •   If restoration is to be given for a longer time, then            takes place over the exposed site, restore the tooth
                                                     amalgam restoration should be given.                             permanently with protective cement base and restorative
                                                 • Tooth should be evaluated after 6-8 weeks.                         material. If favorable prognosis is not there, pulpotomy
                                                 • After 2 to 3 months, remove the cement and evaluate                or pulpectomy is done.
                                                     the tooth preparation. If due to remineralization and/or

                                                     formation of secondary dentin, the soft dentin has
                                                                                                                   depends are as follows:
                                                     become hard, then remove any residual soft debris and
                                                                                                                   1. Age of the patient: Due to vascularity of the pulp, young
                                                     then finally give protective cement base and place the           patients have greater potential for success than older
                                                     permanent restorative material.                                  ones.

                                                 age of the patient, size of the exposure, restorative procedure      has better prognosis than exposure caused by caries,
                                                 and evidence of pulp vitality. In young patients, the potential      due to less pulpal inflammation and deleterious effect of

                                                                                                                   MATERIALS USED FOR PULP
                                                 tooth preparation or following a trauma, an appropriate           PROTECTION (FIG. 13.12)
                                                 protective base should be placed in contact with the exposed
                                                 pulp tissue so as to maintain the vitality of the remaining       Various materials are used to:
                                                 pulp tissue (Fig. 13.11).                                         • Insulate the pulp
                                                                                                                   • Protect the pulp in case of deep carious lesion
                                                 Indications                                                       • Act as barriers to microleakage
                                                 • Small mechanical exposure of pulp during                        • Prevent bacteria and toxins from affecting the pulp.
                                                    – Tooth preparation.                                               The term varnish, sealer, liner and base is applied for
                                                    – Traumatic injury.                                            these materials. Terminology of pulp protective materials
                                                 • No or minimal bleeding at the exposure site.                    according to thickness of material:
                                                                                                                              255




                                                                                                                              Pulp Protection
      Fig. 13.12: Different materials used for pulp protection    Fig. 13.13: Dentin bonding agent to seal dentinal tubules


1. Solution liner (include varnish and adhesive sealer):
   Thin film of 2-5 µm thickness.
2. Suspension liner: Relatively thin film of 20-30 µm
   thickness.
3. Cement liner: Medium thickness of 100-500 µm
   thickness.
4. Cement base: Thick film of 500-1000 µm thickness.
   McCoy (1995) gave following definitions for these
terms:
1. Sealer: These materials provide a protecting covering
   the walls of tooth preparation and act as barrier to leakage
   occurring at restoration tooth interface.
   These can be :
   • Varnish: A varnish is an organic gum or rosin sus-
       pended in organic solutions like ether or chloroform.
   • Adhesive sealer: These help in sealing and adhesion
       at the tooth restoration interface. For example, dentin                      Fig. 13.14: Varnish
       bonding agent and resin luting cements (Fig. 13.13).
2. Liners: They are applied in thin layer of less than
   0.5 mm so as to attain a physical barrier to pulp and to
   provide therapeutic effect.
3. Bases: They are applied in an attempt to replace the lost
   dentin and to provide thermal, physical and therapeutic
   advantages to the pulp.

Varnish
A varnish is an organic copal or resin gum suspended in
solutions of ether or chloroform (Fig. 13.14). When applied
on the tooth surface the organic solvent evaporates leaving
behind a protective film (Fig. 13.15).                            Fig. 13.15: Varnish is applied on prepared tooth surface
256
                                                     Varnish liner is used for pulp protection and reduction
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                 of leakage. On drying, varnish acts as an inert plug between
                                                 the tooth and restoration.
                                                     In case of amalgam restoration, varnish improves the
                                                 sealing ability of the amalgam, reduces postoperative
                                                 sensitivity and prevents discoloration of tooth by checking
                                                 ion migration into the dentin. If base is to be given or casting
                                                 is to be cemented by zinc phosphate cement, varnish
                                                 application is advantageous as it will block the seepage due
                                                 to the available acid. Use of varnish is contraindicated under
                                                 glass ionomers as they interfere the bonding of tooth to
                                                 these cements. With restorative resins varnish is not used                  Fig. 13.16: Calcium hydroxide linear is applied in an
                                                                                                                               attempt to stimulate reparative dentin formation
                                                 because the varnish liners dissolve in the monomer of the
                                                 resin and also they interfere in their polymerization process.
                                                                                                                      Types of Liners
                                                                    Indications for use of varnish
                                                                                                                      Following three materials are most commonly used as liners:
                                                     •    To seal the dentinal tubules                                • Zinc oxide eugenol liners
                                                     •    To act as barrier to protect the tooth from chemical        • Calcium hydroxide
                                                          irritants from cements
                                                                                                                      • Flowable composites
                                                     •    To reduce microleakage around restorations.
                                                                                                                      • Glass ionomers.

                                                                           Contraindication                           Zinc Oxide Eugenol Liners
                                                     •    Contraindicated under composite resin and glass             Many dental materials containing eugenol and zinc oxide
                                                          ionomer restorations.
                                                                                                                      are used as liners. Eugenol is used to alleviate pain from
                                                 Adhesive Sealer                                                      mild to moderate inflammation of pulp. Though in low
                                                                                                                      concentration, it acts as obtundant but in high concentration
                                                                                                                      it acts as chemical irritant. When used as liner, there is
                                                                     Indications for use of sealer
                                                                                                                      release of eugenol for first few days of setting, therefore,
                                                     •    To seal dentinal tubules                                    this liner is not preferred especially in moderately deep tooth
                                                     •    To treat dentin hypersensitivity.                           preparations.
                                                                                                                          Zinc oxide eugenol liners should not be used under
                                                     An adhesive sealer is commonly used under indirect               composite restorations since they inhibit polymerization of
                                                 restorations. For application, cotton tip applicator is used         bonding agent and composite.
                                                 to apply sealer on all areas of exposed dentin.
                                                                                                                      Calcium hydroxide: Calcium hydroxide has been used as
                                                 Liners (Fig. 13.16)                                                  liner in deep preparations cavities because of its following
                                                                                                                      features:
                                                 Liners are typically fluid materials that, because of their          1. It causes dentin mineralization by activating the enzyme
                                                 rheology, can adapt more readily to all aspects of a tooth               ATPase.
                                                 preparation. They can be used to create a uniform, even              2. It stimulates reparative dentin formation.
                                                 surface that aids in adaptation of more viscous filling              3. It forms a mechanical barrier, when applied to dentin.
                                                 materials such as amalgams or composites.                            4. Because of high pH, it neutralizes acidity of silicate and
                                                    Liners usually do not have sufficient thickness, hardness             zinc phosphate cements.
                                                 and strength to be used alone in the deep preparation.               5. Calcium hydroxide dissociates into Ca2+ and OH– ions,
                                                                                                                          the OH– ions neutralize the (H+) hydrogen ions from
                                                 Indications of Use of Liners
                                                                                                                          acids of cement.
                                                 •       To protect pulp from chemical irritants by sealing ability   6. Biocompatible in nature
                                                 •       To stimulate formation of reparative dentin.                 7. Bactericidal in nature.
                                                                                                                                    257
Limitations: It has low strength, high solubility thus when




                                                                                                                                    Pulp Protection
it is exposed to the oral environment (e.g. due to leakage) it
will dissolve. This limits its use over only small areas
requiring pulp protection. Sometimes glass ionomer or zinc
phosphate base is applied over it to prevent its dissolution.
Flowable composites: Flowable composites are the
composites with a lower amount of filler. This reduced filler
content allows more fluid consistency, less strength and
lower modulus than fully filled composites.
    They are primarily used under composite restorations
and in crown and bridge preparations to block out undercuts
                                                                           Fig. 13.17: Base is applied over liner as pulp
prior to impression taking.                                                   protective material in deep preparations
Advantages of using flowable composites as liners:
• Adaptation to preparation walls because of their flow              Bases should have sufficient strength so as to withstand
• Placement ease since the materials are injected directly       forces of mastication and condensation of permanent
   into the preparation                                          restorations. Bases can be classified as following:
• Esthetic
                                                                 1. Protective bases: They protect the pulp before resto-
• Consistency.
                                                                     ration is placed.
Disadvantages of flowable composites:                            2. Sedative bases: They help in soothing the pulp which
• Technique sensitive                                                has been irritated by mechanical, chemical or other
• Requires maintenance of contamination free field
                                                                     means.
• Polymerization shrinkage can result in gap formation at
                                                                 3. Insulating bases: They protect the tooth from thermal
   resin-tooth interface.
                                                                     shock.

                                                                                                                   Precautions to be Taken While Using
                                                                                                                   Amalgam as a Restorative Material
                                                                                                                   •   Use of varnish or dentin bonding agent at the margins
                                                                                                                       of restoration if more than 2 mm of remaining dentin
                                                                                                                       thickness is present.
                                                                                                                   •   Use of liner or base under the silver amalgam restoration
                                                                                                                       when remaining dentin thickness is 0.5 to 2 mm.
                                                                                                                   •   Use of calcium hydroxide as sub-base (0.5-1 mm)
                                                                                                                       covered with a base material in preparations with less
                                                                                                                       than 0.5 mm remaining dentin thickness.
                                                               Fig. 13.18: Zinc carboxylate cement
                                                                                                                   Restorative Resins
                                                 Polycarboxylate Cement (Fig. 13.18)                               Restorative resins have been used in dentistry for past many
                                                 Zinc polycarboxylate cement contains modified zinc oxide          years. Despite of having several advantages, they are not
                                                 powder and an aqueous solution of polyacrylic acid. It            considered best materials because of their high coefficient
                                                 chemically bonds to enamel and dentin and has antibacterial       of thermal expansion and polymerization shrinkage, which
                                                 properties. Polycarboxylate cement is well tolerated by the       results in marginal leakage, subsequently the recurrent caries
                                                 pulp. Varnish should not be used with polycarboxylate             and ultimately the pulp damage. Monomer present in
                                                 cement because it would neutralize the adhesion potential         composite resins also acts as an irritant to the pulp.
                                                 of the cement.

                                                 Glass Ionomer Cement                                              Composite Resin as a Restorative Material

INTRODUCTION




                                                                                                                                   Basics of Endodontics
Endo is a Greek word for “Inside” and Odont is Greek
word for “Tooth”. Endodontic treatment treats inside of
the tooth.
    Endodontics is the branch of clinical dentistry associated
with the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of the pathosis
of the dental pulp and their sequelae.

  Main aim of the endodontic therapy involves to:
   i. Maintain vitality of the pulp.
  ii. Preserve and store the tooth with damaged and necrotic
      pulp.
 iii. Preserve and restore the teeth which have failed to the
      previous endodontic therapy, to allow the tooth to remain
      functional in the dental arch.
                                                                        Fig. 14.1: Normal anatomy of a tooth showing enamel,
                                                                                      dentin, cementum and pulp
           Features of pulp which distinguish it from
            tissue found elsewhere in the body
 a. Pulp is surrounded by rigid walls and so is unable to              Pulpal reaction to microbial irritation (Fig. 14.3)
    expand in response to injury as a part of the                  Carious enamel and dentin contains numerous bacteria
    inflammatory process (Fig.14.1). Therefore, pulpal
                                                                                                 ↓
    tissue is susceptible to a change in pressure affecting
                                                                     Bacteria penetrate in deeper layers of carious dentin
    the pain threshold.
 b. There is minimal collateral blood supply to pulp tissue                                      ↓
    which reduces its capacity for repair following injury.        Pulp is affected before actual invasion of bacteria via their
 c. The pulp is composed almost entirely of simple                                       toxic byproducts
    connective tissue, yet at its periphery there is a layer of                                  ↓
    highly specialized cells, the odontoblasts. Secondary                Byproducts cause local chronic cell infiltration
    dentin is gradually deposited as a physiological                                             ↓
    process which reduces the blood supply and therefore,             When actual pulp exposure occurs pulp tissue gets
    the resistance to infection or trauma.                         locally infiltrated by PMN’s to form an area of liquefaction
 d. The innervation of pulp tissue is both simple and                              necrosis at the site of exposure
    complex. Simple in that there are only free nerve
                                                                                                 ↓
    endings and consequently the pulp lacks
    proprioception. Complex because of innervation of the            Eventually necrosis spreads all across the pulp and
    odontoblast processes which produces a high level of           periapical tissue resulting in severe inflammatory lesion.
    sensitivity to thermal and chemical change.

                                                                                                                      Manufacturing of Hand Instruments
                                                            Fig. 14.2: Response of pulp to various irritants
                                                                                                                      A hand operated instrument reamer or file begins as a round
                                                                                                                      wire which is modified to form a tapered instrument with
                                                                                                                      cutting edges. Several shapes and forms of such instruments
                                                                                                                      are available. These are manufactured by two techniques:
                                                                                                                      a. By machining the instrument directly on the lathe for
                                                                                                                          example H-file and NiTi instruments are machined.
                                                                                                                      b. By first grinding and then twisting. Here the raw wire is
                                                                                                                          ground into tapered geometric blanks, i.e. square,
                                                                                                                          triangular or rhomboid. These blanks are then twisted
                                                                                                                          counterclockwise to produce cutting edges.

                                                                                                                      Standardization of Instruments
                                                      Fig. 14.3: Gradual response of pulp to microbial invasion       given by Ingle and Levine
                                                                                                                      Ingle and Levine using and electronic microcomparator
                                                                                                                      found variation in the diameter and taper for same size of
                                                                                                                      instrument. They suggested few guidelines for instruments
                                                                                                                      for having uniformity in instrument diameter and taper
                                                                                                                      (Fig. 14.4). The guidelines were:
                                                                                                                      • Instruments are numbered from 10-100. There is
                                                                                                                          increase in 5 units up to size 60 and in 10 units till they
                                                                                                                          are size 100.
                                                                                                                      • Each number should represent diameter of instrument
                                                                                                                          in 100th of millimeter at the tip.
                                                                                                                      • Working blade shall begin at tip (D1) and extend 16 mm
                                                                                                                          up the shaft (D2). D2 should be 0.32 mm greater than
                                                 Fig. 14.4: Diagrammatic representation of an endodontic instrument       D1, ensuring that there is constant increase in taper, i.e.
                                                            in accordance with ANSI specification No. 57
                                                                                                                          0.02 mm per mm of instrument.
                                                                                                                      • Instruments handles should be color coded for their
                                                                                                                          easier recognition (Pink, gray, purple, white, yellow, red,
                                                 Group II     :   Latch type Engine driven: Same design as                blue, green, black………….)
                                                                  group I but can be attached to handpiece.           • Instruments are available in following length : 21 mm,
                                                 Group III :      Drills or reamers latch type engine driven              25 mm, 28 mm, 30 mm and 40 mm. 21 mm length is
                                                                  for example Gates-Glidden, Peeso reamers.               commonly used for molars, 25 mm for interiors, 28
                                                 Group IV :       Root Canal points like gutta-percha, silver             and 30 mm for canines and 40 mm for endodontic
                                                                  point, paper point.                                     implants.

Modifications from Ingle’s
Standardization (Fig. 14.5)
•     An additional diameter measurement point at D 3 is
      3 mm from the tip of the cutting end of the instrument
      at D0 (Earlier it was D1).                                          Fig. 14.6: Color coding of endodontic instruments
•     Tip angle of an instrument should be 750 ± 150.
•     Greater taper instruments (0.04, 0.06, 0.08—) have also
      been made available.

                                                 •     Extirpation of pulp tissues (Fig. 14.8).
                                                 •     Removal of cotton or paper points lodged in the canal.

                                                 Reamers (Figs 14.9A and B)
                                                 1. Reamers are K-type instruments (manufactured by Kerr
                                                    company), which are used to ream the canals. They cut
                                                    by inserting into the canal, twisting clockwise one
                                                    quarter to half turn and then withdrawing, i.e.
                                                    penetration, rotation and retraction.
                                                                                                                                Fig. 14.10: Triangular blank and lesser
                                                 2. Reamers have triangular blank and lesser number of                                number of flutes in reamer
                                                    flutes than files (Fig. 14.10). Numbers of flutes in reamer
                                                    are ½-1/mm, while in files the flutes are 1½-2½/mm.
                                                 3. Though reamer has fewer numbers of flutes than file,
                                                    cutting efficiency is same as that of files because more
                                                    space between flutes causes better removal of debris
                                                    (Fig. 14.11).

                                                                    Disadvantage of K-files
    Files are predominantly used with filing or rasping action
in which there is little or no rotation in the root canals. It is   1. Less cutting efficiency.
placed in root canal and pressure is exerted against the canal      2. Extrusion of debris periapically.
wall and instrument is withdrawn while maintaining the
pressure (Fig. 14.12).

Commonly Used Files
•   K-files
•   K-flex files
•   Hedstrom files
•   Safety H-files

K-files (Fig. 14.13)
•   They are triangular, square or rhomboidal in cross-
    section, manufactured from stainless steel wire, which
    is grounded into desired shape (Fig. 14.14).

                                                                                                                   NiTi was developed by Buchler 40 years ago. NiTi is also
                                                                                                                   known as the NiTinol (NiTi Navol Ordinance Laboratory in
                                                      Fig. 14.26: Use of Gates-Glidden drill for coronal flaring
                                                                                                                   US). In endodontics commonly used NiTi alloys are called
                                                                                                                   55 NiTinol (55% weight Ni and 45% Ti) and 60 NiTinol
                                                                                                                   (60% weight of Ni, 40% Ti).
                                                                                                                       First use of NiTi in endodontics was reported in 1988,
                                                 3. During instrument removal, if used incorrectly for             by Walia et al when a 15 No. NiTi file was made from
                                                    example using at high rpm, incorrect angle of insertion,       orthodontic wire and it showed superior flexibility and
                                                    forceful drilling, the use of Gates-Glidden can result in      resistance to torsional fracture. This suggested the use of
                                                    procedural accidents like perforations, instrument             NiTi files in curved canals.
                                                    separation, etc.
