                                                                                                                 portion, i.e. pulp chamber (Fig. 14.35) reflects the external
                                                                                                                 from of crown. The roof of pulp chamber consists of dentin
                                                                                                                 covering the pulp chamber occlusally or incisally. The floor
                                                                                                                 of pulp chamber merges into the root canal at the orifices.
                                                                                                                 Thus, canal orifices are the openings in the floor of pulp
                                                                                                                 chamber leading into the root canals (Fig. 14.36).

                                                                                                                 Pulp Horns
                                                                                                                 Pulp horns are landmarks present occlusal to pulp chamber.
                                                                                                                 Pulp horn tends to be single horn associated with each cusp
                                                 ACCESS CAVITY PREPARATION                                       of posterior teeth and mesial and distal in anterior teeth.

                                                 Pulp Cavity                                                     Pulp Chamber
                                                 The pulp cavity lies within the tooth and is enclosed by        It occupies the coronal portion of pulp cavity. It acquires
                                                 dentin all around except at the apical foramen. It is divided   shape according to shape and size of crown of the tooth,
                                                 into two—a coronal and a radicular portion. The coronal         age of person, and irritation, if any.
                                                                                                                       271
Canal Orifice




                                                                                                                       Basics of Endodontics
Canal orifices are openings in the floor of pulp chamber
leading into root canals.

Root Canal
The root canal extends from canal orifice to the apical
foramen. In anterior teeth, the pulp chamber merges into
the root canal (Fig. 14.37) but in multirooted posterior teeth
this division becomes quite obvious (Fig. 14.38).
Apical root anatomy: It is based on following anatomic
and histological landnarts in the apical part of the root canal:
    i. Apical constriction (Minor diameter): It is apical
       part of root canal having the narrowest diameter short
       of the apical foramina or radiographic apex. It may or      Fig. 14.37: Root canal anatomy of anterior tooth
       may not coincide with CDJ.
   ii. Apical formen (Major diameter): It is main apical
       opening on the surface of root canal through which
       blood vessels enter the canal. Its diameter is almost
       double the apical constriction giving it a funnel shape
       appearance, witch has been described as morning
       glory or hyperbolic. Average distance between minor
       and major diameter in young person is 0.5 mm and in
       older person, it is 0.7 mm.
  iii. Cementodentinal junction: Cementodentinal
       junction is the point in the canal, where cementum
       meets dentin. The position of CDJ varies but usually
       it lies 0.1 mm from the apical foramen (Fig. 14.39).

Definition of Access Cavity Preparation
Access cavity preparation is defined as endodontic coronal
preparation which enables unobstructed access to the canal
orifices, a straight line access to apical foramen, complete
control over instrumentation and to accommodate obturation         Fig. 14.38: Root canal anatomy of posterior tooth

technique.
    The main objective of the access cavity preparation is
to create a smooth, straight line access to the canal system
and the apex. The optimal access cavity results in the straight
entry into the canal orifices with line angles forming a funnel
which drops smoothly into the canals (Fig. 14.40).

 An ideal access preparation should have following
    qualities:
 1. An unobstructed view into the canal.
 2. A file should pass into the canal without touching any
    part of the access cavity.
 3. No remaining caries should be present in access cavity.
 4. Obturating instruments should pass into the canal
    without touching any portion of the access cavity.
                                                                         Fig. 14.39: Cementodentinal junction

                                                    handpiece against the radiograph. This is done so as to                sense when dropping into the pulp chamber (Fig. 14.44).
                                                    note the position and depth of the pulp chamber (Fig.               3. When locating the canal orifices is difficult, one should
                                                    14.42).                                                                not apply rubber dam until correct location has been

                                                    form. The bur is penetrated into the crown until the                4. Remove all the unsupported tooth structure to prevent

                                                                                                                                  273




                                                                                                                                  Basics of Endodontics
                Fig. 14.44: Access preparation                         Fig. 14.46: Complete access cavity preparation




                  Fig. 14.45: Access refining                       Fig. 14.47: Straight line access to root canal system


5. Remove the chamber roof completely as this will allow
   the removal of all the pulp tissue, calcifications, caries
   or any residuals of previous fillings (Fig. 14.45). If pulp
   chamber is not completely deroofed, it can result in:
   a. Contamination of the pulp space.
   b. Discoloration of endodontically treated tooth.
6. The walls of pulp chamber are flared and tapered to
   form a gentle funnel shape with larger diameter towards
   occlusal surface (Fig. 14.46).
7. Endodontic access cavity is prepared through the
   occlusal or lingual surface never through proximal or
   gingival surface. If access cavity as made through
   wrong entry, it will cause inadequate canal instru-
   mentation resulting iatrogenic errors (Figs 14.47 and
   14.48).                                                       Fig. 14.48: Correct position for entering into the pulp cavity
274

                                                    magnification and illumination.                                       penetrated, bur is directed parallel to the long axis of the
                                                                                                                          tooth, until “a drop” in effect is felt (Fig. 14.50).
                                                     Laws of access cavity preparation for locating canal             • Now when pulp chamber has been penetrated, the
                                                     orifices                                                             remainder of chamber roof is removed by working a
                                                     Law of centrality: Floor of pulp chamber is always located           round bur from inside to outside. This is done to remove
                                                     in the center of tooth at the level of cementoenamel junction.       all the obstructions of enamel and dentin overhangs that
                                                     Law of cementoenamel junction: Distance from external                would entrap debris, tissues and other materials.
                                                     surface of clinical crown to the wall of pulp chamber is         • Now locate the canal orifices using endodontic explorer.
                                                     same through out the tooth circumference at the level of
                                                     CEJ.
                                                                                                                          Sharp explorer tip is used to locate the canal orifices, to
                                                                                                                          penetrate the calcific deposits if present, and also to
                                                     Law of concentricity: Walls of pulp chamber are always
                                                     concentric to external surface of tooth at the level of CEJ.
                                                                                                                          evaluate the straight line access.
                                                     This indicates anatomy of external tooth surface reflects        • Once the canal orifices are located, the lingual shoulder
                                                     the anatomy of pulp chamber.                                         is removed using Gates-Glidden drills or safe tipped
                                                     Law of color change: Color of pulp chamber floor is darker           diamond or carbide burs. Lingual shoulder is basically a
                                                     than the cavity walls.                                               prominence of dentin formed by removal of lingual roof
                                                     Law of symmetry: Usually canal orifices are equidistant              which extends from the cingulum to approximately
                                                     from a line drawn in mesial and distal direction through of          2 mm apical to the orifice (Fig. 14.51).
                                                     floor of pulp chamber.                                               During the removal of lingual shoulder, the orifice should
                                                     Law of orifice location: Canal orifices are located at the       also be flared so that it becomes confluent with all the walls
                                                     junction of floor and walls, and at the terminus of root         of access cavity preparation. By this a straight line access
                                                     development fusion lines.                                        to the apical foramen is attained, i.e. an endodontic file can
                                                                                                                      reach up to apical foramen without bending or binding to
                                                 ACCESS CAVITY OF ANTERIOR TEETH                                      the root canal wall. Any deflection of file occurs should be
                                                 •     The access cavity shape varies with size and shape             corrected because it can lead to instrumental errors (Fig.
                                                       accordingly the internal anatomy of the pulp chamber,          14.52). The deflected instruments work under more stress,
                                                       so internal anatomy of tooth must be determined before         more chance of instrument separation is there. Deflected
                                                       starting the treatment.                                        instruments also result in procedural accidents like canal
                                                 •     Remove all the caries and any defective restorations so        transportations, perforations, ledging and zipping.
                                                       as to prevent contamination of pulp space as well as to
                                                       have a straight line access into the canals.
                                                 •     Access opening is started at center of the lingual surface
                                                       (Fig. 14.49). If it is made too small and too close to the
                                                       cingulum the instrument tends to bind the canal walls
                                                       and thus may not work optimally.




                                                                 Fig. 14.49: Access opening is initiated                         Fig. 14.50: Once enamel is penetrated, bur
                                                                       at center of lingual surface                                is directed parallel to long axis of tooth
                                                                                                                                          275
                                                                             Since, the outline form of access cavity reflects the




                                                                                                                                          Basics of Endodontics
                                                                         internal anatomy of the pulp space, though technique of the
                                                                         access opening of anterior teeth is the same, the shape may
                                                                         vary according to internal anatomy of each tooth.

                                                                         Maxillary Central Incisor
                                                                         The outline form of access cavity of maxillary central incisor
                                                                         is a rounded triangular shape with base facing the incisal
                                                                         aspect (Fig. 14.53). The width of base depends upon the
                                                                         distance between mesial and distal pulp horns. Shape may
                                                                         change from triangular to slightly oval in mature tooth
                                                                         because of less prominence of mesial and distal pulp horns.

                                                                         Maxillary Lateral Incisor
                                                                         The shape of access cavity is almost similar to that of
                                                                         maxillary central incisor except that:
                                                                            i. It is smaller in size.
Fig. 14.51: Lingual shoulder is prominence of dentin formed by lingual
roof. It extends from cingulum to 2 mm apical to the canal orifice         ii. When pulp horns are present, shape of access cavity
                                                                               is rounded triangle.
                                                                          iii. Generally the pulp horns are missing so shape of access
                                                                               cavity which results is oval.

                                                                         Maxillary Canine
                                                                         Shape of access cavity of canine though is quite similar to
                                                                         incisors with following differences:
                                                                             i. Canine does not have pulp horns.
                                                                            ii. Access cavity is oval in shape with greater diameter
                                                                                labiopalatally (Fig. 14.54).

                                                                         Mandibular Incisors
                                                                         Mandibular central and lateral incisors are similar in shape
                                                                         of access cavity and the root canal system. Shape of access
                                                                         cavity of mandibular incisors is different from maxillary
                                                                         incisors in following aspects (Fig. 14.55):
                                                                             i. It is smaller in shape.
          Fig. 14.52: Improper access cavity preparation                    ii. Shape is long oval with greatest dimensions directed
                 causing deflection of instrument
                                                                                incisogingivally.


•   After the straight line access of the canal is confirmed
    by passing a file passively into the canal, one should
    evaluate the access cavity using magnification and
    illumination.
•   Finally smoothening of the cavosurface margins of
    access cavity is done because rough or irregular cavity
    margins can cause coronal leakage through restorations.
    Also smooth cavity margins allow better and précised
    placement of final composite restoration with minimal
    coronal leakage.                                                          Fig. 14.53: Outline of access cavity of maxillary incisor

ACCESS CAVITY PREPARATION FOR
MAXILLARY MOLARS
Though the technique of access cavity preparation of molar
is similar to that of anterior teeth and premolar but because
of anatomic differences, they are discussed separately.

                                                                                                                            Methods of determining working length

                                                                                                                           Radiographic Method of Working
                                                                                                                           Length Determination
                                                 •       If placed in correct limits, it plays an important role in
                                                         determining the success of treatment.                             This technique was first introduced by John Ingle. When
                                                 •       Once apical stop is calculated, monitor the working length        radiographs are used in determining working length the
                                                         periodically because working length may change as                 quality of the image is important for accurate interpretations.
                                                         curved canal is straightened.                                         Among the two commonly used techniques, paralleling
                                                 •       Failure to accurately determine and maintaining working           techniques have been demonstrated as superior to bisecting
                                                         length may result in length being over or short of apical         angle technique in determination and reproduction of apical
                                                         constriction.                                                     anatomy.
                                                                                                                               Before studying the X-rays for endodontics, under-
                                                     Consequences of overextended working length                           standing of buccal object rule is essential. The basic concept
                                                     •    Perforation through apical construction                          of the rule is that as the vertical or horizontal angulation of
                                                     •    Over instrumentation                                             X-ray tube changes, the object buccal or closest to tube
                                                     •    Overfilling of root canal                                        head moves to opposite side of radiograph compared to the
                                                     •    Increased incidence of postoperative pain                        lingual object. To separate buccal and lingual roots (for
                                                     •    Prolonged healing period                                         example in maxillary first premolar) to visualize the working
                                                     •    Lower success rate due to incomplete regeneration of
                                                          cementum, periodontal ligament and alveolar bone.
                                                                                                                           length, tube head should be moved from a 20o mesial
                                                                                                                           angulation. This captures the buccal root to the opposite or
                                                                                                                           distal side of radiograph and lingual root on mesial side of
                                                     Consequences of working short of actual working length
                                                     • Incomplete cleaning and instrumentation of the canal                the radiograph. It is also known as SLOB rule that is same
                                                     • Persistent discomfort due to presence of pulpal                     lingual opposite buccal.
                                                        remnants                                                               Before access opening, fractured cusps, cusps
                                                     • Underfilling of the root canal                                      weakened by caries or restorations are reduced to avoid
                                                     • Incomplete apical seal                                              fracture of weakened enamel during the treatment. This

tooth surface or carious tooth structure. These should be first removed

                                                                                     Fig. 14.66: Complicated root canal anatomy




                                                                                   Fig. 14.67: Irrigation helps in loosening of debris



                                                                          IRRIGATION OF ROOT CANAL SYSTEM
                                                                          It’s truly said, “Instruments shape, irrigants clean”. Every
                                                                          root canal system has spaces that cannot be cleaned
                                                                          mechanically. The only way we can clean webs, fins and
                                                                          anastomoses is through the effective use of an irrigation
                                                                          solution (Fig. 14.66).

                                                                          Functions of Irrigants
                                                                          1. Irrigants perform physical and biologic functions. Dentin
                                                                             shavings get removed from canals by irrigation (Fig.
                                                                             14.67).
              Figs 14.65A to D: Radiographic method
                  of working length determination
                                                                          2. Instruments are less likely to break when canal walls
                                                                             are lubricated with irrigation.
                                                                          3. Irrigants act as solvent of necrotic tissue, so they loosen
4. On the radiograph measure the difference between the                      debris, pulp tissue and microorganisms from irregular
   tip of the instrument and root apex. Add or subtract this                 dentinal walls (Fig. 14.68).
   length to the estimated working length to get the new                  4. Irrigants help in removing the debris from accessory
   working length.                                                           and lateral canals where instruments cannot reach.
5. Correct working length is finally calculated by                        5. Most irrigants are germicidal but they also have
   subtracting 1 mm from this new length.                                    antibacterial action.
282
                                                 6. Irrigants also have bleaching action to lighten teeth          Disadvantages
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                    discolored by trauma or extensive silver restorations.
                                                                                                                   •     Does not possess dissolution and disinfecting properties.
                                                                                                                   •     Too mild to thoroughly clean the canals.
                                                 Commonly Used Irrigating Solutions
                                                                                                                   •     Cannot clear microbial flora from inaccessible areas like
                                                 Chemically Non-active Solution                                          accessory canal.
                                                                                                                   •     Does not possess antimicrobial activity.
                                                 •   Water                                                         •     Does not remove smear layer.
                                                 •   Saline
                                                 •   Local anesthetic                                              Sodium Hypochlorite
                                                                                                                   Sodium hypochlorite is a clear, pale, green-yellow liquid
                                                 Chemically Active Materials
                                                                                                                   with strong odor of chlorine (Fig. 14.69). It is easily miscible
                                                 •   Alkalis: Sodium hypochlorite 0.5-5.25%                        with water and gets decomposed by light.
                                                 •   Chelating agents: Ethylene diamine tetra-acetic acid
                                                                                                                       1. Introduced in World War Ist by Dakin.
                                                     (EDTA)
                                                                                                                       2. Walker-1936—First suggested its use in root canal
                                                 •   Oxidizing agents: Hydrogen peroxide, carbamide
                                                                                                                          therapy.
                                                     peroxide
                                                                                                                       3. Grossman-1941—Used it as an intracanal medica-
                                                 •   Antibacterial agents: Chlorhexidine, Bisdequalinium                  ment.
                                                     acetate                                                           4. Spangberg-1973-0.5%—NaOCl has good germicidal
                                                 •   Acids: 30% hydrochloric acid                                         activity.
                                                 •   Enzymes: Streptokinase, papain, trypsin                           5. Madden-1977—Compared the different concentrations
                                                 •   Detergents: Sodium laruyl sulphate.                                  of Sodium hypochlorite.
                                                                                                                       6. Foley et al-1983—Compared effectiveness of 0.5%
                                                 Normal Saline (Fig. 14.68)                                               NaOCl and Glyoxide.

                                                 Normal saline causes gross debridement and lubrication of
                                                 root canals. Since it very mild in action, it can be used as an   Mechanism of Action of Sodium Hypochlorite
                                                 adjunct to chemical irrigant.                                     •     At body temperature, reactive chlorine in aqueous
                                                                                                                         solution exists in two forms-hypochlorite (OCl–) and
                                                 Advantage                                                               hypochlorous acid (HOCl). State of available chlorine
                                                 It is biocompatible in nature. No adverse reaction even if              depends on pH of solution, i.e. above pH of 7.6, it is
                                                 extruded periapically because osmotic pressure of normal                mainly hypochlorite form and below this pH, it is
                                                 saline is same as that of the blood.                                    hypochlorous acid.

                                                                                                                                    Basics of Endodontics
    is responsible for breakdown of proteins into amino

    groups.
                                                                  •   Emulsification

    necrotic tissue because of its high alkaline nature (pH

Advantages of Sodium Hypochlorite                                 •   It inhibits growth of bacteria and ultimately destroys
                                                                      them by starvation because EDTA chelates with the
1. It causes tissue dissolution.
                                                                      metallic ions in medium which are needed for growth
2. It has antibacterial and bleaching action.
                                                                      of microorganisms.
3. It causes lubrication of canals.
                                                                  •   EDTA has self limiting action. It forms a stable bond
4. Economical.
                                                                      with calcium and dissolve dentin, but when all chelating
5. Easily available.
                                                                      ions have reacted, an equilibrium reached which prevents
                                                                      further dissolution.
Disadvantages
1. Because of high surface tension, its ability to wet dentin     Uses of EDTA
   is less.
                                                                  •   It has dentin dissolving properties
2. Irritant to tissues, if extruded periapically, it can result
                                                                  •   It helps in enlarging narrow canals
   in severe cellular damage.
                                                                  •   Makes easier manipulation of instruments
3. If comes in contact, it cause inflammation of gingiva
                                                                  •   Reduces time needed for debridement.
   because of its caustic nature.
4. It can bleach the clothes if spilt.                            BIOMECHANICAL PREPARATION
5. It has bad odor and taste.
6. Vapors of sodium hypochlorite can irritate the eyes.           Cleaning and shaping is one of the most important step in
7. It can be corrosive to instruments.                            the root canal therapy for obtaining success in the root
                                                                  canal treatment.
Chelating Agents (Fig. 14.70)
                                                                  Cleaning
Chelating agent is defined as a chemical which combines
with a metal to form chelate. EDTA is most commonly               It comprises the removal of all potentially pathogenic
used chelating agent. It was introduced in dentistry by           contents from the root canal system.
Nygaard Ostby for cleaning and shaping of the canals. It
contains four acetic acid groups attached to ethylenediamine.     Shaping
EDTA is relatively nontoxic and slightly irritating in weak       The establishment of a specifically shaped cavity which
solutions. The effect of EDTA on dentin depends on the            performs the dual role of three-dimensional progressive
concentration of EDTA solution and length of time it is in        access into the canal and creating an apical preparation
contact with dentin.                                              which will permit the final obturation instruments and
                                                                  materials to fit easily.
                                                                      The mechanics of cleaning and shaping may be viewed
                                                                  as an extension of the principles of coronal cavity preparation
                                                                  to the full length of the root canal system. Schilder gave
                                                                  five mechanical objectives for successful cleaning and
                                                                  shaping 30 years ago. The objectives taught the clinicians
                                                                  to think and operate in three dimensions.
                                                                      The objectives given by Schilder are (Fig. 14.71):
                                                                  1. The root canal preparation should develop a
                                                                      continuously tapering cone (Fig. 14.72): This shape
                                                                      mimics the natural canal shape. Funnel shaped prepara-
                   Fig. 14.70: Chelating agent                        tion of canal should merge with the access cavity so
284

                                                       Fig. 14.71: Diagrammatic representation of objectives
                                                                        of canal preparation




                                                                                                                      Fig. 14.74: Doubling the file size apically, increases
                                                                                                                            the surface area of foramen four times




                                                                                                                  overlapping of foramen contributes to number of
                                                                                                                  iatrogenic problems. Doubling the file size apically
                                                           Fig. 14.72: Prepared root canal shape should           increases the surface area of foramen four folds (πr2)
                                                                       be continuous tapered
                                                                                                                  (Fig. 14.74). This overlapping of apical foramen should
                                                                                                                  be avoided.
                                                    that instruments will slide into the canal. Thus, access
                                                                                                               Objectives of Biomechanical Preparation
                                                    cavity and root canal preparation should form a
                                                    continuous channel.                                        Biologic Objectives of Root Canal Preparation
                                                 2. Making the preparation in multiple planes which
                                                                                                               Biologic objectives of biomechanical preparation are to
                                                    introduces the concept of “flow”: This objective
                                                                                                               remove the pulp tissue, bacteria and their byproducts from
                                                    preserves the natural curve of the canal.
                                                                                                               the root canal space.
                                                 3. Making the canal narrower apically and widest
                                                    coronally: To create a continuous tapers up to apical

deeper into the canals to remove all the debris and contents
of root canal. This creates a smooth tapered opening to the
apical terminus for obtaining three-dimension obturation of
the root canal system.

Basic Principles of Canal Instrumentation
•    There should be a straight line access to the canal
     orifices. Creation of a straight line access by removing               Fig. 14.77: Techniques of biomechanical preparation
     overhang dentin influences the forces exerted by a file
     in apical third of the canal.
•    Files are always worked with in a canal filled with irrigant.
     Therefore, copious irrigation is done in between the            TECHNIQUES OF ROOT CANAL PREPARATION
     instrumentation, i.e. canal must always be prepared in
                                                                     Basically, there are two approaches used for biomechanical
     wet environment.
                                                                     preparation, either starting at the apex with fine instruments
•    Preparation of canal should be completed while retaining
                                                                     and working up to the orifice with progressively larger
     its original form and the shape (Fig. 14.76).
                                                                     instruments, this is Step back technique or starting at the
•    Canal enlargement should be done by using instruments
                                                                     orifice with larger instrument and working up to apex with
     in the sequential order without skipping sizes.
                                                                     larger instruments, this is Crown down technique
•    All the working instruments should be kept in confines
                                                                     (Fig. 14.77).
     of the root canal to avoid any procedural accidents.
•    Recapitulation is regularly done to loosen debris by
                                                                     Step Back Technique
     returning to working length. The canal walls should not
     be enlarged during recapitulation.                              Step back technique is also known as Telescopic canal
•    Over preparation and too aggressive over enlargement            preparation or serial root canal preparation. Step back
     of the curved canals should be avoided.                         technique emphasizes keeping the apical preparation small,
•    Never force the instrument in the canal. Forcing or             in its original position and producing a gradual taper coronally
     continuing to rotate an instrument may break the                (Fig. 14.78). This technique was first described in 1960 by
     instrument.                                                     Mullaney.
286
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry




                                                              Fig. 14.78: Tapered canal preparation                        Fig. 14.79: Tooth decay causing pulp exposure




                                                     Basically this technique involves the canal preparation
                                                 into two phases; phase I involves the preparation of apical
                                                 constriction and phase II involves the preparation of the
                                                 remaining canal.

                                                 Phase I

                                                 1. Evaluate the carious tooth before initiating endodontic
                                                    treatment (Fig. 14.79).
                                                 2. Initially prepare the access cavity, and locate the canal
                                                    orifices (Fig. 14.80).
                                                 3. Establish the working length of the tooth using pathfinder.
                                                 4. Now insert the first instrument into the canal with watch
                                                    winding motion. In watch winding motion, a gentle
                                                    clockwise and anticlockwise rotation of file with minimal     Fig. 14.80: Prepare the access cavity and locate the canal orifices

                                                    apical pressure is given (Fig. 14.81).
                                                 5. Remove the instrument and irrigate the canal.
                                                 6. Don’t forget to lubricate the instrument for use in apical
                                                    area because it is shown that lubricant emulsifies the
                                                    fibrous pulp tissue allowing the instrument to remove it
                                                    whereas irrigants may not reach the apical area to
                                                    dissolve the tissues.
                                                 7. Place the next larger size files to the working length in
                                                    similar manner and again irrigate the canal (Fig. 14.82).
                                                 8. Don’t forget to recapitulate the canal with previous
                                                    smaller number instrument. This breaks up apical debris
                                                    which are washed away with the irrigant.
                                                 9. Repeat the process until a size 25 K-file reaches the
                                                    working length (Fig. 14.83). Recapitulate between the
                                                    files by placing a small file to the working length (Fig.        Fig. 14.81: Watch winding motion with gentle clockwise and
                                                    14.84).                                                                        anticlockwise motion of the file
                                                                                                                  287
                                                Phase II




                                                                                                                  Basics of Endodontics
                                                1. Place next file in the series to a length 1 mm short of
                                                   working length. Insert the instrument into the canal with
                                                   watch winding motion, remove it after circumferential
                                                   filing, irrigate and recapitulate (Fig. 14.85).
                                                2. Repeat the same procedure with successively larger files
                                                   at 1 mm increments from the previously used file (Fig.
                                                   14.86).
                                                3. Similarly mid canal area and coronal part of the canal is
                                                   prepared and shaped with larger number files (Figs 14.87
                                                   and 14.88).
                                                4. Finally, refining of the root canal is done by master apical
                                                   file with push-pull strokes to achieve a smooth taper
                                                   form of the root canal (Fig. 14.89).

  Fig. 14.82: Place file to working length




 Fig. 14.83: 25 No. file at working length             Fig. 14.85: 30 No. file 1 mm short of working length




Fig. 14.84: Recapitulation using smaller file          Fig. 14.86: 35 No. file 2 mm short of working length
288
                                                                                                        Advantage of Step Back Technique
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                        More flare at coronal part of root canal with proper apical
                                                                                                        stop.

                                                                                                        Disadvantages of Step Back Technique
                                                                                                        1. Difficult to irrigate apical region.
                                                                                                        2. More chances of pushing debris periapically.
                                                                                                        3. Time consuming.
                                                                                                        4. Increased chances of iatrogenic errors for example ledge
                                                                                                           formation in curved canals.
                                                                                                        5. Difficult to penetrate instruments in canal.
                                                                                                        6. More chances of instrument fracture.

                                                                                                        Crown Down Technique

                                                                                                        In the crown down technique, the dentist prepares the canal
                                                 Fig. 14.87: 40 No. file 3 mm short of working length
                                                                                                        from crown of the tooth, does shaping of the canal while
                                                                                                        moving towards apical portion of the canal (Fig. 14.90).

                                                                                                        Techniques of Crown Down Preparation
                                                                                                        1. First step in the crown down technique is the access
                                                                                                           cavity preparation with no pulp chamber obstructions.
                                                                                                           Locate the canal orifices with sharp explorer which
                                                                                                           shows binding in the pulp chamber.
                                                                                                        2. Now fill the access cavity with an irrigant and start
                                                                                                           preflaring of the canal orifices. Preflaring of the coronal
                                                                                                           third of the canal can be done by using hand instruments,
                                                                                                           Gates-Glidden drills or the Nickle titanium rotary
                                                                                                           instruments.


                                                 Fig. 14.88: 45 No. file 4 mm short of working length




                                                     Fig. 14.89: 50 No. file for canal preparation                     Fig. 14.90: Crown down technique
                                                                                                                                      289
3. Gates-Glidden drills can be used after scouting the canal            progressively smaller number files deeper into the canal




                                                                                                                                      Basics of Endodontics
   orifices with number 10 or 15 files. The crown down                  in sequential order and prepare the apical part of the
   approach begins with larger Gates-Glidden first                      canal (Figs 14.94 and 14.95).
   (Fig. 14.91). After using this subsequent, smaller                7. Final apical preparation is prepared and finished along
   diameter Gates-Glidden are worked into the canal with                with frequent irrigation of the canal system.
   additional mm to complete coronal flaring.                           The classical apical third preparation should have a
4. Frequent irrigation with sodium hypochlorite and                  tapered shape which has been enlarged to at least size 20 at
   recapitulation with a smaller file (usually No. 10 file) to       apex and each successive instrument should move away
   prevent canal blockage.                                           from the foramen by 1/2 mm increments.

   explore the canal and establish the working length with           Biological Benefits of Crown Down Technique
   small instruments (Fig. 14.92).

   prepare it (Fig. 14.93). Subsequently introduce                      extrusion of debris periapically.




          Fig. 14.91: Use of Gates-Glidden for preflaring                  Fig. 14.93: Use of larger files to prepare coronal third




  Fig. 14.92: Establishing working length using a small instrument            Fig. 14.94: Preparation of canal at middle third
290
                                                                                                                  2. Flexible (smaller) files are used in apical portion of the
Textbook of Preclinical Conservative Dentistry


                                                                                                                     canal; where as larger (stiffer) files need not be forced
                                                                                                                     but kept short of the apex.
                                                                                                                  3. In curved canals, after doing coronal flaring, files can
                                                                                                                     go up to apex more effectively due to decrease deviation
                                                                                                                     of instruments in the canal curvature.
                                                                                                                  4. Provides more space of irrigants.
                                                                                                                  5. Straight line access to root curves and canal junctions.
                                                                                                                  6. Enhanced movement of debris coronally.
                                                                                                                  7. Desired shape of canal can be obtained that is narrow at
                                                                                                                     apex, wider at coronal.
                                                                                                                  8. Predictable quality of canal cleaning and shaping.
                                                                                                                  9. Decreased frequency of canal blockages.

                                                                                                                   Step back vs crown down technique

                                                                                                                   1. Apico-coronal technique         1. Coronoapical
                                                                                                                                                         technique
                                                                                                                   2. Has been used for past          2. Introduced recently
                                                                                                                      many year                          an gaining popularity
                                                                                                                   3. Starts with smallest            3. Starts with largest
                                                                                                                      instruments                        instruments
                                                                                                                   4. Shapes apical 1/3rd initially   4. Shapes coronal 1/3rd
                                                                                                                                                         initially
                                                                                                                   5. Commonly uses hand files        5. Commonly uses
                                                                                                                                                         rotary files



                                                                                                                  OBTURATION OF ROOT CANAL SYSTEM

                                                                                                                  Purpose of Obturation

                                                                                                                  1. To achieve total obliteration of the root canal space so
                                                      Fig. 14.96: Preflaring of canal causes removal of coronal       as to prevent ingress of bacterias and body fluids into
                                                                             interferences                            root canal space as well as egress of bacterias which
                                                                                                                      are left in canal.
                                                                                                                  2. To attain fluid tight seal so as to prevent bacterial
                                                 2. Reduction of postoperative sensitivity which could result
                                                                                                                      microleakage.
                                                    from periapical extrusion of debris.
                                                                                                                  3. To replace the empty root canal space with an inert
                                                 3. Greater volumes of irrigants can reach in canal
                                                                                                                      filling material so as to prevent recurrent infection.
                                                    irregularities in early stages of canal preparation because
                                                                                                                  4. To seal the root canal space as well as to have coronal
                                                    of coronal flaring.
                                                                                                                      seal for long-term success of root canal therapy.
                                                 4. Better dissolution of tissue with increased penetration
                                                                                                                      A three-dimensional well fitted root canal with fluid tight
                                                    of the irrigants.
                                                                                                                  seal is the main objective of the root canal obturation
                                                 5. Rapid removal of contaminated and infected tissues from
                                                                                                                  (Fig. 14.97). This helps in:
                                                    the root canal system.
                                                                                                                  a. Preventing percolation and microleakage of periapical
                                                                                                                      exudate into the root canal space.
                                                 Clinical Advantages of the
                                                                                                                  b. Preventing infection by completely obliterating the apical
                                                 Crown Down Technique
                                                                                                                      foramen and other portals of communication.
                                                 1. Enhanced tactile sensation with instruments because of        c. Creating a favorable environment for process of healing
                                                    removal of coronal interferences (Fig. 14.96).                    to take place.

                                                                   Lateral Compaction Technique
                                                                   It is one of the most common methods used for root canal
                                                                   obturation. It involves placement of tapered gutta-percha
                                                                   cones in the canal and then compacting them under pressure
                                                                   against the canal walls using a spreader. A canal should
                                                                   have continuous tapered shape with a definite apical stop,
                                                                   before it is ready to be filled by this method.

    Fig. 14.103: Lateral and vertical compaction of gutta-percha   Technique

                                                                      percha cone whose diameter is consistent with largest
                                                                      file used in the canal up to the working length. One
                                                                      should feel the tugback with master gutta-percha point

   • Eucalyptol

                                                                      – If cone fits short of the working length, check for
   • Vertical compaction technique

   • System B continuous wave condensation technique

                                                  • Overfilling of canals with gutta-percha or sealer from      they are more resistant to microbial penetration.
                                                     apex.                                                          Final restoration of endodontically treated tooth should

                                                     with alcohol to remove remnants of sealer or gutta-
                                                     percha.

                                                 Importance of Coronal Restoration
                                                                                                                QUESTIONS
                                                 Post endodontic coronal restoration is important to prevent
                                                 ingress of microorganisms into coronal pulp.                   Q.    What is endodontics?
                                                     To prevent coronal leakage the clinician should:
                                                 1. Temporarily seal the tooth during or after the treatment.   Q.    What are objectives of endodontics?
                                                 2. Provide adequate coronal restoration after treatment.       Q.    What is dental pulp?
                                                 3. Do long-term follow-up so as to evaluate the integrity
                                                                                                                Q.    What are features of pulp which distinguish it
                                                     of restoration.
                                                                                                                      from other tissues?
                                                     Even a well done endodontic treatment can get infected

                                                 • Delay in permanent restoration after completion of
                                                     endodontic treatment                                       Q.    What are guidelines given by Ingle and Levine
                                                 • Poor marginal integrity of final restoration                       for standardization of instruments?
                                                 • Fractured tooth                                              Q.   What will be the tip diameter of 40 No. instru-

                                                            Glossary

Abfraction: Abfractions are the microfractures which appear in the         Alveolar crest: The alveolar crest refers to the highest point of the
enamel as cervical area of tooth flexes under heavy loads. Abfraction      alveolar ridge, which extends beyond the tooth socket. The position of
lesion appears as a wedge shaped defect with sharp line angles.            the crest moves slightly upwards as the tooth erupts.
Abrasion: It refers to the loss of tooth substance induced by mechanical   Alveolar eminence: The alveolar eminence is the outline of the root
wear other than that of mastication. Abrasion results in saucer-shaped     on the facet section of the alveolar bone.
or wedge-shaped indentations with a smooth, shiny surface.
                                                                           Alveolus: The bony socket in which the root of the tooth sits.
Abutment: A term used to denote the teeth on either side of a missing
tooth.                                                                     Amalgam: Amalgam is an alloy in which mercury occurs as a main
                                                                           constituent.
Access cavity preparation: It is defined as endodontic coronal
preparation which enables unobstructed access to the canal orifices, a     Amalgam blues: It is the discoloration of tooth which is caused by
straight line access to apical foramen, complete control over              leakage of corrosion products of amalgam restoration.
instrumentation and to accommodate obturation technique.                   Amalgampins: Amalgampins are vertical posts of amalgam anchored
Acid etch technique: It is the process of increasing the surface           in dentin. They increase the retention and resistance of complete
reactivity by demineralizing the superficial calcium layer and thus        restoration.
creating the enamel tags. These tags are responsible for micromechanical   Anaerobic bacteria: Bacteria that do not need oxygen to grow. They
bonding between tooth and restorative resin.                               are generally associated with periodontal disease.
Active carious lesion: A progressive lesion is described as an active      Anatomic crown: It is part of tooth that is covered with enamel.
carious lesion.
                                                                           Anatomic tooth root: It is part of tooth that is covered with cementum.
Active eruption: The emergence of the tooth from its position in the
jaw.                                                                       Angle: It is the junction of two or more surfaces of prepared tooth.
                                                                           Anodontia: The developmental absence of teeth.
Acute dental caries: Acute caries travels towards the pulp at a very
fast speed.                                                                Anomaly: A deviation from the normal or expected outcome.
Adhesion: The sticking together of unlike substances.                      Antagonist: A structure that opposes or counteracts another structure.
Advanced caries: Involves the dentinoenamel junction and less than         Anterior teeth: The front teeth; these are made up of the incisors and
half distance to pulp cavity.                                              canines (cuspid teeth).

Aerobic bacteria: Bacteria which grow in oxygen-rich environments          Apex: The apex often refers to the tip or most superior point of a
in the oral cavity.                                                        structure; the tip of the root of the tooth is also known as the apex.

Agar: A gelatin-like substance obtained from seaweed used in               Apical constriction (Minor diameter): It is apical part of root canal
impression materials.                                                      having the narrowest diameter short of the apical foramina or
                                                                           radiographic apex. It may or may not coincide with CDJ.

involves high energy sandblasting of tooth surface. Basically in an air    Apical delta: It is a triangular area of root surrounded by main canal,
abrasion technique, the abrasion particles are emitted in a well-defined   accessory canals and periradicular tissue.
sharply focused beam to the target.                                        Apical foramen: The opening at the end of the root of a tooth through

compressed air supplied by the compressor. This handpiece has high         Apical foramen (Major diameter): It is main apical opening on the
speed and low torque.                                                      surface of root canal through which blood vessels enter the canal. Its

models.                                                                    shape appearance, which has been described as morning glory or
                                                                           hyperbolic.
Alloy: Alloy is a union of two or more metals.

anchors the roots of the teeth.                                            teeth. It occurs both on occlusal and proximal surfaces. Attrition is

                                                                               teeth in the dental arch; this is common in children between the ages of
Intertubular dentin: This dentin is present between the tubules                6 and 12 when some, but not all, of the deciduous teeth have fallen out
which is less mineralized than peritubular dentin. Intertubular dentin         and been replaced by permanent teeth.
determines the elasticity of the dental matrix.                                Moderate caries: Involves more than half the thickness of enamel,
                                                                               but does not involve dentinoenamel junction.
Intraoral: Inside your mouth.
                                                                               Molars: Distal to premolars are the molars. There are six molars on
Inverted cone bur: It has flat base and sides tapered towards shank.           each arch (three on each side), therefore a total of 12 inside the mouth.
It is used for establishing wall angulations and providing undercuts in        They have multiple cusps which help in crushing and grinding the
tooth preparations.                                                            food. These teeth also help in maintenance of vertical height of the
                                                                               face.
Labial: The term labial refers to the lips, which are also known as the
labia.                                                                         Mulling: Mulling is done so that all alloy particles are properly
                                                                               coated with mercury, in other words it is continuation of the trituration.
Land: It is the plane surface immediately following the cutting edge.          Mulling of the amalgam can be done manually or mechanically. By
                                                                               hand, it can be done by squeezing the freshly mixed amalgam collected
Line angle: It is a junction of two surfaces of different orientations         in the chamois skin. Mechanical mulling is done in the amalgamator by
along the line and its name is derived from the involved surfaces.             triturating it for one to two seconds.
Liner: It is applied in thin layer of less than 0.5 mm so as to attain a       Oblique ridge: It is a ridge obliquely crossing the occlusal surfaces of
physical barrier to pulp and to provide therapeutic effect.                    maxillary molars. It is usually formed by the union of triangular ridge
                                                                               of distobuccal cusp and distal cusp ridge of the mesiolingual cusp.
Lingual fossae: Occur on lingual surface of incisors.
                                                                               Occlusal contact: Any contacting or touching of tooth surfaces is
Lingual: The term lingual refers to the tongue; structures that are            called occlusal contact. Unmodified, contact should involve a normal,
close to the tongue are also often described as being lingual for example,     non-pathologic touching of tooth surfaces. Harmful occlusal contacts
lingual surface of the tooth.                                                  can occur in following forms:
Lobe: It is one of the primary sections of formation in the development        Occlusal surface: Masticating surface of posterior teeth (in molar or
of the crown.                                                                  premolar).
Malocclusion: Any deviation from a physiologically acceptable                  Occlusion: Any contact between the incising or masticating surfaces
contact of opposing dentition is called “malocclusion”.                        of the upper and lower teeth.

                                                 and rest of the crown is covered like three quarter crown and seven-          tooth eruption.
                                                 eighth crown.

                                                 Passive eruption: Describes the process by which teeth continue to            placement of preparation walls to best enables both the tooth and
                                                 erupt into the mouth as tooth structure is lost to attrition and wear.        restoration to withstand, without fracture the stresses of masticatory

                                                 end of cone directed towards shank. It is used in class I tooth               Primary retention form: Primary retention form is that form, shape

                                                 preparation for amalgam.                                                      or removal of restoration from the preparation under lifting and tipping

                                                 teeth.

                                                 as used normally, while the other smaller wedge (Piggyback) is inserted

                                                 with gingival recession.

                                                 Porosity: Porosity is considered as a major defect in the casting which       • Negative rake angle: When rake face is ahead of radial line.
                                                 can occur on the internal as well as on the external surface of the           • Zero rake angle: When rake face and radial line coincide each
                                                 casting. It usually weakens the casting.                                         other.

Rampant caries: It is the name given to multiple active carious lesions      Secondary dentin: Secondary dentin is formed after completion of




                                                                                                                                                        Glossary
occurring in the same patient, frequently involving surfaces of teeth        root formation. In this, the direction of tubules is more asymmetrical
that are usually caries free. It occurs usually due to poor oral hygiene     and complicated as compared to primary dentin.
and taking frequent cariogenic snacks and sweet drinks between meals.
It is also seen in mouths where there is hyposalivation.                     Simple caries: Caries involving only one tooth surface is termed as

• Early childhood caries is a term used to describe dental caries            Simple tooth preparation: A tooth preparation involving only one

     are commonly observed that after radiotherapy of malignant areas

pass through a single point when bur is moving. It measures the

Sclerotic dentin: It occurs due to aging or chronic and mild irritation

(such as slowly advancing caries) which causes a change in the

                                                 separation. It helps in stabilization of retainer and matrix during

                                                 restorative procedures and prevents gingival overhang of restoration.

                                                 inserted from lingual embrasure area while another is inserted between
                                                 the wedge and matrix band at right angle to first wedge.
